Title: Repairing Kenmore Elite HE3 Washer Control Board Relays

Lines.Text: the f-dl door lock error may indicate an inability to open the door , trapping your damp clothes inside . this first step is optional , and explains how to release the door lock manually .
unplug the washing machine !
using a torx t20 screwdriver or a 9 /32 socket wrench or driver , remove the three screws along the bottom front of the washer , and remove the panel .

reach up inside the right hand side behind the door latch , and you should be able to feel a 1 diameter ring . grab the ring with your fingers , and pull it down toward the floor . it will release the door lock .

Steps.Text_raw: The F-DL door lock error may indicate an inability to open the door, trapping your damp clothes inside.  This first step is optional, and explains how to release the door lock manually. Unplug the washing machine! Using a Torx T20 screwdriver or a 9/32" socket wrench or driver, remove the three screws along the bottom front of the washer, and remove the panel. Reach up inside the right hand side behind the door latch, and you should be able to feel a 1" diameter ring.  Grab the ring with your fingers, and pull it down toward the floor.  It will release the door lock.

slide the top panel toward the back of the machine about one half of an inch , and lift the top panel up and off .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the main power cord. To remove the lid, remove the three screws along the back that hold it in place using either a T20 Torx screwdriver or a 9/32" socket driver. Slide the top panel toward the back of the machine about one half of an inch, and lift the top panel up and off.

either apply wire labels , or take a fine-tipped permanent marker and as you disconnect each connector mark it with the two letter name of the mating socket , which you will find stamped on the plastic of the control unit's housing . a flashlight will help reading the letters along the left side of the control unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Mark the wires and note how the cables are routed, so you can return them to their original routes after disassembly. Either apply wire labels, or take a fine-tipped permanent marker and as you disconnect each connector mark it with the two letter name of the mating socket, which you will find stamped on the plastic of the control unit's housing.  A flashlight will help reading the letters along the left side of the control unit.

Lines.Text: remove the control unit by very gently prying up the two outside tabs that hold it to the top crossbar with a flat bladed screwdriver and simultaneously sliding the control unit toward the front of the washer .
only the outer two tabs have a locking notch holding the control unit to the crossbar . the middle tab is there just for support .
open the gray housing of the control unit by gently prying the side tabs open .
remove the circuit board the same way , by gently prying open the tabs holding it down .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the control unit by very gently prying up the two outside tabs that hold it to the top crossbar with a flat bladed screwdriver and simultaneously sliding the control unit toward the front of the washer. Only the outer two tabs have a locking notch holding the control unit to the crossbar. The middle tab is there just for support. Open the gray housing of the control unit by gently prying the side tabs open. Remove the circuit board the same way, by gently prying open the tabs holding it down.

Lines.Text: there are three or five relays on the circuit board . k6 is an omron g2 rl-1 a-e , 12 vdc , and rated to switch 16 a at 250 vac . k1 and k4 are both omron g5 le-1-vd , 12 vdc , and rated to switch 10 a at 250 vac .

k1 controls the door lock solenoid . i found the contacts on it were blackened due to arcing . i didn't bother to find out what the other two relays do , but i cleaned them all anyway . another repairer says that only k1 k4 were inspected ; k1 had significant contanimation k4 looked new by comparison . treated k1 only with all problems resolved !
unsolder one relay at a time from the circuit board , clean or replace it , then solder it back in position .

to unsolder a relay , start by heating the solder at one end of the relay , and gently pull the relay's plastic package with a finger on the hand holding the circuit board . use solder wick to remove excess solder . after making progress at one end , switch to desoldering the contacts at the other end of the relay in the same fashion .

to clean a relay , open its plastic case . blow out the dust and grit . dress the relay contacts with a small piece of folded-in-half 200-400 grit sandpaper , treated with contact cleaner . replace the plastic case on the relay .
solder the relay back onto the circuit board , and repeat with the next relay until all relays are cleaned and/or replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three or five relays on the circuit board.  K6 is an OMRON G2RL-1A-E, 12VDC, and rated to switch 16A at 250 VAC.  K1 and K4 are both OMRON G5LE-1-VD, 12 VDC, and rated to switch 10A at 250 VAC. K1 controls the door lock solenoid.  I found the contacts on it were blackened due to arcing.  I didn't bother to find out what the other two relays do, but I cleaned them all anyway.  Another repairer says that only K1 & K4 were inspected; K1 had significant contanimation & K4 looked new by comparison.  Treated K1 only with all problems resolved! Unsolder one relay at a time from the circuit board, clean or replace it, then solder it back in position. To unsolder a relay, start by heating the solder at one end of the relay, and gently pull the relay's plastic package with a finger on the hand holding the circuit board. Use solder wick to remove excess solder.  After making progress at one end, switch to desoldering the contacts at the other end of the relay in the same fashion. To clean a relay, open its plastic case. Blow out the dust and grit.  Dress the relay contacts with a small piece of folded-in-half 200-400 grit sandpaper, treated with contact cleaner. Replace the plastic case on the relay. Solder the relay back onto the circuit board, and repeat with the next relay until all relays are cleaned and/or replaced.

Title: Testing the Starbucks Barista Heating Element

Lines.Text: remove the 6 phillips 1 screws from the back panel .
remove the back panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 6 Phillips #1 screws from the back panel. Remove the back panel.

Lines.Text: make sure the machine is turned off and unplugged .
set your voltmeter in continuity mode and place the leads on the two 90 degree prongs on the boiler's heating element .
it does not matter which lead touches which prong as you're just testing for a break , or open in the heating element circuit . '''
if the voltmeter shows 0 , or open , then there is an issue with the heating element's continuity and it needs to be replaced .
if given a reading , then your heating element is fine .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the machine is turned off and unplugged. Set your voltmeter in continuity mode and place the leads on the two 90 degree prongs on the boiler's heating element. It does not matter which lead touches which prong as you're just testing for a break, or "open" in the heating element circuit.''' If the voltmeter shows 0, or "open", then there is an issue with the heating element's continuity and it needs to be replaced. If given a reading, then your heating element is fine.

see the links section of the device page for further directions .

Steps.Text_raw: In the water reservoir, place mixture of de-calcifying agent and water as directed on the product label. Place a cup, to catch fluid, underneath the portafilter. Lines.Text: this is looking toward the top . there are three phillips screws that need to be removed .
once removed , the black cover that holds the popping chamber can be removed . the popping chamber and the black cover are removed as one piece .

Steps.Text_raw: This is looking toward the top. There are three Phillips screws that need to be removed. Once removed, the black cover that holds the popping chamber can be removed. the popping chamber and the black cover are removed as one piece.

Lines.Text: the bottom cover is fastened with four screws . remove those .
once the bottom cover is removed , the blower motor is clearly visible .
where the power cable attaches to the motor , are four diodes . these diodes only allow half-cycle of a full cycle of positive and negative power cycle to reach the motor .
the motor only gets current in one direction , allowing it to spin in one direction . after all , we are dealing with ac current here .

Steps.Text_raw: The bottom cover is fastened with four screws. Remove those. Once the bottom cover is removed, the blower motor is clearly visible. Where the power cable attaches to the motor, are four diodes. These diodes only allow half-cycle of a full cycle of positive and negative power cycle to reach the motor. The motor only gets current in one direction,allowing it to spin in one direction. After all, we are dealing with AC current here.

Lines.Text: with the bottom cover off , the hot air assembly will easily slide out . power connections and temperature control are clearly visible .
use a multimeter to check the switch for continuity .
check the heating element for continuity .

Steps.Text_raw: With the bottom cover off, the hot air assembly will easily slide out. Power connections and temperature control are clearly visible. Use a multimeter to check the switch for continuity. Check the heating element for continuity.

Lines.Text: the problem that was visible on close inspections with a magnifying glass , was a charred diode .
removed the diode ( it was attached by point-to-point soldering to the other ones ) by de-soldering .
replace the faulty diode . description on the diode was v81 n4001.

Steps.Text_raw: The problem that was visible on close inspections with a magnifying glass, was a charred diode. removed the diode (it was attached by point-to-point soldering to the other ones) by de-soldering. Replace the faulty diode. Description on the diode was V81 N4001.

Title: Kenwood Chef A701A New Feet Replacement

Lines.Text: why put new feet on your chef ?
it is important for proper airflow and cooling of the motor . the chef is built to take air in and push it past the motor and out the bottom .
no feet means the airflow is directed through the case where its not supposed to go .
this is the consquence . ewwwwwww ! and this was after one vacuum . 40 years of flour from ebay !

Steps.Text_raw: Why put new feet on your Chef? It is important for proper airflow and cooling of the motor. The Chef is built to take air in and push it past the motor and out the bottom. No feet means the airflow is directed through the case where its not supposed to go. This is the consquence. Ewwwwwww! And this was after one vacuum. 40 years of flour from ebay!

when you've gripped the old pin , turn it anticlockwise- the pin has a clockwise spiral on it .

try to not let water get into the toaster as this may damage the heating coil .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the tray is exposed, it is possible to clean the face here. Try to not let water get into the toaster as this may damage the heating coil. If the tray can not be cleaned simply by opening it, keep going through the guide to fully remove it.

Lines.Text: to remove the tray , the metal hinges must be bent up .

while applying pressure to the bottom of the toaster , use pliers or tweezers to bend up the bracket . the pressure applied to the bottom of the toaster should be just enough to allow the bracket to swing up .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the tray, the metal hinges must be bent up. While applying pressure to the bottom of the toaster, use pliers or tweezers to bend up the bracket. turn the toaster upside down and remove the rubber stopper feet with your fingers .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the toaster is unplugged before starting. Burnt hair smells even worse than burnt toast! Turn the toaster upside down and remove the rubber stopper "feet" with your fingers.

Lines.Text: using a 2 phillips head screwdriver , remove the four 12 mm screws that attach the shell to the rest of the toaster .

Lines.Text: with the dial facing you , push the toaster base up and away until the base is just over the lip of the shell . this will disconnect the browning dial from the rest of the toaster .
when reassembling the toaster , make sure that the back of the dial lines up with the slot both in position and orientation ( the dial and slot are not perfect circles - they have a notch ) .
the only object holding the shell onto the toaster now is the grey part of the lever .

Lines.Text: reach under the shell and grab the back , white part of the lever .
grab the grey lever between your index finger and your middle finger and pull .
pulling too hard will break the mechanism that holds the grey handle onto the white lever .
remove the shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach under the shell and grab the back, white part of the lever. Grab the grey lever between your index finger and your middle finger and pull. Pulling too hard will break the mechanism that holds the grey handle onto the white lever. Remove the shell.

repeat this for the other side .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the spring, use the tweezers to push the bottom edge of the spring out and around the metal bracket that keeps the springs in place. Repeat this for the other side.

Lines.Text: pulling the bottom of the spring out , lift the left circle up over the metal bracket that extends out from the bread grabbers .
bring the right circle out , down , and around the bracket the extends out from the shelf that the toast would sits on .
remove the right circle .

Lines.Text: make sure that all the angles are similar to the other metal spring .
if not , then bend the broken spring to the angles of the correct spring .

Lines.Text: to begin fixing the lever spring , remove the top metal plate of the toaster .
to do this , locate the four metal bending couples that keep it attached ( two in front , two in back ) .
bend down each of the bending couples that are currently at a ninety degree angle .
lift the plate and remove .

Steps.Text_raw: To begin fixing the lever spring, remove the top metal plate of the toaster. To do this, locate the four metal bending couples that keep it attached (two in front, two in back). Bend down each of the bending couples that are currently at a ninety  degree angle. Lift the plate and remove.

Lines.Text: locate the metal u bracket that is in the middle of the two toaster slots .
the bracket is secured by two protruding metal strips that are twisted and one metal strip on the lever side that is bent over the pole .
using pliers or tweezers , untwist the two metal strips .
use pliers or tweezers to unfold the metal sheet that keeps the pole in place .
pull up on the bracket and remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the metal "U" bracket that is in the middle of the two toaster slots. The bracket is secured by two protruding metal strips that are twisted and one metal strip on the lever side that is bent over the pole. Using pliers or tweezers, untwist the two metal strips. Use pliers or tweezers to unfold the metal sheet that keeps the pole in place. Pull up on the bracket and remove.

Lines.Text: remove the short top spring from the pole .
find the bottom of the pole and push it up through the top of the white lever bracket .
prepare for the spring to jump out as it will no longer be held in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the short top spring from the pole. Find the bottom of the pole and push it up through the top of the white lever bracket. Prepare for the spring to jump out as it will no longer be held in place.

Lines.Text: use soap and water to clean the spring and rod . if you can not complete the third bullet , just brush of the debris as the soap will remove the lubricant .
ensure there are no crumbs restricting the compression of the spring or movement along the pole .
now use a commercial lubricant , such as wd-40 , to re-lubricate the pole and springs .

Steps.Text_raw: Use soap and water to clean the spring and rod. If you can not complete the third bullet, just brush of the debris as the soap will remove the lubricant. Ensure there are no crumbs restricting the compression of the spring or movement along the pole. Now use a commercial lubricant, such as WD-40, to re-lubricate the pole and springs.

Lines.Text: with the dial facing you , push the toaster base up and away until the base is just over the lip of the shell . this will disconnect the browning dial from the rest of the toaster .
when reassembling the toaster , make sure that the back of the dial lines up with the slot both in position and orientation ( the dial and slot are not perfect circles - they have a notch ) .
the only object holding the shell onto the toaster now is the grey part of the lever .

Steps.Text_raw: With the dial facing you, push the toaster base up and away until the base is just over the lip of the shell. This will disconnect the browning dial from the rest of the toaster. When reassembling the toaster, make sure that the back of the dial lines up with the slot both in position and orientation (the dial and slot are not perfect  circles - they have a notch). The only object holding the shell onto the  toaster now is the grey part of the lever.

Lines.Text: reach under the shell and grab the back , white part of the lever .
grab the grey lever between your index finger and your middle finger and pull .
pulling too hard will break the mechanism that holds the grey handle onto the white lever .
remove the shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach under the shell and grab the back, white part of the lever. Grab the grey lever between your index finger and your middle finger and pull. Pulling too hard will break the mechanism that holds the grey handle onto the white lever. Remove the shell.

Lines.Text: after disassembling the toaster , turn the back side of the toaster towards you .
on the back of the toaster the metal tabs attached to the bread shelf should be visible .
these tabs will sometimes get caught in the shaft which disables your toaster from returning the bread .

Steps.Text_raw: After disassembling the toaster, turn the back side of the toaster towards you. On the back of the toaster the metal tabs attached to the bread shelf should be visible. These tabs will sometimes get caught in the shaft which disables your toaster from returning the bread.

Lines.Text: twist the metal tabs to vertical position to allow them to glide along the slot .
push down on the white lever on the opposite side repeatedly to ensure that the metal tabs will no longer stick .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the metal tabs to vertical position to allow them to glide along the slot. Push down on the white lever on the opposite side repeatedly to ensure that the metal tabs will no longer stick.

Title: Quasar Microwave Capacitor Replacement

Lines.Text: disconnect the power supply cord from the outlet .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the power supply cord from the outlet.

Lines.Text: remove the eight screws holding the wood-patterned cover to the microwave frame .
the first four screws are located on either side of the microwave front .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight screws holding the wood-patterned cover to the microwave frame. The first four screws are located on either side of the microwave front.

Lines.Text: remove the additional four screws securing the wood-paneled case to the microwave frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the additional four screws securing the wood-paneled case to the microwave frame.

Lines.Text: placing your hands on either side of the case , slide the case back gently until you feel it completely separate from the microwave frame .
lift the case upward slowly until the case is free of the microwave .

Steps.Text_raw: Placing your hands on either side of the case, slide the case back gently until you feel it completely separate from the microwave frame. Lift the case upward slowly until the case is free of the microwave.

Lines.Text: old electronics collect dust , no matter if they are in active use or being stored . it is recommended to clear out some of the dust prior to affecting any complicated repairs . use compressed air , and wear a dust mask and goggles . always use precaution when working with old electronics .

the capacitor stores a small amount of electrical energy . discharge capacitor by placing a screwdriver across the terminals . use a screwdriver with a non-metallic handle and a shaft that is longer than 4 ( 10.75 mm ) touch the metal shaft of the screwdriver simultaneously to both metal terminals of the capacitor . there should be a spark .
if the capacitor sparks , you can stop reading here . the spark indicates that the capacitor is working properly . if the capacitor does not spark , read on to step 6.

Steps.Text_raw: Old electronics collect dust, no matter if they are in active use or being stored. It is recommended to clear out some of the dust prior to affecting any complicated repairs. Use compressed air, and wear a dust mask and goggles. Always use precaution when working with old electronics. The capacitor stores a small amount of electrical energy. Discharge capacitor by placing a screw driver across the terminals. Use a screwdriver with a non-metallic handle and a shaft that is longer than 4” (10.75mm) Touch the metal shaft of the screwdriver simultaneously to both metal terminals of the capacitor. There should be a spark. If the capacitor sparks, you can stop reading here. The spark indicates that the capacitor is working properly. If the capacitor does not spark, read on to Step 6.

Lines.Text: place the multimeter on resistance mode and test the resistance of the capacitor .
if the resistance increases/decreases , the capacitor is working fine . if the resistance of the capacitor reads 0 or over several kilo ohms , the capacitor needs to be replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the multimeter on resistance mode and test the resistance of the capacitor. If the resistance increases/decreases, the capacitor is working fine. If the resistance of the capacitor reads 0 or over several kilo ohms, the capacitor needs to be replaced.

Lines.Text: tip the microwave back so it is lying face up . this allows access to the screws beneath the transformer .

Steps.Text_raw: Tip the microwave back so it is lying face up. This allows access to the screws beneath the transformer.

Lines.Text: locate the transformer . the capacitor cannot be removed without removing the transformer first .
locate and unhook all wires connecting the transformer to the rest of the microwave .
take note of where each wire connects before disconnecting . wiring a microwave incorrectly can cause serious damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the transformer. The capacitor cannot be removed without removing the transformer first. Locate and unhook all wires connecting the transformer to the rest of the microwave. Take note of where each wire connects before disconnecting. Wiring a microwave incorrectly can cause serious damage.

Lines.Text: remove the four exterior screws securing the transformer to the microwave frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four exterior screws securing the transformer to the microwave frame.

Lines.Text: remove the transformer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the transformer.

Lines.Text: the metal band locking the capacitor in place can now be accessed . locate and remove the screw securing the the metal band .
lift the metal band off the capacitor .

Steps.Text_raw: The metal band locking the capacitor in place can now be accessed. Locate and remove the screw securing the the metal band. Lift the metal band off the capacitor.

Lines.Text: remove the capacitor .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the capacitor.

Lines.Text: you can now install a replacement capacitor .
repeat all steps in reverse order to install a capacitor in a quasar microwave mq7774 xw ( 1984 ) .

Steps.Text_raw: You can now install a replacement capacitor. Repeat all steps in reverse order to install a capacitor in a Quasar Microwave MQ7774XW (1984).

Subject: Capacitor

Title: Nostalgia Electrics RHP-310 Power Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug popper .
remove plastic lid by picking the lid up .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug popper. Remove plastic lid by picking the lid up.

Lines.Text: flip the popper on its side .
remove the screws on the bottom with the phillips 2 phillips head screwdriver .
there are seven screws on the base . five screws on the perimeter ( 12 mm phillips 2 screws ) and two in the middle ( 15 mm phillips 2 screws ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the popper on its side. Remove the screws on the bottom with the Phillips #2 phillips head screwdriver. There are seven screws on the base.  Five screws on the perimeter (12mm Philips #2 screws) and two in the middle (15 mm Philips #2 screws).

Lines.Text: remove the base .
save the screws you took out of the bottom in a safe place . they will be needed to reattach the housing to the base .
unscrew the two screws ( 10 mm phillips 2 screws ) from the base .
remove the base and set it aside for now .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the base. Save the screws you took out of the bottom in a safe place.  They will be needed to reattach the housing to the base. Unscrew the two screws (10 mm Philips #2 screws) from the base. Remove the base and set it aside for now.

Lines.Text: locate the power switch connected to the side of the housing .
carefully pinch the sides of the power switch .
push the power button up and out of the housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the power switch connected to the side of the housing. Carefully pinch the sides of the power switch. Push the power button up and out of the housing.

Lines.Text: now that the power switch is removed from the housing , you have to remove the wires connected to the power switch .
use the plastic opening tool to gently pry the wires loose from the power switch .
the wires should pop easily out from the power switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the power switch is removed from the housing, you have to remove the wires connected to the power switch. Use the plastic opening tool to gently pry the wires loose from the power switch. The wires should pop easily out from the power switch.

Lines.Text: remove the power switch from the device .
you can now replace the power switch if necessary .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the power switch from the device. You can now replace the power switch if necessary.

Subject: Power Switch

Title: Sanitaire SC684 front wheel replacement

Lines.Text: be sure to unplug the vacuum before disassembling it to prevent electric shock .
lay vacuum on side .
using a phillips screwdriver , unscrew the screw behind the front wheels , on the edge of the underside of the vacuum cleaner .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure to unplug the vacuum before disassembling it to prevent electric shock. Lay vacuum on side. Using a Phillips screwdriver, unscrew the screw behind the front wheels, on the edge of the underside of the vacuum cleaner.

Lines.Text: stand the vacuum upright and identify the dial on the front of the vacuum .
unscrew the screw using a torx 20 screwdriver
pull the dial out .

Steps.Text_raw: Stand the vacuum upright and identify the dial on the front of the vacuum. Unscrew the screw using a Torx 20 screwdriver Pull the dial out.

Lines.Text: lift the cover off of the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the cover off of the vacuum.

Lines.Text: identify the two gray metal plates at the front of the vacuum .
using the t20 torx screwdriver , remove the four screws on the smaller gray plate holding the larger gray metal plates .

Steps.Text_raw: Identify the two gray metal plates at the front of the vacuum. Using the T20 Torx screwdriver, remove the four screws on the smaller gray plate holding the larger gray metal plates.

Lines.Text: remove the small metal plate with the black bolt in the center .
repeat on opposite side near the other wheel

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the small metal plate with the black bolt in the center. Repeat on opposite side near the other wheel

Lines.Text: remove the larger gray metal plate .
repeat on opposite side near other wheel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the larger gray metal plate. Repeat on opposite side near other wheel.

Lines.Text: remove the front wheels by lifting the silver bar that attaches the two wheels .
detach the spring attaching the wheels to the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the front wheels by lifting the silver bar that attaches the two wheels. Detach the spring attaching the wheels to the vacuum.

Lines.Text: remove a wheel from the wheel's axel by pulling off the wheel .
slide spring off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove a wheel from the wheel's axel by pulling off the wheel. Slide spring off.

Subject: Front Wheels

Title: Kenmore 110 Series Washing Machine Lid Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: to avoid risk of electric shock , unplug the washing machine .
using a 5 /16 socket wrench or an adjustable wrench , remove the three screws from the top rear of the washer .
lifting from the rear , remove the top panel .
set the top panel on its rear face , with its underside facing you .
the top panel will still be connected to the washer by wires and hoses . it will help if you have a flat raised surface to set the top panel on .

Steps.Text_raw: To avoid risk of electric shock, unplug the washing machine. Using a 5/16" socket wrench or an adjustable wrench, remove the three screws from the top rear of the washer. Lifting from the rear, remove the top panel. Set the top panel on its rear face, with its underside facing you. The top panel will still be connected to the washer by wires and hoses. It will help if you have a flat raised surface to set the top panel on.

Lines.Text: using a 5 /16 socket wrench or hand wrench , remove the two screws from the component cover .
gripping from the bottom , pull the component cover out of the washer .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 5/16" socket wrench or hand wrench, remove the two screws from the component cover. Gripping from the bottom, pull the component cover out of the washer.

Lines.Text: carefully unplug the two wires connected to the lid switch .
remove the two phillips screws securing the bracket .
remove the green ground wire .
with a screwdriver , remove the single screw connecting the lid switch to the bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully unplug the two wires connected to the lid switch. Remove the two Phillips screws securing the bracket. Remove the green ground wire. With a screwdriver, remove the single screw connecting the lid switch to the bracket.

Subject: Lid Switch

Lines.Text: unplug the washing machine !
using a 5 /16 socket wrench or an adjustable wrench , remove the three screws from the top rear of the washer .
lifting from the rear , remove the top panel .
the top panel will still be connected by wires and hoses . it will help if you have a flat raised surface to set the top panel on .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the washing machine! Using a 5/16" socket wrench or an adjustable wrench, remove the three screws from the top rear of the washer. Lifting from the rear, remove the top panel. The top panel will still be connected by wires and hoses. It will help if you have a flat raised surface to set the top panel on.

Lines.Text: using a 5 /16 socket wrench or a hand wrench , remove the two screws from the component cover .
from the bottom , pull out and remove the component cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 5/16" socket wrench or a hand wrench, remove the two screws from the component cover. From the bottom, pull out and remove the component cover.

Lines.Text: remove wires from water level sensor .
with a phillips screwdriver remove the mounting screw .
cut the zip tie and remove water level hose .

carefully lay washing machine on its back .

pull the pump out of place .
pulling the pump away takes a little force .

make sure the fan is unplugged while removing the circuit board as you may get shocked .
to remove the screws , unscrew in a left-to-right fashion at an angle to make sure that the wires do not get tangled .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Phillips (5-mm head) 6-mm screw that holds the circuit board to the outer shell of the fan. Make sure the fan is unplugged while removing the circuit board as you may get shocked. To remove the screws, unscrew in a left-to-right fashion at an angle to make sure that the wires do not get tangled.

Lines.Text: remove the top cover containing the circuit board and the wires by pulling it away from the body of the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top cover containing the circuit board and the wires by pulling it away from the body of the fan.

Lines.Text: remove the circuit board from the top cover . do not touch the other side of the circuit board as you may damage circuit elements .
unscrew the four screws on the top of the circuit board in a left-to-right fashion . after pull screws out of the board .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the circuit board from the top cover. Do not touch the other side of the circuit board as you  may damage circuit elements. Unscrew the four screws on the top of the circuit board in a left-to-right fashion. After pull screws out of the board.

Lines.Text: follow steps 1-4 to remove the front , back , and top covers of the fan to reach the fan blades .
use a cloth to clean off dust clogged in between the fan blades .

Steps.Text_raw: Follow steps 1-4 to remove the front, back, and top covers of the fan to reach the fan blades. Use a cloth to clean off dust clogged in between the fan blades.

be careful not to pull the front cover off completely because it holds the wires .

after the holding nut is loose , use the pliers to pull up to remove the nut .

Lines.Text: remove the two bronze phillips 29-mm bolts that hold the fan blade to the transformer .
use a pair of pliers to hold the nut at the bottom of the transformer , as you unscrew from left-to-right at the top of the transformer . after , pull up and remove both the screw and nut .

remove screws by pulling them away from the base .
the transformer should be free after this step .

lubricate the track with grease .

Title: GD Midea FT30-3D Power/Speed Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: locate and remove the 14.5 mm phillips 1 screw on the bottom of the fan base .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the 14.5 mm Phillips #1 screw on the bottom of the fan base.

Lines.Text: locate the gray base support release tabs found on either side pictured in the first image .
there are release tabs on each side of the base .
press both release tabs in with the tip of your fingers and pull the gray base support until the tabs are cleared .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the gray base support release tabs found on either side pictured in the first image. There are release tabs on each side of the base. Press both release tabs in with the tip of your fingers and pull the gray base support until the tabs are cleared.

Lines.Text: continue removing the gray base support by pressing your thumb into the circular opening in the base and pulling with your figures on the back side .
'''notice''' that on the internal front tip of the base there is a tab . because of this tab the back end will pivot off at that point .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue removing the gray base support by pressing your thumb into the circular opening in the base and pulling with your figures on the back side. '''Notice''' that on the internal front tip of the base there is a tab. Because of this tab the back end will pivot off at that point.

Lines.Text: after the base has separated more it will be easy to fully remove it . continue pulling the back edge of the gray base support , rotating it around the front tab until it comes off completely .

Steps.Text_raw: After the base has separated more it will be easy to fully remove it. Continue pulling the back edge of the gray base support, rotating it around the front tab until it comes off completely.

Lines.Text: remove the following five 14.5 mm phillips 1 screws found on the bottom .
all of the screws are recessed by 17.5 mm , so ensure your screwdriver can reach that far .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following five 14.5 mm Phillips #1 screws found on the bottom. All of the screws are recessed by 17.5 mm, so ensure your screwdriver can reach that far.

Lines.Text: once all five screws have been removed the base cover should fall right off with out any effort .
when putting the base cover back on ; be careful to make sure that none of the wires are pinched .

Steps.Text_raw: Once all five screws have been removed the base cover should fall right off with out any effort. When putting the base cover back on; be careful to make sure that none of the wires are pinched.

Lines.Text: remove the two 10 mm phillips 1 screws found connecting the switch to the case .
notice the ac power cord line ( white wire ) goes into the switch under the '''off''' button

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 10 mm Phillips #1 screws found connecting the switch to the case. Notice the AC power cord line (white wire) goes into the switch under the '''[Off]''' button

Lines.Text: take the 1.5 mm flathead screwdriver , or any thin elongated tool that fits into the semi-circular holes along side the wires . press into the hole gently to release the grip on the wires .
the wires should release with ease if done properly .
when reassembling ; skip this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the 1.5 mm Flathead Screwdriver, or any thin elongated tool that fits into the semi-circular holes along side the wires. Press into the hole gently to release the grip on the wires. The wires should release with ease if done properly. When reassembling; skip this step.

Lines.Text: take the new switch , and simply push the wiring into the correct holes :
ac power cord ( white wire )
low speed ( gray wire )
medium speed ( orange wire )
high speed ( red wire )

Steps.Text_raw: Take the new switch, and simply push the wiring into the correct holes: AC Power Cord (white wire) Low speed (gray wire) Medium speed (orange wire) High speed (red wire)

Subject: Power/Speed Switch

four 18 mm phillips screws .

two 8 mm phillips screws .
the cover will not remove entirely . keep ''green'' ground wire attached to the cover .

ensure that only the water inlet valve can be moved .

this creates more slack in the wire to give you more room to work with .
do not remove green wire from the cover its attached to .

do not yank them out from the other end . move them aside and out of the way .

the wires for the switch will need to be tied back to the wires leading to the battery . if necessary , use electrical tape .

Title: Black and Decker Toast R Oven On/Off switch Replacement
Category: Black and Decker Toast R Oven

Lines.Text: make sure that the toaster is unplugged before you begin .
turn the toaster over with its backside face down .
remove the two phillips 4 1cm screws that attach the side panels .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure that the toaster is unplugged before you begin. Turn the toaster over with its backside face down. Remove the two Phillips #4 1cm screws that attach the side panels.

Lines.Text: pull downwards ( towards the bottom of the unit ) and outward to remove the side panels .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull downwards (towards the bottom of the unit) and outward to remove the side panels.

Lines.Text: remove the metal vent piece that is below the door .
this should slide off easily once both of the side panels are removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the metal vent piece that is below the door. This should slide off easily once both of the side panels are removed.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips 4 1 cm screws , which connect the bottom panel to the unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips #4 1 cm screws, which connect the bottom panel to the unit.

Lines.Text: remove the crumb tray ( the bottom , metal panel ) from the toaster unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the crumb tray (the bottom, metal panel) from the toaster unit.

Lines.Text: remove the aluminum strip from the bottom of unit ; this is the piece that is directly under the door .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the aluminum strip from the bottom of unit; this is the piece that is directly under the door.

Lines.Text: remove the knobs by pulling them upward ; they should slide right off .
when placing the knobs back on the unit , make sure the semicircle notch fits correctly in the hole so that the knobs don't fall off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the knobs by pulling them upward; they should slide right off. When placing the knobs back on the unit, make sure the semicircle notch fits correctly in the hole so that the knobs don't fall off.

Lines.Text: unhook the bottom of the the display panel from the toaster unit .
it will be a little tough to pry off , but don't be afraid to be forceful . you can use your hands , or pliers , to bend the metal piece backwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Unhook the bottom of the the display panel from the toaster unit. It will be a little tough to pry off, but don't be afraid to be forceful. You can use your hands, or pliers, to bend the metal piece backwards.

Lines.Text: begin to detach the back panel from the toaster unit .
then , unhook the rest of the display panel .
this will also be a little tough to get off , but don't be afraid to be forceful .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin to detach the back panel from the toaster unit. Then, unhook the rest of the display panel. This will also be a little tough to get off, but don't be afraid to be forceful.

Lines.Text: now , you can clean the outside units of the toaster oven .

Steps.Text_raw: Now, you can clean the outside units of the toaster oven.

Lines.Text: remove the the heating coil protection bar from the toaster unit by first pulling out the left side .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the the heating coil protection bar from the toaster unit by first pulling out the left side.

Lines.Text: finish removing the outside cover by lifting the lid upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Finish removing the outside cover by lifting the lid upward.

Lines.Text: remove the four phillips 4 1 cm screws from the back of the unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Phillips #4 1 cm screws from the back of the unit.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips 4 1 cm screws that were under the faceplate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips #4 1 cm screws that were under the faceplate.

Lines.Text: forcefully bend back the faceplate in order to get to the knob .

Lines.Text: remove switch from the opening it protrudes from .

Title: Dyson DC14 Brush Bar Replacement

Lines.Text: turn off the vacuum and unplug it from the outlet .
lay the vacuum on its top so that the brush bar faces you .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn off the vacuum and unplug it from the outlet. Lay the vacuum on its top so that the brush bar faces you.

Lines.Text: using a quarter , turn the three soleplate fasteners 90 degrees to the left .
holding the soleplate on both sides , tilt it down and away from the vacuum .
remove the soleplate from the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a quarter,  turn the three soleplate fasteners 90 degrees to the left. Holding the soleplate on both sides, tilt it down and away from the vacuum. Remove the soleplate from the vacuum.

Lines.Text: turn down the squared tabs on the brushbar so that they face outward .
use a screwdriver to pry the belt up from the brushbar .
be careful not to cut the belt with the screwdriver .
while holding the belt , pull the brushbar to the left and remove it from the vacuum .
you can let go of the belt when it's free from the brushbar . the belt will not retract into the vacuum .
during reassembly , insert the brushbar with the tabs facing outward , then rotate the tabs up to lock the brushbar in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn down the squared tabs on the brushbar so that they face outward. Use a screwdriver to pry the belt up from the brushbar. Be careful not to cut the belt with the screwdriver. While holding the belt, pull the brushbar to the left and remove it from the vacuum. You can let go of the belt when it's free from the brushbar.  The belt will not retract into the vacuum. During reassembly, insert the brushbar with the tabs facing outward, then rotate the tabs up to lock the brushbar in place.

Subject: Brush Bar

Title: Black and Decker BL3000S button panel replacement

Lines.Text: before disassembling the blender base , make sure the blender disconnected from any power outlet .
lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling the blender base, make sure the blender disconnected from any power outlet. Lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar.

Lines.Text: remove the top three 1 /4 inch base screws using a phillip's head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top three 1/4 inch base screws using a Philip's head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver .
this provides access to the base screws beneath .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver. This provides access to the base screws beneath.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws that secure the top and bottom halves of the base .
one 1 /4 phillips screw
one ta-20 screw
both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank ( length ) .
screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws that secure the top and  bottom halves of the base. One 1/4 Phillips screw One TA-20 screw Both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank (length). Screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes.

Lines.Text: lift the top half of the base from the bottom half of the base to reveal the internal mechanism .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the top half of the base from the bottom half of the base to reveal the internal mechanism.

Lines.Text: once you have the base removed , the circuit board should be clearly visible inside .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have the base removed, the circuit board should be clearly visible inside.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws located on the circuit board .
two are on the left side .
two are on the right side .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws located on the circuit board. Two are on the left side. Two are on the right side.

Lines.Text: remove the following soldered connections with a soldering iron :
motor wires
power cord wires

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following soldered connections with a soldering iron: Motor wires Power cord wires

Lines.Text: lift the circuit board straight up to remove it from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the circuit board straight up to remove it from the base.

Lines.Text: once the circuit board has been freed from its screws it can be moved out of the way to gain access to the buttons .
a single screw must be removed from the top as shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the circuit board has been freed from its screws it can be moved out of the way to gain access to the buttons. A single screw must be removed from the top as shown.

Lines.Text: push firmly from the outside of the blender on the face of the buttons to pop it out of its locked position .

Steps.Text_raw: Push firmly from the outside of the blender on the face of the buttons to pop it out of its locked position.

Lines.Text: provided is a front and a back view of a functioning button frame from the bl3000 s .
check for cracks , bends , debris , or missing extentions and fastens .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling the blender base, make sure the blender disconnected from any power outlet. Lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar.

Lines.Text: remove the top three 1 /4 inch base screws using a phillip's head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top three 1/4 inch base screws using a Philip's head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver .
this provides access to the base screws beneath .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver. This provides access to the base screws beneath.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws that secure the top and bottom halves of the base .
one 1 /4 phillips screw
one ta-20 screw
both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank ( length ) .
screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws that secure the top and  bottom halves of the base. One 1/4 Phillips screw One TA-20 screw Both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank (length). Screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes.

Lines.Text: lift the top half of the base from the bottom half of the base to reveal the internal mechanism .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the top half of the base from the bottom half of the base to reveal the internal mechanism.

Subject: Blender Base

lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar .

this provides access to the base screws beneath .

use a small towel to hold the fan in place . this makes taking off the nut easier to do .

Title: Black and Decker BL3000S Circuit Board

Lines.Text: before disassembling the blender base , make sure the blender disconnected from any power outlet .
lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar .

Steps.Text_raw: Before disassembling the blender base, make sure the blender disconnected from any power outlet. Lift the jar straight up from the base without tilting the jar.

Lines.Text: remove the top three 1 /4 inch base screws using a phillip's head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top three 1/4 inch base screws using a Philip's head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver .
this provides access to the base screws beneath .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two base leg covers next to the power cord using pliers or a flat-head screwdriver. This provides access to the base screws beneath.

Lines.Text: remove the following screws that secure the top and bottom halves of the base .
one 1 /4 phillips screw
one ta-20 screw
both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank ( length ) .
screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the following screws that secure the top and  bottom halves of the base. One 1/4 Phillips screw One TA-20 screw Both screwdrivers must have a minimum of a three inch shank (length). Screwdrivers with extenders will not fit down the access holes.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws located on the circuit board .
two are on the left side .
two are on the right side .

Lines.Text: remove the following soldered connections with a soldering iron :
motor wires
power cord wires
