Title: How to Fix a Noisy Maytag Dryer LDE8604ACE

Lines.Text: obtain replacement parts . i found a mfr's parts list for my unit through a search . all parts that i wanted were available via amazon . my entire bill with shipping was under 50.

Steps.Text_raw: Obtain replacement parts. I found a mfr's  parts list for my unit through a search. All parts that I wanted were available via  Amazon. My entire bill with shipping was under $50.

Lines.Text: here are the tools i used . the riveter and snap ring pliers were bought new , since i've never owned those and i'm a tool collector .

Steps.Text_raw: Here are the tools I used. The riveter and snap ring pliers were bought new, since I've never owned those and I'm a tool collector.

Lines.Text: unplug the dryer . first clear a 2-3 feet of space in front of the dryer . you will be pulling large parts out of the front .
use screwdriver to remove front of unit . be careful to release wires from holding clips .
now remove inner bulkhead , using nutdriver ?
at idler pulley , work the belt loose from its drive and remove it from the dryer .
dryer drum can now be removed . gently lift it out of the dryer .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the dryer. First clear a 2-3 feet of space in front of the dryer.  You will be pulling large parts out of the front. Use screwdriver to remove front of unit. Be careful to release wires from holding clips. Now remove inner bulkhead, using nutdriver? At idler pulley, work the belt loose from its drive and remove it from the dryer. Dryer drum can now be removed. Gently lift it out of the dryer.

Lines.Text: locate both drum rollers in the dryer . see photo
remove old drum roller . the bearings wear out in these . first remove the snap ring on the front of the shaft . then pull off the roller .
remove old drum roller shaft . these can get worn after years of use . they come off by twisting them counter-clockwise .
install new shaft , drum roller , and snap ring . repeat for other roller , since there are 2 in this unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate both drum rollers in the dryer. See photo Remove old drum roller. The bearings wear out in these. First remove the snap ring on the front of the shaft. Then pull off the roller. Remove old drum roller shaft. These can get worn after years of use. They come off by twisting them counter-clockwise. Install new shaft, drum roller, and snap ring. Repeat for other roller, since there are 2 in this unit.

Lines.Text: replace old idler pulley . these can get noisy and sticky as their bearings wear out .
remove snap ring . old pulley will come off . inspect and clean the shaft . install new pulley . install snap ring .
i didn't replace my idler pulley tension spring , but if yours is broken or stretched , the part is maytag 303945

Steps.Text_raw: Replace old idler pulley. These can get noisy and sticky as their bearings wear out. Remove snap ring. Old pulley will come off. Inspect and clean the shaft. Install new pulley. Install snap ring. I didn't replace my idler pulley tension spring, but if yours is broken or stretched, the part is Maytag #303945

Lines.Text: replace blower wheel . these crack and break after a few years' use .
remove snap ring . remove old wheel . install new wheel . install snap ring .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace blower wheel. These crack and break after a few years' use. Remove snap ring. Remove old wheel. Install new wheel. Install snap ring.

Lines.Text: replace front glides/pads . these parts reduce friction between the spinning drum and bulkhead . over time they become less effective . they are inexpensive to replace and a good excuse to play with a riveter .
drill out rivets of old glides . i used a ? bit . pull up old glides .
fit new pad and glide into place . install with ? rivets that were included in kit .
repeat for other glide location

Steps.Text_raw: Replace front glides/pads. These parts reduce friction between the spinning drum and bulkhead. Over time they become less effective. They are inexpensive to replace and a good excuse to play with a riveter. Drill out rivets of old glides. I used a ? bit. Pull up old glides. Fit new pad and glide into place. Install with ? rivets that were included in kit. Repeat for other glide location

Lines.Text: install drum back into dryer . verify that it rolls smoothly on rollers .
install new belt into dryer . see photo for proper belt path through the idler pulley .
turn the drum a few times to verify belt will stay on path .
reinstall bulkhead .
reinstall front panel , taking care to tuck wiring back into clips .
plug dryer back in and do a short test with a small load . dryer should run nice and quiet now !

Steps.Text_raw: Install drum back into dryer. Verify that it rolls smoothly on rollers. Install new belt into dryer. See photo for proper belt path through the idler pulley. Turn the drum a few times to verify belt will stay on path. Reinstall bulkhead. Reinstall front panel, taking care to tuck wiring back into clips. Plug dryer back in and do a short test with a small load. Dryer should run nice and quiet now!

Title: Estate Mo No TEDS840PQ0 Dryer Heating Element Replacement

Lines.Text: don't be an idiot . this is 240 volts ( twice a normal outlet ) unplug your dryer before you even think about starting .

Steps.Text_raw: Don't be an idiot. This is 240 volts (twice a normal outlet) Unplug your dryer before you even think about starting.

Lines.Text: disconnect your vent hose . this is pretty standard some have band clamps and some have squeeze clamps .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect your vent hose. This is pretty standard some have band clamps and some have squeeze clamps.

Lines.Text: pull the dryer back from the wall . most whirlpool made dryers have 9 ( 1 /4 ) screws holding the back cover on . don't forget to remove the cover plate for the cord . save the screws in a safe place . i used my drills bit holder it's exactly 1 /4 and worked perfectly .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the dryer back from the wall. Most Whirlpool made dryers have 9 (1/4") screws holding the back cover on. Don't forget to remove the cover plate for the cord. Save the screws in a safe place. I used my drills bit holder it's exactly 1/4" and worked perfectly.

Lines.Text: after removing all screws gently remove the rear cover and cord cover , place them against a wall . be careful the edges of these can be sharp !

Steps.Text_raw: After removing all screws gently remove the rear cover and cord cover, place them against a wall. Be careful the edges of these can be sharp!

Lines.Text: the dryer element is located in the bottom right corner of the case . make note of the connection locations , i recommend taking a picture with your phone .
remove the connectors to the element .
there are two more screws holding the element housing to the dryer , remove these and the element will come free by sliding down or pulling back .

Steps.Text_raw: The dryer element is located in the bottom right corner of the case. Make note of the connection locations, I recommend taking a picture with your phone. Remove the connectors to the element. There are two more screws holding the element housing to the dryer, remove these and the element will come free by sliding down or pulling back.

Lines.Text: set your multimeter to 20 k ohms .

connect the leads of the multimeter to your element , if your element is functional you will receive a 0.00 reading , if it is faulty the resistance will vary or your multimeter will show 1. you can also visually inspect the element coil . usually if the element has failed there will be a break somewhere in it .

Steps.Text_raw: Set your multimeter to 20K Ohms. Connect the leads of the multimeter to your element, if your element is functional you will receive a 0.00 reading, if it is faulty the resistance will vary or your multimeter will show 1.  You can also visually inspect the element coil. Usually if the element has failed there will be a break somewhere in it.

Lines.Text: if you've verified the old element has failed , set them up sideways next to each other as shown . you will see your new element is missing a piece . most new elements do not come with the high limit thermostat , this will need to be swapped over .
with your 6 mm socket remove the bolt holding the high limit thermostat and gently pry back the top tab . again gently pull the l shaped connector off the element terminal .

your new element may or may not come with a screw hole for the thermostat . if not pry the tab back and slide it into the hole in the element where the old screw hole was and slide the l connector back onto the new terminal .

Steps.Text_raw: If you've verified the old element has failed, set them up sideways next to each other as shown. You will see your new element is missing a piece. Most new elements do NOT come with the high limit thermostat, this will need to be swapped over. With your 6mm socket remove the bolt holding the high limit thermostat and *gently* pry back the top tab. Again *gently* pull the "L" shaped connector off the element terminal. Your new element may or may not come with a screw hole for the thermostat. If not pry the tab back and slide it into the hole in the element where the old screw hole was and slide the "L" connector back onto the new terminal.

Lines.Text: slide the new element housing back in place , reinstall the two screws holding it on and reconnect the terminals .
installation of the remaining components is reverse of removal . this is pretty straight forward .
re-install the cover , reconnect the vent hose , reconnect the plug and test .
that's it ! you did it ! test the dryer , open the door and hold the contact for the door , make sure the element is heating up ( you will see an orange glow ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the new element housing back in place, reinstall the two screws holding it on and reconnect the terminals. Installation of the remaining components is reverse of removal. This is pretty straight forward. Re-install the cover, reconnect the vent hose, reconnect the plug and test. That's it! You DID IT! Test the dryer, open the door and hold the contact for the door, make sure the element is heating up (you will see an orange glow).

Subject: Dryer Heating Element (most Whirlpool dryers)

Title: Oster 6329 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: using the phillips-head 2 screwdriver , unscrew the three 1cm phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips-head #2 screwdriver,  unscrew the three 1cm Phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Lines.Text: push the plastic push-down handle down and pull the plastic handle straight from metal arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the plastic push-down handle down and pull the plastic handle straight from metal arm.

Lines.Text: loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell .
only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell. Only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board.

Lines.Text: disconnect the cable clips from the circuit board using the tweezers to free the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the cable clips from the circuit board using the tweezers to free the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Lines.Text: lift the top outer metal shell .
carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the top outer metal shell. Carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster.

Lines.Text: using a flat-head screwdriver , pry the power cord from the base of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a flat-head screwdriver, pry the power cord from the base of the toaster.

Lines.Text: using a flat-head screwdriver , pry the white wire from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a flat-head screwdriver, pry the white wire from the base.

Lines.Text: locate the circuit board at the front of the toaster where the power cord and white wire meet .
pull the circuit board up and out to free the circuit board from the body of the toaster .
it is tightly fit and may take moderate force to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the circuit board at the front of the toaster where the power cord and white wire meet. Pull the circuit board up and out to free the circuit board from the body of the toaster. It is tightly fit  and may take moderate force to remove.

Lines.Text: desolder the power cord from the circuit board at the locations show in the diagram .
for soldering instructions see the guide .
the wires should be free from board when un-soldering is complete .

Steps.Text_raw: Desolder the power cord from the circuit board at the locations show in the diagram. For soldering instructions see the [guide|750|iFixit Soldering Guide]. The wires should be free from board when un-soldering is complete.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 1.5cm phillips-head screws at the back of the toaster that are holding the power cord in place to remove the retaining clip .
remove the plastic retaining clip that is holding the cord in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two 1.5cm Phillips-head screws at the back of the toaster that are holding the power cord in place to remove the retaining clip. Remove the plastic retaining clip that is holding the cord in place.

Lines.Text: untie the knot in the power cord .

Steps.Text_raw: Untie the knot in the power cord.

Lines.Text: pull the cord from the base to remove the cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the cord from the base to remove the cable.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: Keurig Mini B-31 Handle Replacement

Lines.Text: lift up the handle of the keurig mini .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the handle of the Keurig Mini.

Lines.Text: make sure to avoid the needles above and inside the k-cup because may puncture your hand

firmly place a finger on each one of the three tabs that hold the k-cup holder into place , pushing in lightly . the tabs are difficult to see , but they are there and will make the removal easier . the top tab is located in the same location as the white triangle and the bottom two are located under the plastic bumps highlighted in the picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure to avoid the needles above and inside the K-cup because may puncture your hand Firmly place a finger on each one of the three tabs that hold the K-cup holder into place, pushing in lightly. The tabs are difficult to see, but they are there and will make the removal easier.  The top tab is located in the same location as the white triangle and the bottom two are located under the plastic bumps highlighted in the picture.

Lines.Text: firmly rock the k-cup holder from side to side , loosening the k-cup holder from its seat .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly rock the K-cup holder from side to side, loosening the K-cup holder from its seat.

Lines.Text: pull the k-cup holder straight out .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the K-cup holder straight out.

Lines.Text: open the top lid of the keurig .
pull directly outwards on one of the arms that holds the top lid in place . it will take some force to get the arm off the peg . once one side is off , repeat the process on the second arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the top lid of the Keurig. Pull directly outwards on one of the arms that holds the top lid in place.  It will take some force to get the arm off the peg.  Once one side is off, repeat the process on the second arm.

Lines.Text: lay the keurig on its back with the water reservoir pointing away from you .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the Keurig on its back with the water reservoir pointing away from you.

Lines.Text: avoid the top needle as it may puncture your hand .
unscrew the two 9 mm 1 phillips screws that hold the top plastic cover in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Avoid the top needle as it may puncture your hand. Unscrew the two 9mm  #1 Philips screws that hold the top plastic cover in place.

Lines.Text: set the keurig in an upright position with the front side facing you .
pull the cover off the top of the keurig . it should come off easily with little force .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the Keurig in an upright position with the front side facing you. Pull the cover off the top of the Keurig. It should come off easily with little force.

Lines.Text: firmly grasp the hose and pull it off of the plastic nozzle .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grasp the hose and pull it off of the plastic nozzle.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 9 mm 1 phillips screws at the top of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two  9 mm #1 Philips screws at the top of the device.

Lines.Text: push down lightly on the nozzle that the hose was attached to . the plastic housing along with the needle should pop off without much force .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down lightly on the nozzle that the hose was attached to. The plastic housing along with the needle should pop off without much force.

Lines.Text: with the needle removed , open the device by pulling up on the handle .

Steps.Text_raw: With the needle removed, open the device by pulling up on the handle.

Lines.Text: push in on one of the arms attached to the k-cup holder plastic housing to remove it from its rails . the arms are identical for both sides so once one side is free repeat the process for the second side .
the plastic is flexible and will not snap with the force applied .
once the arms are removed , the configuration should look like the picture . the k-cup holder housing should be separated from the arms .

Steps.Text_raw: Push in on one of the arms attached to the K-cup holder plastic housing to remove it from its rails.  The arms are identical for both sides so once one side is free repeat the process for the second side. The plastic is flexible and will not snap with the force applied. Once the arms are removed, the configuration should look like the picture. The K-cup holder housing should be separated from the arms.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the four 12 mm screws that hold the arm assembly in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screw driver to remove the four 12 mm screws that hold the arm assembly in place.

Lines.Text: lift up the arm and pull up the handle assembly . it should easily come off .
this white tab falls off easily , remove it and set it aside to ensure it is not lost .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the arm and pull up the handle assembly. It should easily come off. This white tab falls off easily, remove it and set it aside to ensure it is not lost.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 9 mm 1 phillips screws from the handle assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two 9mm #1 Philips screws from the handle assembly.

Lines.Text: lay the handle assembly on its side . use one plastic prying tool to hold the snap ring in place so that it does not rotate and another to pop it off .
flip the assembly over and repeat the process on the other side .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the handle assembly on its side. Use one plastic prying tool to hold the snap ring in place so that it does not rotate and another to pop it off. Flip the assembly over and repeat the process on the other side.

Lines.Text: once the both snap rings are removed , pull on the plastic side plates to remove them . it shouldn't take much force to remove them .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the both snap rings are removed, pull on the plastic side plates to remove them.  It shouldn't take much force to remove them.

Lines.Text: with the side plates off , lay the handle assembly upside down with the handle facing you .
now push in the two bars that hold the handle in place .

Steps.Text_raw: With the side plates off, lay the handle assembly upside down with the handle facing you. Now push in the two bars that hold the handle in place.

Lines.Text: firmly pull on the handles to get them off of the bars . it should not take much force once the bars are pushed in .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly pull on the handles to get them off of the bars.  It should not take much force once the bars are pushed in.

Subject: Handle

Lines.Text: using the phillips-head 2 screwdriver , unscrew the three 1cm phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips-head #2 screwdriver,  unscrew the three 1cm Phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board .

carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

Title: Mr. Coffee TF6 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: facing the bottom of the tf6 , carefully pull the two rubber feet out with your hands .

Steps.Text_raw: Facing the bottom of the TF6, carefully pull the two rubber feet out with your hands.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the six 11 mm phillips screws that are holding the bottom cover in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the six 11mm Phillips screws that are holding the bottom cover in place.

Lines.Text: gently lift the bottom cover , detaching it from the main body of the tf6.

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the bottom cover, detaching it from the main body of the TF6.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the two 13 mm phillips screws that are securing the wire harness .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the two 13mm Phillips screws that are securing the wire harness.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the wire harness from the base of the tf6 , detaching it completely .
the power cord wiring is now completely accessible .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the wire harness from the base of the TF6, detaching it completely. The power cord wiring is now completely accessible.

Lines.Text: using a set of wire cutters , cut both leads of the power cord at the heatshrinked area where the leads split .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a set of wire cutters, cut both leads of the power cord at the heatshrinked area where the leads split.

Lines.Text: using your fingers , pry the heatshrink off from the power cord leads .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your fingers, pry the heatshrink off from the power cord leads.

Lines.Text: using a 14-16 awg wire stripper , strip the leads on the replacement power cord .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 14-16 AWG wire stripper, strip the leads on the replacement power cord.

Lines.Text: solder the power cord's positive lead to the white nylon wire .
solder the power cord's ground lead to the bronze nylon wire .

ensure the correct leads are being soldered together ( power to power , ground to ground ) . soldering the incorrect leads together will result in hazardous conditions for both the tf6 and the user when the unit is powered on .
consult the replacement power cord's user manual , packaging , or manufacturer in order to verify the power and ground leads .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder the power cord's positive lead to the white nylon wire. Solder the power cord's ground lead to the bronze nylon wire. Ensure the correct leads are being soldered together (power to power, ground to ground). Soldering the incorrect leads together will result in hazardous conditions for both the TF6 and the user when the unit is powered on. Consult the replacement power cord's user manual, packaging, or manufacturer in order to verify the power and ground leads.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: Mr. Coffee DW13 O Ring Replacement

Lines.Text: before performing this repair , be sure that your machine is unplugged and dry and that your work space is clean .
flip the mr . coffee dw13 over so that the lid is facing away from you and the base is facing toward you .

Steps.Text_raw: Before performing this repair, be sure that your machine is unplugged and dry and that your work space is clean. Flip the Mr. Coffee DW13 over so that the lid is facing away from you and the base is facing toward you.

Lines.Text: remove the eight 11 mm screws that secure the base of the machine with a phillips head 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight 11 mm screws that secure the base of the machine with a Phillips Head #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently lift the base cover to expose the inside of the coffee machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the base cover to expose the inside of the coffee machine.

Lines.Text: remove the two 13 mm screws securing the silver support bracket using a 2 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13mm screws securing the silver support bracket using a #2 Phillips head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently lift the silver support bracket freeing the heating plate from the heating coil .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the silver support bracket freeing the heating plate from the heating coil.

Lines.Text: use needle-nose pilers to pinch and loosen the crimps

Steps.Text_raw: Use needle-nose pilers to pinch and loosen the crimps

Lines.Text: once the crimps are loosened , slide them down the tubing .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the crimps are loosened, slide them down the tubing.

Lines.Text: separate the tubing from the heating coil by grasping the tubing in one hand and the heating coil in the other and gently pulling apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the tubing from the heating coil by grasping the tubing in one hand and the heating coil in the other and gently pulling apart.

Lines.Text: place one of your hands on the front side of the heating plate .
use this hand to gently push the heating plate towards yourself and out of the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Place one of your hands on the front side of the heating plate. Use this hand to gently push the heating plate towards yourself and out of the machine.

Lines.Text: use a 2.5 mm flathead screwdriver to pry out the o-ring .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a 2.5 mm Flathead Screwdriver to pry out the O-ring.

Subject: O Ring

Title: iRobot Roomba 551 Bumper Sensor Replacement

Lines.Text: place your roomba upside-down on a hard surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your Roomba upside-down on a hard surface.

Lines.Text: while holding the side brush in place , use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5 mm screw from the center of the brush .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the side brush in place, use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5mm screw from the center of the brush.

Lines.Text: gently pull upwards on the brush to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull upwards on the brush to remove it.

Lines.Text: rotate the roomba upside-down so the bottom is facing towards you .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the Roomba upside-down so the bottom is facing towards you.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the bottom plate .
the battery is only secured in place by the bottom plate , and may fall out once the bottom plate is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the bottom plate. The battery is only secured in place by the bottom plate, and may fall out once the bottom plate is removed.

Lines.Text: with a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the ten 12 mm screws located along the bottom of the bumper .

Steps.Text_raw: With a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the ten 12mm screws located along the bottom of the bumper.

Lines.Text: lift the bottom cover and set it to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the bottom cover and set it to the side.

Lines.Text: flip the roomba over , grasp the bumper , and gently lift to remove .
the battery is not secured in place once the bottom plate has been removed , and may fall out when the roomba is turned right-side up .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Roomba over, grasp the bumper, and gently lift to remove. The battery is not secured in place once the bottom plate has been removed, and may fall out when the Roomba is turned right-side up.

Lines.Text: flip the roomba so that the bottom is facing you .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Roomba so that the bottom is facing you.

Lines.Text: remove the two 5 mm screws located near the center of the bumper using a phillips 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 5mm screws located near the center of the bumper using a Phillips #1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: pull gently on the bottom of the sensor to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull gently on the bottom of the sensor to remove.

Lines.Text: flip the bumper over and lift the sensor from its compartment .
you are now free to replace the bumper sensor .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the bumper over and lift the sensor from its compartment. You are now free to replace the bumper sensor.

Lines.Text: pull up on the front of the faceplate until the friction locks pop out of place .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull up on the front of the faceplate until the friction locks pop out of place.

Lines.Text: continue around the outside of the roomba , pulling up on the faceplate to free all of the outer friction locks .

Steps.Text_raw: Continue around the outside of the Roomba, pulling up on the faceplate to free all of the outer friction locks.

Lines.Text: grab the faceplate by the outer edge and pull upwards , freeing the center friction locks in the process .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the faceplate by the outer edge and pull upwards, freeing the center friction locks in the process.

Subject: Faceplate

Title: Oster 6329 Circuit Board Resistor Replacement

Lines.Text: using the phillips-head 2 screwdriver , unscrew the three 1cm phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips-head #2 screwdriver,  unscrew the three 1cm Phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Lines.Text: push the plastic push-down handle down and pull the plastic handle straight from metal arm .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the plastic push-down handle down and pull the plastic handle straight from metal arm.

Lines.Text: loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell .
only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell. Only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board.

Lines.Text: disconnect the cable clips from the circuit board using the tweezers to free the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the cable clips from the circuit board using the tweezers to free the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Lines.Text: lift the top outer metal shell .
carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the top outer metal shell. Carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster.

Lines.Text: using a 1 phillips head screwdriver , remove the four 1cm phillips head screws holding the circuit board to the inside of the toaster shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a #1 phillips head screwdriver, remove the four 1cm philips head screws holding the circuit board to the inside of the toaster shell.

Lines.Text: grasp the circuit board and pull on it perpendicular to the attached surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasp the circuit board and pull on it perpendicular to the attached surface.

Lines.Text: inspect the circuit board for any burnt or otherwise damaged components . be sure to carefully identify the damaged components that need replacement . for help identifying resistor values look at electronic color code article .

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the circuit board for any burnt or otherwise damaged components. Be sure to carefully identify the damaged components that need replacement. For help identifying resistor values look at [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_color_code|wikipedia's electronic color code article].

Lines.Text: use the soldering kit to unsolder the damaged component . for soldering instructions look at the guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the soldering kit to unsolder the damaged component. For soldering Instructions look at the [guide|750|iFixit Soldering Guide].

Lines.Text: once the damaged component has been unsoldered from the circuit board , remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the damaged component has been unsoldered from the circuit board, remove it.

Subject: Circuit Board Resistor

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips-head #2 screwdriver,  unscrew the three 1cm Phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Steps.Text_raw: Push the plastic push-down handle down and pull the plastic handle straight from metal arm.

Lines.Text: loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell .
only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell. Only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board.

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the cable clips from the circuit board using the tweezers to free the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the top outer metal shell. Carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster.

Lines.Text: use a flat-head screwdriver to separate the metal flap from the metal plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat-head screwdriver to separate the metal flap from the metal plate.

Lines.Text: grasp the metal flap with the large needle nose pliers .
unbend metal flap until at a 90 degree angle from the metal plate .
repeat these steps for the second metal flap .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasp the metal flap with the large needle nose pliers. Unbend metal flap until at a 90 degree angle from the metal plate. Repeat these steps for the second metal flap.

Lines.Text: use the large need nose pliers to grab the metal panel .
pull the metal panel away from the body of the toaster to dislodge the flaps .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the large need nose pliers to grab the  metal panel. Pull the metal panel away from the body of the toaster to dislodge the flaps.

Lines.Text: push the metal flaps towards the body of the toaster to access the bread lift shelf .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the metal flaps towards the body of the toaster to access the bread lift shelf.

Lines.Text: push down on the opposite side of the bread lift shelf to expose the metal flaps .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the opposite side of the bread lift shelf to expose the metal flaps.

Lines.Text: pull up on the bread lift shelf to remove from the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull up on the bread lift shelf to remove from the toaster.

Title: iRobot Roomba 551 Side Brush Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: place your roomba upside-down on a hard surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your Roomba upside-down on a hard surface.

Lines.Text: while holding the side brush in place , use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5 mm screw from the center of the brush .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the side brush in place, use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5mm screw from the center of the brush.

Lines.Text: gently pull upwards on the brush to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull upwards on the brush to remove it.

Lines.Text: rotate the roomba upside-down so the bottom is facing towards you .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the Roomba upside-down so the bottom is facing towards you.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the bottom plate .
the battery is only secured in place by the bottom plate , and may fall out once the bottom plate is removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the bottom plate. The battery is only secured in place by the bottom plate, and may fall out once the bottom plate is removed.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the two captive mounting screws on the side wheel motor assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the two captive mounting screws on the side wheel motor assembly.

Lines.Text: gently pull on motor assembly to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull on motor assembly to remove.

carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

repeat this step for the opposite side .

Title: Oster 6329 Lever Catch Spring Replacement

Lines.Text: using the phillips-head 2 screwdriver , unscrew the three 1cm phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips-head #2 screwdriver,  unscrew the three 1cm Phillips-head screws on the plastic base of the toaster to separate the outer metal shell from the plastic base.

Lines.Text: loosen the outer metal shell from the plastic base by holding the plastic base while pulling up on the metal shell .
only lift the outer shell a little so as not to disconnect the cables that connect the circuit board .

carefully lift the outer metal shell at an angle so as not to damage the components in the front of the toaster .

Lines.Text: insert the tweezers between the spring and the bottom of the lever to release the spring .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the tweezers between the spring and the bottom of the lever to release the spring.

Lines.Text: remove spring from the bottom of the lever .
the spring should only be connected to the top of the toaster after this is complete .

hold the spring and turn it sideways to lay it flat along the top of the toaster .
pry the spring from the top of the toaster .

Title: Professional Series PS77401 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: make sure that the toaster is unplugged before attempting any sort of disassembly !

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure that the toaster is unplugged before attempting any sort of disassembly!

Lines.Text: grip the black plastic lever nub firmly and ''carefully'' remove it from the metal lever . use one hand to hold the toaster in place while you pull the lever nub with the other .
if this is the first time detaching this piece , it will take some effort to remove . be careful as pulling too hard can cause damage to the inner lever mechanism .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the black plastic lever nub firmly and ''carefully'' remove it from the metal lever. Use one hand to hold the toaster in place while you pull the lever nub with the other. If this is the first time detaching this piece, it will take some effort to remove. Be careful as pulling too hard can cause damage to the inner lever mechanism.

Lines.Text: flipping the toaster upside down , use a t7 torx screwdriver to remove the four 10 mm screws that keep the outer shell attached .
flip the toaster back over and slide off the shell making sure to slip the toaster lever ( now without the black plastic nub ) through the lever opening in the shell .
the outer shell should now only be connected by its internal wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Flipping the toaster upside down, use a T7 Torx Screwdriver to remove the four 10mm screws that keep the outer shell attached. Flip the toaster back over and slide off the shell making sure to slip the toaster lever (now without the black plastic nub) through the lever opening in the shell. The outer shell should now only be connected by its internal wiring.

Lines.Text: locate and remove the two 8 mm screws that attach the circuit board ( located inside of the shell ) from the shell itself using the phillips 2 screwdriver .
the shell should now be completely separated from the rest of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the two 8mm screws that attach the circuit board (located inside of the shell) from the shell itself using the Phillips #2 screwdriver. The shell should now be completely separated from the rest of the toaster.

Lines.Text: remove the small circuit board by pulling on the two side tabs while simultaneously releasing the middle clip .
slide the small circuit board out of it's clips .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the small circuit board by pulling on the two side tabs while simultaneously releasing the middle clip. Slide the small circuit board out of it's clips.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the front two 8 mm screws attaching the chassis to the base .
flip the toaster around and proceed to remove the two remaining 8 mm screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Philips #2 screwdriver, remove the front two 8mm screws attaching the chassis to the base. Flip the toaster around and proceed to remove the two remaining 8mm screws.

Lines.Text: upon removing the chassis , look in the toaster base to find the little white tab holding the power cord in place . use a phillips screwdriver to remove the two 10 mm screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Upon removing the chassis, look in the toaster base to find the little white tab holding the power cord in place. Use a Philips screwdriver to remove the two 10mm screws.

Lines.Text: de-solder the two power cord wires that are connected to the small circuit board .
solder on replacement power cord .
if you're unsure of how to solder here is a helpful guide : topic : solderingsoldering guide

Steps.Text_raw: De-solder the two power cord wires that are connected to the small circuit board. Solder on replacement power cord. If you're unsure of how to solder here is a helpful guide:  [[Topic:Soldering|Soldering Guide]]

Subject: Power Cord

Lines.Text: locate the small circuit board attached to the base of the toaster .
to remove the circuit board , pull apart the two side tabs while releasing the middle tab simultaneously .
pull the circuit board out of the slot .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the small circuit board attached to the base of the toaster. To remove the circuit board, pull apart the two side tabs while releasing the middle tab simultaneously. Pull the circuit board out of the slot.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the front two 8 mm screws attaching the chassis to the base .
flip the toaster around and proceed to remove the two remaining 8 mm screws .
the toaster chassis should now only be connected to the base via wiring .

remove these screws to release the power cable .

Lines.Text: the following wires must be disconnected to be able to remove the chassis : blue x2 , white x2 , bronze x1
disconnecting the cables in the middle is recommended to be able to reconnect new wires from a new chassis easily .

Title: Mr. Coffee DW13 Heating Plate Replacement

Lines.Text: before performing this repair , be sure that your machine is unplugged and dry and that your work space is clean .
flip the mr . coffee dw13 over so that the lid is facing away from you and the base is facing toward you .

Steps.Text_raw: Before performing this repair, be sure that your machine is unplugged and dry and that your work space is clean. Flip the Mr. Coffee DW13 over so that the lid is facing away from you and the base is facing toward you.

Lines.Text: remove the eight 11 mm screws that secure the base of the machine with a phillips head 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the eight 11 mm screws that secure the base of the machine with a Phillips Head #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: gently lift the base cover to expose the inside of the coffee machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the base cover to expose the inside of the coffee machine.

Lines.Text: using the phillips head 2 screwdriver , remove the two 13 mm screws that secure the silver support bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the Phillips Head #2 screwdriver, remove the two 13 mm screws that secure the silver support bracket.

Lines.Text: gently lift the silver support bracket to free the heating plate from the heating coil .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift the silver support bracket to free the heating plate from the heating coil.

Lines.Text: pinch and loosen the crimps with the needle-nose pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: Pinch and loosen the crimps with the needle-nose pliers.

Lines.Text: once the crimps are loosened , slide them down the tubing .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the crimps are loosened, slide them down the tubing.

Lines.Text: separate the tubing from the heating coil by grasping the tubing in one hand and the heating coil in the other . gently pull them apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the tubing from the heating coil by grasping the tubing in one hand and the heating coil in the other. Gently pull them apart.

Lines.Text: place your hand on the front side of the heating plate and push towards the bottom of the coffee maker to pop the heating plate out of place .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your hand on the front side of the heating plate and push towards the bottom of the coffee maker to pop the heating plate out of place.

flip the toaster back over and slide off the shell making sure to slip the toaster lever ( now without the black plastic nub ) through the lever opening in the shell .
the outer shell should now only be connected by its internal wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Flipping the toaster upside down, use a T7 Torx Screwdriver to remove the four 10mm screws that keep the outer shell attached. Flip the toaster back over and slide off the shell making sure to slip the toaster lever (now without the black plastic nub) through the lever opening in the shell. The outer shell should now only be connected by its internal wiring.

Lines.Text: locate and remove the two 8 mm screws that attach the circuit board ( located inside of the shell ) from the shell itself using the phillips 2 screwdriver .
the shell should now be completely separated from the rest of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the two 8mm screws that attach the circuit board (located inside of the shell) from the shell itself using the Phillips #2 screwdriver. The shell should now be completely separated from the rest of the toaster.

Lines.Text: locate the metal knob protruding from the removed circuit board .
remove the 10 mm nut with an equally sized wrench and replace the now removable solenoid .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the metal knob protruding from the removed circuit board. Remove the 10mm nut with an equally sized wrench and replace the now removable solenoid.

Subject: Toaster Solenoid

Title: iRobot Roomba 551 Brush Case Replacement

Lines.Text: place your roomba upside-down on a hard surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Place your Roomba upside-down on a hard surface.

Lines.Text: while holding the side brush in place , use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5 mm screw from the center of the brush .

Steps.Text_raw: While holding the side brush in place, use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the 4.5mm screw from the center of the brush.

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull upwards on the brush to remove it.

Lines.Text: rotate the roomba upside-down so the bottom is facing towards you .

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the captive screws that hold the bottom plate in place.

the battery is only secured in place by the bottom plate , and may fall out once the bottom plate is removed .

Title: ChefsChoice M677 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: there are two different kinds of screws on the base plate . three 3 /8 standard phillips screws one 3 /8 non-standard triangular phillips screw . this image shows the difference between the two screws .

Steps.Text_raw: There are two DIFFERENT kinds of screws on the base plate. • Three 3/8" standard Phillips screws  • One 3/8" non-standard triangular Phillips screw. This image shows the difference between the two screws.

Lines.Text: remove the krubber pad then remove the three 3 /8 phillips screws from the baseplate using a 1 phillips screwdriver .
remove the non-standard phillips screw .
attempting to remove with a standard phillips screwdriver will damage the screw head and potentially prevent its removal .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the "K"rubber pad then remove the three 3/8" Phillips screws from the baseplate using a #1 Phillips screwdriver. Remove the  non-standard Phillips screw. Attempting to remove with a standard Phillips screwdriver will damage the screw head and potentially prevent its removal.

Lines.Text: be cautious that the cord is completely unwound from the base plate .
lift the base plate away from the unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Be cautious that the cord is completely unwound from the base plate. Lift the base plate away from the unit.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the red square protector off the post holding it in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the red square protector off the post holding it in place.

Lines.Text: first image : remove the two 3 /8 phillips screws using a 1 phillips screwdriver .
remove the clamp which holds the cord in place .

Steps.Text_raw: FIRST IMAGE: Remove the two 3/8" Phillips screws using a #1 Phillips screwdriver. Remove the clamp which holds the cord in place.

Lines.Text: use your hands to pull the black cylinder out from the center of the baseplate . this is the power coupling .
take note of the arrangement of the wires on the coupling device to aid in reassembly . if desired , mark the wires and connectors with different colored tapes .
the green wire is the 'ground' or 'protection' wire . it is connected to the center post .
the other two wires are both black . you can distinguish them by feel :
the smooth wire is the 'neutral' wire .
the ribbed wire is the 'hot' wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Use your hands to pull the black cylinder out from the center of the baseplate. This is the power coupling. Take note of the arrangement of the wires on the coupling device to aid in reassembly. If desired, mark the wires and connectors with different colored tapes. The GREEN wire is the 'ground' or 'protection' wire. It is connected to the center post. The other two wires are both BLACK. You can distinguish them by feel: The smooth wire is the 'neutral' wire. The ribbed wire is the 'hot' wire.

Lines.Text: remove the connectors ( spaded lugs ) from the kettle's power coupling by gently pulling on each wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the connectors (spaded lugs) from the kettle's power coupling by gently pulling on each wire.

Lines.Text: ''this photo indicates damage to the ground wire's insulation . this is an example of the sort of damage that could require replacement of the power cord . ''

Steps.Text_raw: ''This photo indicates damage to the ground wire's insulation. This is an example of the sort of damage that could require replacement of the power cord.''

Lines.Text: you will need three 16-22 gauge connectors ( spaded lugs ) . the 'gauge' number refers to the wire size the lug connector is designed to fit . these connectors will slip over the contacts on the power coupling .

Steps.Text_raw: You will need three 16-22 gauge connectors (spaded lugs). The 'gauge' number refers to the wire size the lug connector is designed to fit. These connectors will slip over the contacts on the power coupling.

Lines.Text: on the replacement cord , remove the white , green , and black protective caps . by hand , affix one connector to each cord wire . follows these steps for each wire :
twist the copper strands on the wire so you can cleanly insert the wire into the connector .
push the copper wiring into the connector until the insulation prevents further insertion .

Steps.Text_raw: On the replacement cord, remove the white, green, and black protective caps. By hand, affix one connector to each cord wire. Follows these steps for each wire: Twist the copper strands on the wire so you can cleanly insert the wire into the connector. Push the copper wiring into the connector until the insulation prevents further insertion.

Lines.Text: using the multi-tool in crimper mode ( or a special crimping tool ) , apply pressure on the connector 'shank' where the wire was inserted .

the ridge that you achieve by crimping should look the same as the connector shown here on the green wire . give the connector a gentle pull to confirm it is well connected to the wire ( it should not slip off ) .
repeat steps 10 and 11 for the remaining two wires requiring connectors .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the multi-tool in crimper mode (or a special crimping tool), apply pressure on the connector 'shank' where the wire was inserted. The ridge that you achieve by crimping should look the same as the connector shown here on the green wire. Give the connector a gentle pull to confirm it is well connected to the wire (it should not slip off). Repeat steps 10 and 11 for the remaining two wires requiring connectors.

Lines.Text: thread the replacement cord through the opening closest to the cord symbol on the bottom of the baseplate .
insert the cord until the green , white , and black wires are pushed all the way through .

Steps.Text_raw: Thread the replacement cord through the opening closest to the cord symbol on the bottom of the baseplate. Insert the cord until the green, white, and black wires are pushed all the way through.

Lines.Text: reinsert the power coupling ( the black cylinder ) through the baseplate .
slide the connectors into the exposed metal prongs protruding from the power coupling . this may require a little force because the connection is a tight fit .
reattach the black plastic oval piece in order to secure and stabilize the cord wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Reinsert the power coupling (the black cylinder) through the baseplate. Slide the connectors into the exposed metal prongs protruding from the power coupling. This may require a little force because the connection is a tight fit. Reattach the black plastic oval piece in order to secure and stabilize the cord wires.

Lines.Text: replace the red square protector on top of the wiring system .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the red square protector on top of the wiring system.

Lines.Text: align the two parts of the baseplate as shown in these two photos .
push or pull on the cord as needed to ensure a stable fit before inserting the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Align the two parts of the baseplate as shown in these two photos. Push or pull on the cord as needed to ensure a stable fit before inserting the screws.

Lines.Text: align the holes on the two halves of the baseplate precisely .
using a 1 phillips head screwdriver , tighten the three 3 /8 phillips head screws in the holes located along the outer edge of the base plate .
using a 1 triangular head screwdriver , tighten the 3 /8 triangular phillips screw at the center of the base plate

Steps.Text_raw: Align the holes on the two halves of the baseplate precisely. Using a #1 Phillips head screwdriver, tighten the three 3/8" Philips head screws in the holes located along the outer edge of the base plate. Using a #1 TRIANGULAR head screwdriver, tighten the 3/8" TRIANGULAR Phillips screw at the center of the base plate

Lines.Text: your baseplate with the new cord attached should look similar to the one shown in the photo .

Steps.Text_raw: Your baseplate with the new cord attached should look similar to the one shown in the photo.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: Brother XR-40 Lightbulb Replacement

Lines.Text: place the machine on a solid surface .
remove the 14 mm phillips 2 screw holding on the face cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the machine on a solid surface. Remove the 14mm Phillips #2 screw holding on the face cover.

Lines.Text: remove the two 14 mm phillips 2 screws and two 22 mm phillips 2 screws that secure the rear casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 14mm Phillips #2 screws and two 22mm Phillips #2 screws that secure the rear casing.

Lines.Text: lay the machine on its side .
remove the four 10 mm phillips 2 screws that hold the bottom panel in place .
the feet will come off with the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the machine on its side. Remove the four 10mm Phillips #2 screws that hold the bottom panel in place. The feet will come off with the screws.

Lines.Text: remove the bottom panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bottom panel.

Lines.Text: place the machine upright .
remove the rear casing .
you may have to wiggle the panel and pull at the same time .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the machine upright. Remove the rear casing. You may have to wiggle the panel and pull at the same time.

Lines.Text: using scissors , clip the two zip ties securing the lightbulb wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Using scissors, clip the two zip ties securing the lightbulb wire.

Lines.Text: place the machine on its side , with access to the bottom .
gently pull out the white wire connecting the bulb to the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the machine on its side, with access to the bottom. Gently pull out the white wire connecting the bulb to the machine.

Lines.Text: move the wire out from under the plastic hook .

Steps.Text_raw: Move the wire out from under the plastic hook.

Lines.Text: place the machine upright .
using the flathead screwdriver , remove the 5 mm flathead screw holding on the lightbulb bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the machine upright. Using the flathead screwdriver, remove the 5mm Flathead screw holding on the lightbulb bracket.

Lines.Text: remove the lightbulb assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the lightbulb assembly.

Subject: Lightbulb

Title: ChefsChoice M677 Power Supply Replacement

Lines.Text: first image :
the red circles identify the five ( 5 ) phillips screws .
the green square identifies the on/off switch .
second image : remove the five ( 5 ) 3 /8 phillips screws from the base of the kettle using a 1 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: FIRST IMAGE: The red circles identify the five (5) Phillips screws. The green square identifies the ON/OFF Switch. SECOND IMAGE: Remove the five (5) 3/8" Phillips screws from the base of the kettle using a #1 Phillips head screwdriver.

Lines.Text: using your hands , pry the base off the kettle . open it like a clamshell : the on/off switch will be the hinge point .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your hands, pry the base off the kettle. Open it like a clamshell: the ON/OFF switch will be the hinge point.

Lines.Text: using your hands , remove the kettle base by sliding it over the switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your hands, remove the kettle base by sliding it over the switch.

Lines.Text: now that you have removed the bottom from the kettle , identify all of the parts . the yellow arrows point to the posts for mounting the control circuit components . the red arrows point to the following parts :
a : the power supply .
b : the two boil-dry protection switches , one on either side of the central black ring .
c : the power coupling . this fits into the baseplate when you place the kettle on it .
d : the thermostat . this is a little metal ring , half hidden by the switch cover .
e : the manual on/off switch .
f : the indicator light .
g : the steam chamber . this heats the thermostat , which turns off the kettle automatically .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that you have removed the bottom from the kettle, identify all of the parts. The YELLOW arrows point to the posts for mounting the control circuit components. The RED arrows point to the following parts: A: The power supply. B: The two boil-dry protection switches, one on either side of the central black ring. C: The power coupling. This fits into the baseplate when you place the kettle on it. D: The thermostat. This is a little metal ring, half hidden by the switch cover. E: The manual ON/OFF switch. F: The indicator light. G: The steam chamber. This heats the thermostat, which turns off the kettle automatically.

Lines.Text: take note of how the wires connect to the components to aid reassembly .
remove the connectors ( spaded lugs ) from the circuit components as shown in the second image .
''do not pull on the wires , as you might pull them out of the connectors . ''
you should be able to remove each connector easily by hand . pinch the lug between your fingers and pull in the direction of the attached wire .
if necessary , use needle-nose pliers to grasp the lug shank firmly . gently pull the lug in the direction of the attached wire .
gently bend the disconnected wires back and out of the work area .

Steps.Text_raw: Take note of how the wires connect to the components to aid reassembly. Remove the connectors (spaded lugs) from the circuit components as shown in the second image. ''DO NOT pull on the wires, as you might pull them out of the connectors.'' You should be able to remove each connector easily by hand. Pinch the lug between your fingers and pull in the direction of the attached wire. If necessary, use needle-nose pliers to grasp the lug shank firmly. Gently pull the lug in the direction of the attached wire. Gently bend the disconnected wires back and out of the work area.

Lines.Text: using a 7 /32 nut driver , remove the hex nut that secures the power supply to the base of the kettle .
using a pair of tweezers , remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut . ( it may be hard to see in low light . )

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 7/32" nut driver, remove the hex nut that secures the power supply to the base of the kettle. Using a pair of tweezers, remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut. (It may be hard to see in low light.)

Lines.Text: using your hands , grasp the wire that is still connected to the power supply . carefully lift the power supply off the threaded stud to which it was coupled .
at this point you will have removed the following parts from the kettle :
five ( 5 ) screws .
the kettle base .
one ( 1 ) 7 /32 '' hex nut .
one ( 1 ) 7 /32 split-ring lock washer .
one ( 1 ) power supply unit .

Steps.Text_raw: Using your hands, grasp the wire that is still connected to the power supply. Carefully lift the power supply off the threaded stud to which it was coupled. At this point you will have removed the following parts from the kettle: Five (5) screws. The kettle base. One (1) 7/32'' hex nut. One (1) 7/32" split-ring lock washer. One (1) power supply unit.

Subject: Power Supply

Lines.Text: first image : remove the power supply . align the kettle as shown , with the handle to your right . use the 7 /32 nut driver to remove the 7 /32 nut from the stud that is located clockwise from where the power supply was attached .
use tweezers to remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut .

second image : roll the kettle over so the handle is now on your left . use the 7 /32 nut driver to remove the 7 /32 nut from the final stud , which is now located counter-clockwise from where the power supply was attached .
use tweezers to remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut .

Steps.Text_raw: FIRST IMAGE: Remove the power supply. Align the kettle as shown, with the handle to your right. Use the 7/32" nut driver to remove the 7/32" nut from the stud that is located clockwise from where the power supply was attached. Use tweezers to remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut. SECOND IMAGE: Roll the kettle over so the handle is now on your left. Use the 7/32" nut driver to remove the 7/32" nut from the final stud, which is now located counter-clockwise from where the power supply was attached. Use tweezers to remove the split-ring lock washer located under the nut.

Lines.Text: grasp the control switch with one hand and the kettle with the other .
gently rock the control switch while simultaneously pulling it away from the bottom of the kettle .
pull the switch completely off the kettle .

Steps.Text_raw: Grasp the control switch with one hand and the kettle with the other. Gently rock the control switch while simultaneously pulling it away from the bottom of the kettle. Pull the switch completely off the kettle.

Lines.Text: this image shows the alignment of various kettle parts .
the yellow arrows show how the studs align with the switch brackets .
the blue arrow shows how the steam tube aligns with the steam chamber on the switch thermostat .

Title: Oster 16-Speed Blender Fan and Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the blender container from the blender base .

Lines.Text: flip the blender so the bottom is facing you .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the blender so the bottom is facing you.

Lines.Text: unscrew the 16 mm screws located on the plastic bottom from the blender base using a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the 16mm screws located on the plastic bottom from the blender base using a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove the plastic bottom from the base of the blender .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic bottom from the base of the blender.

Lines.Text: holding the center of the fan , grip the knob in the center of the top of the blender with a wrench and twist the wrench counterclockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Holding the center of the fan, grip the knob in the center of the top of the blender with a wrench and twist the wrench counterclockwise.
