pull the end of the bolt out to completely remove it .
repeat for the second bolt .

Steps.Text_raw: Using any long, thin object, push the 43mm  bolt from the inside towards the outside to expose the end of the bolt. Pull the end of the bolt out to completely remove it. Repeat for the second bolt.

Lines.Text: using the 4.0 mm allen wrench , unscrew the two 26 mm bolts connecting the handle to the upper heating element housing on both sides .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the 4.0mm Allen Wrench, unscrew the two 26mm bolts connecting the handle to the upper heating element housing on both sides.

Lines.Text: unscrew the locking knob all the way to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the locking knob all the way to remove it.

Lines.Text: slide the locking knob couple down to the base of the handle , then pull up on the free end of the handle . it will easily pop off .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the locking knob couple down to the base of the handle, then pull up on the free end of the handle. It will easily pop off.

Lines.Text: gently separate the heating element housing from the cooking surface by pulling up on the housing and pushing down on the surface .
pulling too far or too hard can break the delicate internal wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently separate the heating element housing from the cooking surface by pulling up on the housing and pushing down on the surface. Pulling too far or too hard can break the delicate internal wiring.

Lines.Text: on the underside of the housing , use the ph2 screwdriver to remove the single 12 mm screw to disconnect the led tray .
the housing can now be completely removed .
place on the side for reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: On the underside of the housing, use the PH2 Screwdriver to remove the single 12mm screw to disconnect the LED tray. The housing can now be completely removed. Place on the side for reassembly.

Lines.Text: using the ph2 screwdriver , remove the single 10 mm screw on the circular plastic led tray .
now remove the small plastic t-shaped piece and the plastic tray completely

Steps.Text_raw: Using the PH2 screwdriver, remove the single 10mm screw on the circular plastic LED tray. Now remove the small plastic T-shaped piece and the plastic tray completely

Lines.Text: gently pull off the translucent bulb covers

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pull off the translucent bulb covers

Lines.Text: very gently , slide the white wiring covers down to expose the wiring connectors

Steps.Text_raw: Very gently, slide the white wiring covers down to expose the wiring connectors

Lines.Text: refer to this topic : solderingpage to brush up on your soldering skills .
the led can now be removed by desoldering the connector at each wiring junction .
the red led connects to the red wire ( positive ) and the blue wire ( negative , marked in yellow . )
the green led connects to the white wire ( positive ) and the blue wire ( negative , marked in yellow . )

Steps.Text_raw: Refer to this [[Topic:Soldering|page]] to brush up on your soldering skills. The LED can now be removed by desoldering the connector at each wiring junction. The red LED connects to the red wire (positive) and the blue wire (negative, marked in yellow.) The green LED connects to the white wire (Positive) and the blue wire (negative, marked in yellow.)

Subject: LED

Title: Hamilton Beach 25460Z Plug Wiring Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug your device before proceeding with disassembly .
remove the four 14 mm screws from the bottom of the panini press using the t10 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your device before proceeding with disassembly. Remove the four 14mm screws from the bottom of the Panini Press using the T10 Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift up the plastic cover to expose the plug wiring .
mark the plug wire connected to the red wire with a piece of tape . this will be used as a reference for reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the plastic cover to expose the plug wiring. Mark the plug wire connected to the red wire with a piece of tape. This will be used as a reference for reassembly.

Lines.Text: use the pliers to pinch the widest point of the cap . this should be done opposite of the already existing crimps .
slide off the white cap .
repeat these steps for the second white cap .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the pliers to pinch the widest point of the cap. This should be done opposite of the already existing crimps. Slide off the white cap. Repeat these steps for the second white cap.

Lines.Text: remove the two rubber screw covers from the bottom of the panini press .
remove the four uncovered 10 mm screws with the ph2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two rubber screw covers from the bottom of the Panini Press. Remove the four uncovered 10mm screws with the PH2 Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift the plastic lower heating element up and place to the side for reassembly . you have now disconnected the plug wiring completely .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the plastic lower heating element up and place to the side for reassembly. You have now disconnected the plug wiring completely.

mark the plug wire connected to the red wire with a piece of tape . this will be used as a reference for reassembly .

slide off the white cap .
repeat these steps for the second white cap .

remove the four uncovered 10 mm screws with the ph2 screwdriver .

Lines.Text: de-solder the connection between the wires and the thermal switch .

Title: Nostalgia Electrics PCM805 Heating Element

Lines.Text: make sure that the device is unplugged and has not been used recently because the extractor head and bowl can be very hot .
place the device on a steady table .
lift and remove the rim .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure that the device is unplugged and has not been used recently because the extractor head and bowl can be very hot. Place the device on a steady table. Lift and remove the rim.

Lines.Text: twist the bowl clockwise until it is free of the groove and lift to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the bowl clockwise until it is free of the groove and lift to remove.

Lines.Text: firmly grip the extractor head and slowly lift vertically to remove from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip the extractor head and slowly lift vertically to remove from the device.

Lines.Text: unplug the device before following this guide .
first , place the device on its side , making sure the switch is not facing down .
remove the eight 12 mm phillips 02 screws from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the device before following this guide. First, place the device on its side, making sure the switch is not facing down. Remove the eight 12mm Phillips #02 screws from the base.

Lines.Text: gently separate the panel from the device .
be sure not to tug at the wires that are still connected .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently separate the panel from the device. Be sure not to tug at the wires that are still connected.

Lines.Text: locate the tie strap holding the wires and cut with a pair of scissors .
use care not to snip the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the tie strap holding the wires and cut with a pair of scissors. Use care not to snip the wires.

Lines.Text: make note of the wiring arrangement of each bundle before this step .
using wire cutters , cut each wire as close to the wire connector as possible .
cut the wires in both bundles .
to reassemble the cotton candy maker after cutting the wires , follow our guide .

Steps.Text_raw: Make note of the wiring arrangement of each bundle before this step. Using wire cutters, cut each wire as close to the wire connector as possible. Cut the wires in both bundles. To reassemble the cotton candy maker after cutting the wires, follow our [guide|38263|rewiring guide].

Lines.Text: remove the six 10 mm phillips 02 screws that secure the metal housing covering the heating element .
remove the metal housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six 10mm Phillips #02 screws that secure the metal housing covering the heating element. Remove the metal housing.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9 mm phillips 02 screws that secure the heating element to the rest of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9mm Phillips #02 screws that secure the heating element to the rest of the device.

Lines.Text: line up the prongs on the motor shaft with the slots in either side of the hole in the heating element and lift it off the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Line up the prongs on the motor shaft with the slots in either side of the hole in the heating element and lift it off the device.

Title: Kenmore 400 Washer clutch band Replacement

Lines.Text: kenmore 400 washer that has difficulty spinning . it runs through the cycle but does not spin properly .
open the lid
remove cap from the agitator by using a flat tip screwdriver or similar .

Steps.Text_raw: Kenmore 400 washer that has difficulty spinning. It runs through the cycle but does not spin properly. Open the lid Remove cap from the agitator by using a flat tip screwdriver or similar.

Lines.Text: with the cap removed , a 7 /16 hex bolt becomes visible .
use a socket wrench with 4 inch extension to remove the bolt .
the agitator bolt measures 5 /16 x 1 inches , 24 thread size

Steps.Text_raw: With the cap removed, a 7/16 hex bolt becomes visible. Use a socket wrench with 4 inch extension to remove the bolt. The agitator bolt measures 5/16 X 1 inches, 24 thread size

Lines.Text: with the bolt removed , pull the agitator of the shaft .
view of the drum with agitator removed
for ease of working on the bottom parts , lay the washer on its side .

Steps.Text_raw: With the bolt removed, pull the agitator of the shaft. View of the drum with agitator removed For ease of working on the bottom parts, lay the washer on its side.

Lines.Text: main parts of the assembly include
drain pump
motor
transmission
this is a direct drive model . no belts but a motor coupler connects the motor to transmission . check for any cracks etc .
remove the wiring harness from the motor

Steps.Text_raw: Main parts of the assembly include Drain pump Motor Transmission This is a direct drive model. No belts but a motor coupler connects the motor to transmission. Check for any cracks etc. Remove the wiring harness from the motor

Lines.Text: remove the wiring harness from the clip on the transmission
drain lines from the drum and drain hose are connected to the pump with spring clamps .
using a pair of pliers and squeezinge the opposite ends of the clamps together will loosen the clamp .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the wiring harness from the clip on the transmission Drain lines from the drum and drain hose are connected to the pump with spring clamps. Using a pair of pliers and squeezinge the opposite ends of the clamps together will loosen the clamp.

Lines.Text: pull the drain hose of the pump
remove the tub-to-pump hose the same way
remove the three 1 /2 inch bolts .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the drain hose of the pump Remove the tub-to-pump hose  the same way Remove the three 1/2inch bolts.

Lines.Text: here are the three bolts . they are 5 /16 by 11 /16 with a 1 /2 inch hex head .
with the three bolts removed , pull the complete assembly out of the drum
with the assembly removed , the clutch is now completely visible .

Steps.Text_raw: Here are the three bolts. They are 5/16 by 11/16 with a 1/2 inch hex head. With the three bolts removed, pull the complete assembly out of the drum With the assembly removed, the clutch is now completely visible.

Lines.Text: it is not necessary to replace the whole clutch . for this repair only the clutch band needs to be replaced
using a pair of pliers to compress the spring will loosen the clutch band .
lift the clutch band out of the clutch housing
clutch band removed . replace with model specific part .

Steps.Text_raw: It is not necessary to replace the whole clutch. For this repair only the clutch band needs to be replaced Using a pair of pliers to compress the spring will loosen the clutch band. Lift the clutch band out of the clutch housing Clutch band removed. Replace with model specific part.

Title: Sunbeam Snow Cone Maker Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: push the button on the back to release the lid . ( missing on this example device . )
in the photo on the device page it is red .

Lines.Text: unscrew the dasher by holding it in the middle and turning clockwise .
you will have to spin it quite a bit .
from here , you can now replace the dasher entirely .
alternately , you can continue to step 3 to further disassemble the dasher components .
to reassemble the device , follow these instructions in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the dasher by holding it in the middle and turning clockwise. You will have to spin it quite a bit. From here, you can now replace the dasher entirely. Alternately, you can continue to step 3 to further disassemble the  dasher components. To reassemble the device, follow these instructions in reverse order.

Lines.Text: to take the dasher apart , remove the three 5.5 mm phillips 00 screws embedded in the plastic . the 3 rd screw is behind the hand in the picture
carefully pull the two pieces apart .
when you've finished taking apart the dasher , you should have two parts that are shown in the second picture in this step .

Steps.Text_raw: To take the dasher apart, remove the three 5.5 mm Phillips #00 screws embedded in the plastic.  **The 3rd screw is behind the hand in the picture Carefully pull the two pieces apart. When you've finished taking apart the dasher, you should have two parts that are shown in the second picture in this step.

Lines.Text: after removing the dasher , turn the device so that you can see the lock and unlock symbols on the back .
twist the casing so that it is in the unlocked position and remove it from the bottom half of the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the dasher, turn the device so that you can see the “lock” and “unlock” symbols on the back. Twist the casing so that it is in the unlocked position and remove it from the bottom half of the machine.

Lines.Text: unscrew the five screws and remove the piece labeled in the picture . you should now be able to see the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the five screws and remove the piece labeled in the picture. You should now be able to see the motor.

Lines.Text: lay the device on its side .
remove the 4 gray rubber feet by pulling them straight outward .
remove the four 5.5 mm phillips 00 screws that are under them .
remove the bottom plastic cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the device on its side. Remove the  4 gray rubber “feet” by pulling them straight outward. Remove the four  5.5 mm Phillips #00 screws that are under them. Remove the bottom plastic cover.

Lines.Text: remove the two 5.5 mm phillips 00 screws holding a bracket to keep the cord in place .
remove the the bracket so the chord has room to move .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two  5.5 mm Phillips #00 screws holding a bracket to keep the cord in place. Remove the the bracket so the chord has room to move.

Lines.Text: remove the topmost 2 5.5 mm phillips 00 screws that hold the motor in its casing .
remove and replace the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the topmost 2  5.5 mm Phillips #00 screws that hold the motor in it’s casing. Remove and replace the motor.

Title: Repairing Bodum Bistro Electric Blender Stick Plastic motor transmission part

Lines.Text: 1. put the flat screwdriver above where the mains wire enters , and carefully push the top cover up . a small slit will appear .
2. in the slit , slide the screwdriver to the left . the slit will grow .
3. the tricky part is to push the plastic piece with the screwdriver slightly off the center outwards so that it will come loose and the cover lifts up .
repeat at the right .
i haven't been able to do this yet without breaking one of the plastic rods ( doesn't impair usage ) . don't worry too much , but be careful .

Steps.Text_raw: 1. Put the flat screwdriver above where the mains wire enters, and carefully push the top cover up. A small slit will appear. 2. In the slit, slide the screwdriver to the left. The slit will grow. 3. The tricky part is to push the plastic piece with the screwdriver slightly off the center outwards so that it will come loose and the cover lifts up. Repeat at the right. I haven't been able to do this yet without breaking one of the plastic rods (doesn't impair usage). Don't worry too much, but be careful.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws holding the black undercover with the cross screwdriver .
remove the pull relief with the screwdriver . don't forget to keep these screws apart from the other four . lift the wire up so it gets loose .
pull the top white part slightly down as shown , press the buttons , and slide it up . the buttons and a black body will remain .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws holding the black undercover with the cross screwdriver. Remove the pull relief with the screwdriver. Don't forget to keep these screws apart from the other four. Lift the wire up so it gets loose. Pull the top white part slightly down as shown, press the buttons, and slide it up. The buttons and a black body will remain.

Lines.Text: separate the inner black body containing the motor from the lower white body containing the mixing part .
unscrew the two screws with the cross screwdriver
pull the two parts apart .
remove the metal mixing rod from the lower white body .
put it inwards with your thumb from the bottom .
use a screwdriver to push the last bit completely in the body .
turn around and you'll find a metal rod and white plastic component tumbling down . ( the white plastic bit may also stick to the motor end instead . )

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the inner black body containing the motor from the lower white body containing the mixing part. Unscrew the two screws with the cross screwdriver Pull the two parts apart. Remove the metal mixing rod from the lower white body. Put it inwards with your thumb from the bottom. Use a screwdriver to push the last bit completely in the body. Turn around and you'll find a metal rod and white plastic component tumbling down. (The white plastic bit may also stick to the motor end instead.)

Lines.Text: take the twist tie ( about 3cm long , minimum 1.5cm ) and remove the plastic or paper enclosing .
bend it as shown so that it will fit in the white plastic transmission part .

put the wire inside the white plastic part , and shift it on the motor end . while it was loose before , it should now require a little force to put it on . when turning the white transmission part , the motor should go along now .
cut of the remaining ends of twist tie wire . ( i didn't do this at first , then the blender started making some noise because the wire was touching plastic parts when turned on . )
if it's still loose , you may add another wire at an angle of 90 degrees . i don't expect you'll need this , though .

Steps.Text_raw: Take the twist tie (about 3cm long, minimum 1.5cm) and remove the plastic or paper enclosing. Bend it as shown so that it will fit in the white plastic transmission part. Put the wire inside the white plastic part, and shift it on the motor end. While it was loose before, it should now require a little force to put it on. When turning the white transmission part, the motor should go along now. Cut of the remaining ends of twist tie wire. (I didn't do this at first, then the blender started making some noise because the wire was touching plastic parts when turned on.) If it's still loose, you may add another wire at an angle of 90 degrees. I don't expect you'll need this, though.

Lines.Text: now put back everything together . this should be fairly straightforward if you've followed this guide , except for one thing :
when putting back the motor , first put the motor in the plastic black body , then slide it into the white bottom part . keep an eye on the wires !
enjoy your blender again !

Steps.Text_raw: Now put back everything together. This should be fairly straightforward if you've followed this guide, except for one thing: When putting back the motor, first put the motor in the plastic black body, then slide it into the white bottom part. Keep an eye on the wires! Enjoy your blender again!

Title: Fixing a Refrigerator Door Seal

Lines.Text: grab a phillips head screwdriver
lift up the door seal and locate the screws underneath that hold the seal in place . loosen the screws to where they are pretty loose , but not out of their hole .
'''note''' to save energy , you can turn off your refrigerator before proceeding to steps 2-6.

Steps.Text_raw: Grab a Phillips Head Screw Driver Lift up the door seal and locate the screws underneath that hold the seal in place. Loosen the screws to where they are pretty loose, but not out of their hole. '''Note''' To save energy, you can turn off your refrigerator before proceeding to steps 2-6.

Lines.Text: after all the screws are loose , the door seal should slide off fairly easy . slowly remove the door seal with your hands by peeling it off the seal's shell .

Steps.Text_raw: After all the screws are loose, the door seal should slide off fairly easy. Slowly remove the door seal with your hands by peeling it off the seal's shell.

Lines.Text: thoroughly wash the door seal in soap and water
using a paper towel ( or regular towel ) , dry the seal .
'''note''' if your seal has cracks in it , you will need to replace it . if this is the case , skip this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Thoroughly wash the door seal in Soap and Water Using a paper towel (or regular towel), dry the seal. '''Note''' If your seal has cracks in it, you will need to replace it. If this is the case, skip this step.

Lines.Text: on the side that connects to the refrigerator unit , apply a thin layer of silicon grease . this will improve functionality as well as prevent the seal from cracking in the future .

Steps.Text_raw: On the side that connects to the refrigerator unit, apply a thin layer of silicon grease. This will improve functionality as well as prevent the seal from cracking in the future.

Lines.Text: to reattach the seal , feed the back of the seal behind the white frame .
it is easiest to do this by starting at any corner and completing one side at a time .

Steps.Text_raw: To reattach the seal,feed the back of the seal behind the white frame. It is easiest to do this by starting at any corner and completing one side at a time.

Lines.Text: make sure the white shell is holding the seal in place on all sides .
tighten all of the screws back in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the white shell is holding the seal in place on all sides. Tighten all of the screws back in place.

Title: Breville Dual Boiler (BES900/BES900XL) Group Head Collar Insert Replacement Guide

Lines.Text: there are 2 types of collars for the bes900 /xl and the bes920 /xl , they are both identical except the internal rim inside the collars vary in thickness , the one in the newer bes920 /xl machines have the thicker rim which assists in the portafilter contacting the seal much sooner than the bes900 /xl creating a tighter seal .
some 1 st generation bes900 /xl models had their whole group head , element and collar upgraded under warranty also .
ensure you purchase the correct collar for your machine .

Steps.Text_raw: There are 2 types of collars for the BES900/XL and the BES920/XL, they are both identical except the internal rim inside the collars vary in thickness, the one in the newer BES920/XL machines have the thicker rim which assists in the portafilter contacting the seal much sooner than the BES900/XL creating a tighter seal. Some 1st generation BES900/XL models had their whole group head, element and collar upgraded under warranty also. Ensure you purchase the correct collar for your machine.

Lines.Text: start by removing the water container from the rear of the machine , then unscrew the two t20 torx screws from the rear of the machine on the top of the rear panel
now remove the two phillips screws from the bottom of the rear panel , remembering that the longer screw is on the left and the shorter is on the right

Steps.Text_raw: Start by removing the water container from the rear of the machine, then unscrew the two T20 torx screws from the rear of the machine on the top of the rear panel Now remove the two phillips screws from the bottom of the rear panel, remembering that the longer screw is on the left and the shorter is on the right

Lines.Text: now turn the machine upside down on your workbench then use your screwdriver remove the two phillips screws either side of the group head .
these two screws are about 2cm in length and will likely fall out once you lift the top off the machine

Steps.Text_raw: Now turn the machine upside down on your workbench then use your screw driver remove the two phillips screws either side of the group head. These two screws are about 2cm in length and will likely fall out once you lift the top off the machine

Lines.Text: after removing the four screws from the top cover , the lid can now be lifted from the machine .
remove the rear panel from the machine also .
now fold both the top and rear cover to behind the machine where it is out of the way .

unscrew the two screws from the front panel then lift the panel off the machine , be careful not to break any of the outer holding clips from the panel . removing the front panel will make it easier to access the front boiler and group head screws .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the four screws from the top cover, the lid can now be lifted from the machine. Remove the rear panel from the machine also. Now fold both the top and rear cover to behind the machine where it is out of the way. Unscrew the two screws from the front panel then lift the panel off the machine, be careful not to break any of the outer holding clips from the panel. Removing the front panel will make it easier to access the front boiler and group head screws.

Lines.Text: remove the three phillips screws from the group head boiler .
using your needle nose pliers remove the locking clip pins from the boiler tubes and the pressure dial from the front panel .
use the needle nose pliers to remove the yellow leads from the boiler also .
you may wish to mark each tube prior to the next step .

now remove the tubes and leads from the boiler . you will not need to remove the two red leads , 1 blue lead and the black leads as these can easily be kept with the boiler when moving it to the rear of the machine

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three phillips screws from the group head boiler. Using your needle nose pliers remove the locking clip pins from the boiler tubes and the pressure dial from the front panel. Use the needle nose pliers to remove the yellow leads from the boiler also. You may wish to mark each tube prior to the next step. Now remove the tubes and leads from the boiler. You will not need to remove the two red leads, 1 blue lead and the black leads as these can easily be kept with the boiler when moving it to the rear of the machine

Lines.Text: the boiler can now be relocated to the rear of the machine where it will sit out of the way whilst working on the group head .
after relocating the boiler , unscrew the 8 screws holding the group head in place .

Steps.Text_raw: The boiler can now be relocated to the rear of the machine where it will sit out of the way whilst working on the group head. After relocating the boiler, unscrew the 8 screws holding the group head in place.

Lines.Text: lift the group head out of the way , it can be pulled to the side if required , now remove the plastic collar from the machine ( not pictured ) . at this stage it's a good idea to clean any old coffee grinds from group head and from the aluminum rim underneath the removed insert .
now insert the new group collar insert into the housing .
orientation of the insert is not a concern here , just make sure it is bedded into the housing correctly ( small lugs are resting in their respective holes ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the Group Head out of the way, it can be pulled to the side if required, now remove the plastic collar from the machine (not pictured). At this stage it's a good idea to clean any old coffee grinds from group head and from the aluminum rim underneath the removed insert. Now insert the new group collar insert into the housing. Orientation of the insert is not a concern here, just make sure it is bedded into the housing correctly (small lugs are resting in their respective holes).

Subject: Group Head Collar Insert

Lines.Text: the metal cage is kept in place by three plastic tabs on the plastic body . focus your pulling around these tabs to make the job easier .
in order to remove the metal cage , place one hand firmly on the back plastic body and your other hand on the metal cage .
now work your way around the edge of the fan cage and pull it away from the plastic body .

Steps.Text_raw: The metal cage is kept in place by three plastic tabs on the plastic body. Focus your pulling around these tabs to make the job easier. Lines.Text: to remove the fan blade , reach behind it and slowly pull it towards you .
if the fan blade axle has any hair or dirt , then clean it with a cloth to avoid further fan blade blockage .
if you are having difficulty removing the fan blade , then generously apply wd-40 to the fan blade axle .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the fan blade, reach behind it and slowly pull it towards you. If the fan blade axle has any hair or dirt, then clean it with a cloth to avoid further fan blade blockage. Title: Comfort Zone CZ6C Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: make sure to unplug the comfort zone cz6 c before cutting any wires .
before replacing your switch , learn how to solder using the to solder and desolder connections guide .
start with the fan on its back . unscrew the back panel to expose the internal wiring .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure to unplug the Comfort Zone CZ6C before cutting any wires. Before replacing your switch, learn how to solder using the [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|How To Solder and Desolder Connections Guide]. Start with the fan on its back. Unscrew the back panel to expose the internal wiring.

Lines.Text: remove the plastic cover on the switch by pulling it apart from the the back panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic cover on the switch by pulling it apart from the the back panel.

Lines.Text: use the soldering iron with caution . don't touch the tip of the soldering iron to avoid the risk of injury .
this step can be made easier with the help of a partner to hold the wiring while you desolder the connection .
disconnect the gray power wire from the switch by desoldering the connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the soldering iron with caution. Don't touch the tip of the soldering iron to avoid the risk of injury. This step can be made easier with the help of a partner to hold the wiring while you desolder the connection. Disconnect the gray power wire from the switch by desoldering the connection.

Lines.Text: cut the green and yellow wire as close to the switch connection as possible .

Steps.Text_raw: Cut the green and yellow wire as close to the switch connection as possible.

Lines.Text: strip the green and yellow wire about two centimeters from where it was just cut .

Steps.Text_raw: Strip the green and yellow wire about two centimeters from where it was just cut.

Lines.Text: unscrew the switch from the back panel and remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the switch from the back panel and remove it.

Lines.Text: after replacing the switch , resolder the gray power cord , the green wire , and the yellow wire .

Steps.Text_raw: After replacing the switch, resolder the gray power cord, the green wire, and the yellow wire.

Subject: Switch

Lines.Text: make sure to unplug the comfort zone cz6 c before cutting any wires .

Start with the fan on its back. Unscrew the back panel to expose the internal wiring.

Lines.Text: unscrew the yellow cap that connects the black wire and the gray power cord wire . then , unwind the tied wires and pull them apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the yellow cap that connects the black wire and the gray power cord wire. Then, unwind the tied wires and pull them apart.

Lines.Text: remove the plastic cover on the switch by pulling it apart from the back panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the plastic cover on the switch by pulling it apart from the back panel.

Lines.Text: use the soldering iron with caution . don't touch the tip of the soldering iron to avoid the risk of injury .
this step can be made easier with the help of a partner to hold the wiring while you desolder the connection .
disconnect the gray power wire from the switch by desoldering the connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the soldering iron with caution. Don't touch the tip of the soldering iron to avoid the risk of injury. This step can be made easier with the help of a partner to hold the wiring while you desolder the connection. Disconnect the gray power wire from the switch by desoldering the connection.

Lines.Text: strip the end of the gray power cord .
then solder the end of the gray power cord to the switch .

remove the two 12 mm phillips 2 screws located at the brim of the pot .

Lines.Text: adhesive tape is left holding the lid to the glass pot .
use the spudger for this step .
with one hand , firmly grip the lid while designating your other hand to wedge the spudger between the lid and the glass pot .
working from the outside to the inside , gently pry the adhesive tape from the glass pot , detaching the lid .

Title: Capresso Perfectea 260 Handle Replacement

Lines.Text: lift the lid of the perfectea
remove the two 12 mm phillips 2 screws located at the brim of the pot .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the lid of the Perfectea Remove the two 12mm Phillips #2 screws located at the brim of the pot.

Lines.Text: adhesive tape is left holding the lid to the glass pot .
use the spudger for this step .
with one hand , firmly grip the lid while designating your other hand to wedge the spudger between the lid and the glass pot .
working from the outside to the inside , gently pry the adhesive tape from the glass pot , detaching the lid .

With one hand, firmly grip the lid while designating your other hand to wedge the spudger between the lid and the glass pot. Working from the outside to the inside, gently pry the adhesive tape from the glass pot, detaching the lid.

Lines.Text: use the plastic opening tool for this step .
firmly grip the glass pot with one hand while using the other to slip the flat end of the plastic opening tool between the glass pot and the adhesive tape holding the handle to the glass pot .
gently pry the adhesive tape from the glass pot . work your way around the handle until the handle is loose and not attached to the pot anymore .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the plastic opening tool for this step. Lines.Text: the bottom panel has four wires that latch on to four tabs .
use the metal spudger to pry up one metal tab in the latch .
apply pressure with the metal spudger to the other tab on the latch to slide off tab .
repeat for the remaining three tabs .
the bottom panel should now be disconnected from the rest of the kettle .
take note of which cable attaches to which tab so that you will remember how to reconnect the wires properly . using masking tape to mark which wire goes to which terminal is helpful .
do not push tabs too forcefully otherwise you may damage your device or impale yourself .

Steps.Text_raw: The bottom panel has four wires that latch on to four tabs. Use the metal spudger to pry up one metal tab in the latch. Apply pressure with the metal spudger to the other tab on the latch to slide off tab. Repeat for the remaining three tabs. The bottom panel should now be disconnected from the rest of the kettle. Take note of which cable attaches to which tab so that you will remember how to reconnect the wires properly. Using masking tape to mark which wire goes to which terminal is helpful. Do not push tabs too forcefully otherwise you may damage your device or impale yourself.

Lines.Text: remove the metal spacer and washer from the central threaded rod .

Lines.Text: remove the base wall .

Lines.Text: wedge a plastic opening tool under the rubber seal on the inside of the kettle .
work the plastic opening tool around to loosen the seal and push the heating dome out of its hole .

the heating dome is wedged in the bottom very firmly and will fly out its position suddenly if not controlled . make sure you are holding the top side of the heating dome while pushing from the bottom so that it does not hit the side of the kettle and shatter the glass .
remove the heating dome from the kettle .

Steps.Text_raw: Wedge a plastic opening tool under the rubber seal on the inside of the kettle. Work the plastic opening tool around to loosen the seal and push the heating dome out of its hole. The heating dome is wedged in the bottom very firmly and will fly out its position suddenly if not controlled. Make sure you are holding the top side of the heating dome while pushing from the bottom so that it does not hit the side of the kettle and shatter the glass. Remove the heating dome from the kettle.

Lines.Text: desolder the five wires from the solder pads shown .
if you do not know how to do this , ifixit has a describing the process .

Lines.Text: after the wires have cooled enough to touch , carefully slide the circuit board free of the wires .
'''note''' : keep track of which pad each wire was soldered to . this is important for your blender to function .

Title: How to open and clean Keurig Coffee Maker

Lines.Text: keurig k40 not brewing/dispensing 12 oz
open the keurig all the way to remove the k-cup holder
the k-cup holder simply pulls straight up . there might be a bit of resistance from some spring clips . the flaky debris is actually coffee from reusable k-cup filters .

Steps.Text_raw: Keurig K40 not brewing/dispensing 12oz Open the Keurig all the way to remove the K-cup Holder The K-cup holder simply pulls straight up. There might be a bit of resistance from some spring clips. The flaky debris is actually coffee from reusable K-cup filters.

Lines.Text: k-cup insert removed . clean with hot water as needed .

on the bottom of the k-cup insert is a tapered needle that punctures the bottom of the k-cup . on the side of it is a small hole . use a paper clip ( or similar ) and insert it in there to remove any scale , coffee grounds etc .

next is to clean the top needle . it is trickier since it is somewhat hard to reach around the sides of the needle . there will be three holes around the needle . open the keurig all the way , and again use a paper clip ( or similar ) .

Steps.Text_raw: K-cup insert removed. Clean with hot water as needed. On the bottom of the K-cup insert is a tapered needle that punctures the bottom of the K-cup. On the side of it is a small hole. Use a paper clip (or similar) and insert it in there to remove any scale, coffee grounds etc. Next is to clean the top needle. It is  trickier since it is somewhat hard to reach around the sides of the needle. There will be three holes around the needle. Open the Keurig all the way, and again use a paper clip (or similar).

Lines.Text: a hypodermic needle or similar can also be used to open up the water outlet
next remove the water tank by simply lifting it up .
on the inside bottom of the tank is a simple check valve that allows the removal of the tank , then empty the tank .

Steps.Text_raw: A hypodermic needle or similar can also be used to open up the water outlet Next remove the water tank by simply lifting it up. On the inside bottom of the tank is a simple check valve that allows the removal of the tank, then empty the tank.

Lines.Text: top part of the check valve on the bottom . there is a fine screen that acts as a filter . remove that by removing the three phillips screws with a long 2 phillips screwdriver . clean the screen under running water with a brush . reassemble after proper cleaning .
next step is to remove the top cover to get to the water supply to the k-cup . open the keurig . remove two phillips screws that hold it in place .
lift the top cover up and forward to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Top part of the check valve on the bottom. there is a fine screen that acts as a filter. Remove that by removing the three Phillips screws with a long #2 Phillips screwdriver. Clean the screen under running water with a brush. Reassemble after proper cleaning. Next step is to remove the top cover to get to the water supply to the K-cup.  Open the Keurig. remove two Phillips screws that hold it in place. Lift the top cover up and forward to remove it.

Lines.Text: water supply from the boiler to the k-cup needle is via a water hose through a check valve .
remove the two small screws that hold the water line to the inlet
unhook the water line from the connector above the k-cup needle . it is a simple press fit .
next remove the tie straps . ( you don't have to do this step ) just remove the other end of hose from pump . you might have to use a flat head screwdriver to lift up on end of hose while pulling up

Steps.Text_raw: Water supply from the boiler to the K-cup needle is via a water hose through a check valve. Remove the two small screws that hold the water line to the inlet Unhook the water line from the connector above the K-cup needle. it is a simple press fit. Next remove the tie straps. (You don't have to do this step) Just remove the other end of hose from pump. You might have to use a flat head screwdriver to lift up on end of hose while pulling up

Lines.Text: test the check valve . blowing air in it from the boiler side should cause it to open . repeat that a couple of times to loosen any sediments etc . it will also help to run some hot water from the k-cup side into the check valve and shake it up . once it is cleaned , replace the check valve and the tie straps . reassemble the keurig

Steps.Text_raw: Test the check valve. Blowing air in it from the boiler side should cause it to open. Repeat that a couple of times to loosen any sediments etc. It will also help to run some hot water from the K-cup side into the check valve and shake it up. Once it is cleaned, replace the check valve and the tie straps. Reassemble the Keurig

Title: Repairing Holmes tower fan to fix and eliminate clicking, scraping sounds

Lines.Text: in order to open the fan , you will need a phillips head screwdriver , micro screwdriver , and safety glasses .

start by unplugging the fan and removing the screws that hold the cover into place . my fan had 7 screws ; six were obvious but one was hidden behind a plastic cap near the top/back of the unit ( arrow in 2nd pic ) .
in order to access the hidden screw , push in on one side of the cap so that it rotates and then slide the micro screwdriver behind it . pry the cap out and remove that screw .

next , gently remove the cover . the right side of it will likely have tabs holding it in place ( circled in 3 rd pic ) . you will need to push in on the cover at those locations in order to pop the tabs out . be patient and gentle and eventually youll have the cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to open the fan, you will need a Philips head screw driver, micro screw driver, and safety glasses. Start by unplugging the fan and removing the screws that hold the cover into place.  My fan had 7 screws; six were obvious but one was hidden behind a plastic cap near the top/back of the unit (arrow in 2nd pic). In order to access the hidden screw, push in on one side of the cap so that it rotates and then slide the micro screw driver behind it.  Pry the cap out and remove that screw. Next, gently remove the cover.  The right side of it will likely have tabs holding it in place (circled in 3rd pic).  You will need to push in on the cover at those locations in order to pop the tabs out.  Be patient and gentle and eventually you’ll have the cover off.

Lines.Text: put on your safety glasses and plug the fan in . turn it on and listen for the source of the sound . most likely it will be coming from the bearing at the top of the blade drum ( see picture ) . you may even see the metal bracket vibrating . if this is the case , youre in luck and can follow the steps below to fix it !

go to the hardware store and ask for a bottle of liquid electrical tape , rtv sealant , or caulking . what you want is a liquid rubber that will provide some viscoelastic dampening ( hopefully using that word will make me sound smart and make up for the grammar errors and misspellings ) .

turn off the fan and remove the two screws that hold the metal bracket on . remove the bracket by flexing the blade drum towards you and lifting the bracket and bearing off the shaft . next use a cotton swab to spread the grease around the blade drums shaft .

see how the metal bracket has a horizontal tab that sits in a slot of the plastic housing ? you want to lightly coat that tab with the liquid rubber compound and also coat the back of the vertical surface that has the screw holes . be careful not to slop any onto the bearing or shaft .

place a little rubber compound into the screw holes and then put the bearing/bracket back onto the blade shaft . start the screws back in again but stop before they become snug so that the bracket is still loose .

still wearing your safety glasses , turn the fan back on and observe the bracket . adjust the screws a little tighter at a time until the bracket stops vibrating and the fan runs quietly . turn the fan back off and allow the liquid rubber time to dry before putting the case back together again .
hopefully it solved the problem permanently !

Steps.Text_raw: Put on your safety glasses and plug the fan in.  Turn it on and listen for the source of the sound.  Most likely it will be coming from the bearing at the top of the blade drum (see picture).  You may even see the metal bracket vibrating.  If this is the case, you’re in luck and  can follow the steps below to fix it! Go to the hardware store and ask for a bottle of liquid electrical tape, RTV sealant, or caulking.  What you want is a liquid rubber that will provide some viscoelastic dampening (hopefully using that word will make me sound smart and make up for the grammar errors and misspellings). Turn off the fan and remove the two screws that hold the metal bracket on.  Remove the bracket by flexing the blade drum towards you and lifting the bracket and bearing off the shaft.  Next use a cotton swab to spread the grease around the blade drum’s shaft. See how the metal bracket has a horizontal tab that sits in a slot of the plastic housing?  You want to lightly coat that tab with the liquid rubber compound and also coat the back of the vertical surface that has the screw holes.  Be careful not to slop any onto the bearing or shaft. Place a little rubber compound into the screw holes and then put the bearing/bracket back onto the blade shaft.  Start the screws back in again but stop before they become snug so that the bracket is still loose. Still wearing your safety glasses, turn the fan back on and observe the bracket.  Adjust the screws a little tighter at a time until the bracket stops vibrating and the fan runs quietly.  Turn the fan back off and allow the liquid rubber time to dry before putting the case back together again. Hopefully it solved the problem permanently!

unscrew the two caps and keep track of the wires that wire up together to make it easier in the end to put back together .

Lines.Text: locate the clear plastic motor fan .
grab hold of the motor and pull upwards to pop the motor fan off of the needle that connects to the motor .
this may require large amounts of force to pull it off the needle .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the clear plastic motor fan. Grab hold of the motor and pull upwards to pop the motor fan off of the needle that connects to the motor. This may require large amounts of force to pull it off the needle.

Lines.Text: remove the two 4 mm phillips 00 screws .
once the screws are removed , the motor should drop down .
now remove the motor base to expose the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 4 mm Phillips #00 screws. Once the screws are removed, the motor should drop down. Now remove the motor base to expose the motor.

Lines.Text: this is the motor .
now replace it with your new one !

Steps.Text_raw: This is the motor. Now replace it with your new one!

Subject: Motor

Title: Presto PopLite 04820 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: be sure that the popper is unplugged before disassembly .
turn presto popper upside down .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure that the popper is unplugged before disassembly. Turn Presto Popper upside down.

Lines.Text: remove the four 9 mm phillips 2 screws from the base .
once all four screws are removed , take the base off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 9 mm Phillips #2  screws from the base. Once all four screws are removed, take the base off.

Lines.Text: untwist the two orange twist-on wire connectors .
make a note of which wires are in each of the orange caps .

Steps.Text_raw: Untwist the two orange twist-on wire connectors. Make a note of which wires are in each of the orange caps.

Lines.Text: locate the plastic piece holding the power cord in place .
take the metal spudger from the tool kit and pry this piece loose .
this plastic piece may take excessive force to pry out , just keep trying until it pops out .
remove the power cord .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the plastic piece holding the power cord in place. Take the metal spudger from the tool kit and pry this piece loose. This plastic piece may take excessive force to pry out, just keep trying until it pops out. Remove the power cord.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: Kenwood Chef A701A Power Cable Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the mixer upside down
remove the two screws holding the white cable grip .
remove the black cable grip . the long screw also holds the cover onto the terminal block

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the mixer upside down Remove the two screws holding the white cable grip. Remove the black cable grip. The long screw also holds the cover  onto the terminal block

Lines.Text: remove the cable cover to expose the terminal block .
remove the wires from the live and neutral terminals .
thread the cables out though the cover and then from the mixer chassis

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cable cover to expose the terminal block. Remove the wires from the live and neutral terminals. Thread the cables out though the cover and then from the mixer chassis

Lines.Text: to refit simply follow the removal process in reverse
be sure to connect the wires to the correct terminals , brown - live , blue , neutral .
if fitting a new plug ensure it is fitted with the appropriate fuse . if in any doubt consult a compitent electrician/electrical engineer

Steps.Text_raw: To refit simply follow the removal process in reverse Be sure to connect the wires to the correct terminals,  Brown - Live, Blue, Neutral. If fitting a new plug ensure it is fitted with the appropriate fuse.  If in any doubt consult a compitent electrician/electrical engineer

Title: Ceiling Fan Light  Fixture Replacement

Lines.Text: working with electrical wires could lead to electrocution .
find your circuit breaker panel and turn off the breaker that corresponds to your ceiling lights .
do this by pushing it to the right .
also flip your light switch to off .

Steps.Text_raw: Working with electrical wires could lead to electrocution. Find your circuit breaker panel and turn off the breaker that corresponds to your ceiling lights. Do this by pushing it to the right. Also flip your light switch to off.

Lines.Text: remove the two 1.4 mm phillips head screws that hold the fixture to the fan itself .
once loose , pull down to expose the two connecting wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 1.4 mm Phillips head screws that hold the fixture to the fan itself. Once loose, pull down to expose the two connecting wires.

Lines.Text: disconnect these wires by twisting the caps in a counter-clockwise direction .
you only need to disconnect the wires coming from the lighting fixture .
once both caps are removed , simply pull the wires apart to remove the fixture .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect these wires by twisting the caps in a counter-clockwise direction. You only need to disconnect the wires coming from the lighting fixture. Once both caps are removed, simply pull the wires apart to remove the fixture.

Lines.Text: loosen the nut holding the ceiling fan piece to the lighting fixture .
this step may require a crescent wrench if finger force is not enough .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen the nut holding the ceiling fan piece to the lighting fixture. This step may require a crescent wrench if finger force is not enough.

Lines.Text: pull upwards to remove the fan piece that holds the light fixture .
your model may require you to twist this piece in a counter-clockwise motion to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull upwards to remove the fan piece that holds the light fixture. Your model may require you to twist this piece in a counter-clockwise motion to remove.

Lines.Text: switch out the old fixture with your new fixture by doing the last two steps in reverse order .

Steps.Text_raw: Switch out the old fixture with your new fixture by doing the last two steps in reverse order.

Lines.Text: to connect your new fixture , locate the black wire from your light and the colored wire from the fan .
be sure to attached the colored wires to each other , and white wires to each other . ( positive-positive , negative-negative )
twist these together . do the same with the two white wires .

Steps.Text_raw: To connect your new fixture, locate the black wire from your light and the colored wire from the fan. Be sure to attached the colored wires to each other, and white wires to each other. (Positive-Positive, Negative-Negative) Twist these together. Do the same with the two white wires.

Lines.Text: your new light fixture should come with replacement caps . twist these in a clockwise motion over your wire ends to ensure connection .
the old caps work just as well for this if you were not given new ones .

Steps.Text_raw: Your new light fixture should come with replacement caps. Twist these in a clockwise motion  over your wire ends to ensure connection. The old caps work just as well for this if you were not given new ones.

Lines.Text: be sure to neatly tuck in all wires when re-attaching the fixture .
failure to do this will result in not being able to correctly close the gap and put in the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure to neatly tuck in all wires when re-attaching the fixture. Failure to do this will result in not being able to correctly close the gap and put in the screws.

Lines.Text: flip your breaker back on , turn on your light switch , and enjoy your new lights !

Steps.Text_raw: Flip your breaker back on, turn on your light switch, and enjoy your new lights!

Subject: Light Fixture

Title: Bionaire Mini Tower Fan Blade Replacement

Lines.Text: there are 6 screws holding the entire fan together , which need to be removed to access the internals of the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: There are 6 screws holding the entire fan together, which need to be removed to access the internals of the fan.

Lines.Text: once the screws are all off , the fan can be pulled apart with a little bit of force . however , not too much force is required .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the screws are all off, the fan can be pulled apart with a little bit of force.  However, not too much force is required.

Lines.Text: once you have the fan apart , in order to get more maneuverability , the wire attached to the motor needs to be loosened . this can be done by removing the two screws highlighted in red .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have the fan apart, in order to get more maneuverability, the wire attached to the motor needs to be loosened.  This can be done by removing the two screws highlighted in red.

Lines.Text: to get more maneuverability , remove the button panel . this can be done by removing the 2 screws on either side of the panel in order to fully remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: To get more maneuverability,  remove the button panel. This can be done by removing the 2 screws on either side of the panel in order to fully remove it.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the panel by pulling on it . it should fall out easily and separate completely from its housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the panel by pulling on it. It should fall out easily and separate completely from its housing.

Lines.Text: the bolt that you need to remove is inside of the pre-installed fan blades . with your pliers , grab a hold of the nut and twist to the right . this will allow you to remove the fan blades .

Steps.Text_raw: The bolt that you need to remove is inside of the pre-installed fan blades.  With your pliers, grab a hold of the nut and twist to the RIGHT. This will allow you to remove the fan blades.

Lines.Text: in order to install the new blades , there are two pieces that you have to match up . the blades and pole both have a flat side that you have to match up in order for the blades to stay on .
make sure when you install the blades , it blows air when it rotates in a counterclockwise fashion .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to install the new blades, there are two pieces that you have to match up.  The blades and pole both have a flat side that you have to match up in order for the blades to stay on. Make sure when you install the blades, it blows air when it rotates in a counterclockwise fashion.

Lines.Text: tighten the bolt to the left and you have successfully installed your new fan blades .

Steps.Text_raw: Tighten the bolt to the left and you have successfully installed your new fan blades.

Subject: Blades

Title: Repairing Kitchenaid KTT340OB0 Catch Lever

Lines.Text: start this fix by making sure the toaster is unplugged .
next , remove the crumb tray from the bottom slot and set it aside .
pull the toaster lever cover straight off .

Steps.Text_raw: Start this fix by making sure the toaster is unplugged. Next, remove the crumb tray from the bottom slot and set it aside. Pull the toaster lever cover straight off.

Lines.Text: pull the timer knob located on the front of the toaster . with a little bit of force , it should easily pop off .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the timer knob located on the front of the toaster. With a little bit of force, it should easily pop off.

Lines.Text: flip the toaster upside down .
use needle nose pliers to remove the rubber screw covers located on the four corners of the bottom of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the toaster upside down. Use needle nose pliers to remove the rubber screw covers located on the four corners of the bottom of the toaster.

Lines.Text: use the screwdriver to remove the four 12.5 mm phillips 1 screws . the screws are located on the four corners of the toaster under the rubber covers .
to remove the screws , turn the screwdriver counterclockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the screwdriver to remove the four 12.5 mm Phillips #1 screws. The screws are located on the four corners of the toaster under the rubber covers. To remove the screws, turn the screwdriver counterclockwise.

Lines.Text: pull the bottom of the toaster straight out of the top shell .
be careful to not loosen or break any components .
set the toaster down the normal way it would sit .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the bottom of the toaster straight out of the top shell. Be careful to not loosen or break any components. Set the toaster down the normal way it would  sit.

Lines.Text: locate broken metal lever catch to the right of the large spring . it should look like a paperclip .
remove it carefully with your fingers or needle nose pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate broken metal lever catch to the right of the large spring. It should look like a paperclip. Remove it carefully with your fingers or needle nose pliers.

Lines.Text: use needle nose plyers to pry off the remaining piece of the broken metal lever catch .
the broken metal lever catch pieces are pictured in the third picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Use needle nose plyers to pry off the remaining piece of the broken metal lever catch. The broken metal lever catch pieces are pictured in the third picture.

Lines.Text: take new paperclip with needle nose plyers .
bend in paperclip into the hook shape pictured so it will be able to loop around the divots on the plastic lever .
the divots on the plastic lever are shown in the third picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Take new paperclip with needle nose plyers. Bend in paperclip into the hook shape pictured so it will be able to loop around the divots on the plastic lever. The divots on the plastic lever  are shown in the third picture.

Lines.Text: place the newly bent paperclip onto plastic lever weaving it through the divots . make sure that when the main spring comes down it engages the paperclip to push the lever down .

when the plastic lever is pushed down , the magnet engages and the timer on the toaster starts . as long as the paperclip stays glued on , the toaster will function fine because the magnet actually holds the toast down . the plastic lever just engages the magnet . the paperclip's main purpose is to extend the lever so it will be able to engage .

use an adhesive to bond the paperclip to the plastic lever . a plastic welding adhesive such as jb weld will work best but super glue or even a hot glue gun will work as well . as long as the paperclip stays glued on , the toaster will function fine . make sure to fully cover the paperclip with the adhesive .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the newly bent paperclip onto plastic lever weaving it through the divots. Make sure that when the main spring comes down it engages the paperclip to push the lever down. When the plastic lever is pushed down, the magnet engages and the timer on the toaster starts. As long as the paperclip stays glued on, the toaster will function fine because the magnet actually holds the toast down. The plastic lever just engages the magnet. The paperclip's main purpose is to extend the lever so it will be able  to engage. Use an adhesive to bond the paperclip to the plastic lever. A plastic welding adhesive such as JB weld will work best but super glue or even a hot glue gun will work as well. As long as the paperclip stays glued on, the toaster will function fine. Make sure to fully cover the paperclip with the adhesive.

Title: Hamilton Beach 51101BA Power Button Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the container from the base .
hold the blender and the container , then twist the container in a clockwise motion .
make sure to follow the lock and unlock markings on the container .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the container from the base. Hold the blender and the container, then twist the container in a clockwise motion. Make sure to follow the lock and unlock markings on the container.

Lines.Text: turn the blender so the bottom is facing you .
using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the two 5 mm phillips screws from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the blender so the bottom is facing you. Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the two 5 mm Phillips screws from the base.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the two 5 mm phillips screws from the motor platform .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the two 5 mm Phillips screws from the motor platform.

Lines.Text: unhinge the motor platform from the blender .
you may need a plastic spudger to unhinge the plastic bottom piece from the base of the blender .
you do not need to completely remove this piece from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Unhinge the motor platform from the blender. You may need a plastic spudger to unhinge the plastic bottom piece from the base of the blender. You do not need to completely remove this piece from the base.

Lines.Text: pull out the rectangular green piece .
this is the actual power button .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the rectangular green piece. This is the actual power button.

Lines.Text: some experience in soldering is required !
on the back of the power button , desolder the red and grey wires that are connected to the piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Some experience in soldering is required! On the back of the power button, desolder the red and grey wires that are connected to the piece.

Subject: Power Button

Title: Lasko Box Fan Back Wire Repair

Lines.Text: make sure the fan is unplugged .
unscrew the 6 screws on the front of the fan .
remove the face plate .
flip the fan and repeat for the 6 screws on the back . they are in the same position as the front .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the fan is unplugged. Unscrew the 6 screws on the front of the fan. Remove the face plate. Flip the fan and repeat for the 6 screws on the back. They are in the same position as the front.

Lines.Text: unscrew the screws attaching the motor/blades to the frame .
unscrew the screws attaching the plastic frame to the motor .
the blades cannot be removed from the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the screws attaching the motor/blades to the frame. Unscrew the screws attaching the plastic frame to the motor. The blades cannot be removed from the motor.

Lines.Text: strip the wires using wire strippers .

Steps.Text_raw: Strip the wires using wire strippers.

Lines.Text: twist the ends of the wire together
place wires in soldering kit arms .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the ends of the wire together Place wires in soldering kit arms.

Lines.Text: plug in the soldering iron .
when the soldering iron is hot , solder the wires together .
place the tip of the soldering iron on the wires directly .
place the solder on the wire .
remove the solder and soldering iron from the wire
repeat this step with the second wire .
soldering irons are very hot !

Steps.Text_raw: Plug in the soldering iron. When the soldering iron is hot, solder the wires together. Place the tip of the soldering iron on the wires directly. Place the solder on the wire. Remove the solder and soldering iron from the wire Repeat this step with the second wire. Soldering irons are very hot!

Lines.Text: use electrical tape to insulate the wires .
wrap the tape around each wire .
wrap tape around the outside of all of the wires .
make sure to completely cover any exposed wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Use electrical tape to insulate the wires. Wrap the tape around each wire. Wrap tape around the outside of all of the wires. Make sure to completely cover any exposed wire.

Lines.Text: clean out the dust from the blades and motor using tweezers .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean out the dust from the blades and motor using tweezers.

Lines.Text: tape wires along the frame to prevent further damage .
put the face plates back on and enjoy !

Steps.Text_raw: Tape wires along the frame to prevent further damage. Put the face plates back on and enjoy!

Title: Ninja Master Prep QB900B button replacement

Lines.Text: place the blender to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the blender to the side.

Lines.Text: remove the two highlighted screws with a phillips 2 screwdriver
gently pull off the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two highlighted screws with a Phillips #2 Screw Driver Gently pull off the top.

Lines.Text: remove the highlighted screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the highlighted screws.

Lines.Text: pull out the highlighted spring .
now wash the button with soap and water , and follow the guide backwards to reassemble .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the highlighted spring. Now wash the button with soap and water, and follow the guide backwards to reassemble.

Title: Honeywell HY-254-TGT Front Panel Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the two 3 /4 wing screws on the bottom of the fan by rotating them counter-clockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 3/4" wing screws on the bottom of the fan by rotating them counter-clockwise.

Lines.Text: twist the fan base counter-clockwise until the pins line up as shown .
pull the base straight towards you to remove it , feeding the wire through the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the fan base counter-clockwise until the pins line up as shown. Pull the base straight towards you to remove it, feeding the wire through the base.

Lines.Text: remove all of the marked 1 /2 phillips 02 screws on the backside of the fan
remove the two marked 3 /4 phillips 02 screws in the middle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove all of the marked 1/2" Phillips #02 screws on the backside of the fan Remove the two marked 3/4" Phillips #02 screws in the middle.

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool or screwdriver to pry off the back of the fan , starting from the top down .
be aware of two clips inside the fan , towards the bottom third of the fan . if the back appears stuck on certain spots , push inward edges of the front casing around the problematic area .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a plastic opening tool or screwdriver to pry off the back of the fan, starting from the top down. Be aware of two clips inside the fan, towards the bottom third of the fan. If the back appears stuck on certain spots,  push inward edges of the front casing around the problematic area.

Lines.Text: remove the four 1 /2 phillips 02 screws , indicated by a red circle .
lean the front panel forwards and set it down .
the front panel will not fully detach and cannot be removed . do not try to forcibly remove it , as it may cause damage to the electronics .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 1/2" Phillips #02  screws, indicated by a red circle. Lean the front panel forwards and set it down. The front panel will not fully detach and cannot be removed. Do not try to forcibly remove it, as it may cause damage to the electronics.

Lines.Text: gently lift and remove the panel covering the electronics assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently lift and remove the panel covering the electronics assembly.

Lines.Text: remove the four 1 /2 phillips 01 screws in the circuit board .
gently pull the circuit board off of the rest of the front panel assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 1/2" Phillips #01 screws in the circuit board. Gently pull the circuit board off of the rest of the front panel assembly.

Lines.Text: lift out the internal part of the front panel to access the buttons .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift out the internal part of the front panel to access the buttons.

Lines.Text: if necessary , remove the buttons by grabbing them with two fingers and pulling up and away from the panel .
upon reassembly , ensure buttons are placed in the correct location .

Steps.Text_raw: If necessary, remove the buttons by grabbing them with two fingers and pulling up and away from the panel. Upon reassembly, ensure buttons are placed in the correct location.

Subject: Front Panel

Title: Cuisinart Smart Stick CSB-75 Power Switch Board Replacement

Lines.Text: located on the back of the motor body are three screw covers . to remove the three grey screw covers , use a flat head screwdriver ( 1.0 mm or 1.5 mm ) .
after prying these off , the screws will be exposed .

Steps.Text_raw: Located on the back of the motor body are three screw covers. To remove the three grey screw covers, use  a Flat Head Screwdriver (1.0mm or 1.5mm). After prying these off, the screws will be exposed.

Lines.Text: remove three 13.3 mm phillips ph2 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove  three 13.3 mm  Phillips PH#2 screws.

Lines.Text: pry open cuisinart using a plastic opening tool .
the metal spudger is great when you need serious prying power , but the regular black nylon spudger or a plastic opening tool should be used whenever possible .
make sure to pry open near the clips of the smart stick for easy opening .

Steps.Text_raw: Pry open Cuisinart using a plastic opening tool. The metal spudger is great when you need serious prying power, but the regular black nylon spudger or a plastic opening tool should be used whenever possible. Make sure to pry open near the clips of the smart stick for easy opening.

Lines.Text: unscrew the 4 screws on the inside .
remove 2 13.3 mm phillips ph2 screws .
remove 2 17.5 mm phillips ph2 screws .
unscrewing these screws will isolate the switch board .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the 4 screws on the inside. Remove 2 13.3mm Phillips PH#2 screws. Remove 2 17.5 mm  Phillips PH#2 screws. Unscrewing these screws will isolate the switch board.

Lines.Text: refer to these steps on soldering to replace the switch board in the smart stick .
be careful when soldering ; it gets very hot .

Steps.Text_raw: Refer to these steps on  [https://www.ifixit.com/Wiki/Soldering| Soldering] to replace the switch board in the smart stick. Be careful when soldering; it gets very hot.

Subject: Power Switch Board

pull the base straight towards you to remove it , feeding the wire through the base .

remove the two marked 3 /4 phillips 02 screws in the middle .

Lines.Text: use a plastic opening tool or screwdriver to pry off the back of the fan , starting from the top down .
be aware of two clips inside the fan , towards the bottom third of the fan . if the back appears stuck on certain spots , push inward edges of the front casing around the problematic area .

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 1 /2 phillips 02 screws .
upon doing so , the front panel of the fan can be leaned forward and set down .
the front panel is not detached from the body and cannot be completely removed . do not try to forcefully remove it , as it may cause damage to the electronics .

slide the plastic fan cap off the fan while holding the fan blade to ensure it comes off smoothly .

you may need to rotate the fan blade to find the screw .
upon reassembly , make sure that the notched part of the motor axle ( blue square ) lines up with the screw hole on the fan blade .

Lines.Text: return back to the top of the fan blade . lift the fan blade to a slight angle and gently pull it towards you .
if the fan blade seems stuck , spin the fan blade back and forth while pulling it towards you .

remove 2 17.5 mm phillips ph2 screws .
