Title: Hamilton Beach 49980A Large Heating Component Replacement

Lines.Text: begin by inverting the coffee maker and resting it on a flat surface to make working on the bottom easier .
now use a y0 bit to remove all of the . 46 inch long screws from the bottom .
lift the plate to remove it from the rest of the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by inverting the coffee maker and resting it on a flat surface to make working on the bottom easier. Now use a Y0 bit to remove all of the .46 inch long screws from the bottom. Lift the plate to remove it from the rest of the machine.

Lines.Text: once the bottom plate is removed , use a ph1 bit to remove the . 525 inch long screws holding the motherboard bracket in the main housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the bottom plate is removed, use a PH1 bit to remove the .525 inch long screws holding the motherboard bracket in the main housing.

Lines.Text: using a ph1 bit , remove the two . 425 inch long screws holding down the white power cord bracket . this will give you the slack in the wire that you need to work on the motherboard .
carefully remove the large white connector that has multiple wires attached to it . this is the wire connected to the button functions on the interface of the coffee maker .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a PH1 bit, remove the two .425 inch long screws holding down the white power cord bracket. This will give you the slack in the wire that you need to work on the motherboard. Carefully remove the large white connector that has multiple wires attached to it. This is the wire connected to the button functions on the interface of the coffee maker.

Lines.Text: remove the two . 374 inch long phillips head screws from the brace using a ph1 bit and take the brace off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two .374 inch long Philips head screws from the brace using a PH1 bit and take the brace off.

Lines.Text: remove the second brace .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the second brace.

Lines.Text: to remove the tubes from the large heating component , squeeze the spring clamps and slide them further down the tube .
using pliers makes moving the spring clamps much easier , but it can be done by hand .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the tubes from the large heating component, squeeze the spring clamps and slide them further down the tube. Using pliers makes moving the spring clamps much easier, but it can be done by hand.

Lines.Text: with the spring clamps moved down , slide the tubes from the ends of the large heating component . once the ends are free , separate the component from the hot plate .

Steps.Text_raw: With the spring clamps moved down, slide the tubes from the ends of the large heating component. Once the ends are free, separate the component from the hot plate.

Lines.Text: in order to remove the small housing that covers the motherboard , remove the lone screw with a ph1 bit .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to remove the small housing that covers the motherboard, remove the lone screw with a PH1 bit.

Lines.Text: solder the brown wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard and remove it .
the wire and all following wires will be hot , so use pliers to safely handle them .

Steps.Text_raw: Solder the brown wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard and remove it. The wire and all following wires will be hot, so use pliers to safely handle them.

Lines.Text: solder the white wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard and remove it .
the wire will be hot , be sure to use pliers

Steps.Text_raw: Solder the white wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard and remove it. The wire will be hot, be sure to use pliers

Lines.Text: gently remove the red wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard using pliers . if this connection is too tight to remove by hand , you may heat the solder on the bottom and remove it completely .
when replacing any soldered components , you may want to apply new solder .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently remove the red wire connecting the large heating component to the motherboard using pliers. If this connection is too tight to remove by hand, you may heat the solder on the bottom and remove it completely. When replacing any soldered components, you may want to apply new solder.

Subject: Large Heating Component

Title: AmazonBasics B00Q3KFX8U Drive Gear Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the shredder assembly from the paper scrap bin .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the shredder assembly from the paper scrap bin.

Lines.Text: remove the two 10 mm ph1 screws holding the small black panel in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 10mm PH1 screws holding the small black panel in place.

Lines.Text: remove the six 14 mm ph1 screws holding the bottom cover in place .
remove the cover by lifting straight upwards .
one of the screws will be hidden beneath a warranty sticker . simply push the head of the screwdriver through the sticker to access the screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six 14mm PH1 screws holding the bottom cover in place. Remove the cover by lifting straight upwards. One of the screws will be hidden beneath a warranty sticker. Simply push the head of the screwdriver through the sticker to access the screw.

Lines.Text: remove the blade/motor assembly from the top cover by lifting straight upwards . do not disconnect any wiring just yet .
the blades are sharp . coming into contact with them may result in injury .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the blade/motor assembly from the top cover by lifting straight upwards. Do not disconnect any wiring just yet. The blades are sharp. Coming into contact with them may result in injury.

Lines.Text: remove the five 8 mm ph2 screws from the bracket holding the gears in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the five 8mm PH2 screws from the bracket holding the gears in place.

Lines.Text: use a metal spudger to pry the bracket from the main shredder assembly .
if the bracket is attached too tightly for the spudger , carefully use a metal screwdriver to pry it loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a metal spudger to pry the bracket from the main shredder assembly. If the bracket is attached too tightly for the spudger, carefully use a metal screwdriver to pry it loose.

Lines.Text: remove the two plastic drive gears from the shredder assembly by lifting straight upwards .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two plastic drive gears from the shredder assembly by lifting straight upwards.

Subject: Drive Gear

Steps.Text_raw: Using a the standard Phillips head screwdriver bit, remove the slotted black plastic covering and then unscrew the one 11mm screw holding the power cord in place. Unscrew the four 14 mm screws that are in the deep slots.  This will release the motor from the base.

Lines.Text: caution : the silver blade attached to the motor is very sharp . use a towel or thick cloth to protect your hands for the next step .
using a towel , hold the silver fan still . twist the small black rubber wheel that is attached to the top of the blender base to the right . this will remove the wheel for replacement .

Steps.Text_raw: CAUTION: the silver blade attached to the motor is very sharp.  Use a towel or thick cloth to protect your hands for the next step. Using a towel, hold the silver fan still.  Twist the small black rubber wheel that is attached to the top of the blender base to the right.  This will remove the wheel for replacement.

Lines.Text: use the standard phillips head screw bit to unscrew the screws in the black plastic with the silver circular discs .
using the t9 screw bit , unscrew the four sets of two 11 mm screws located on each of the four sides of the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the standard Phillips head screw bit to unscrew the screws in the black plastic with the silver circular discs. Using the T9 screw bit, unscrew the four sets of two 11 mm screws located on each of the four sides of the motor.

Lines.Text: untwist the small rubber connector to detach the plastic from the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Untwist the small rubber connector to detach the plastic from the motor.

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motor and replace it.

Lines.Text: remove the cover by turning it in the counterclockwise direction .

Lines.Text: remove the bowl scraping mechanism by simply grabbing the middle section and lifting .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bowl scraping mechanism by simply grabbing the middle section and lifting.

Lines.Text: remove the blade mechanism by lifting it off of the blade shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the blade mechanism by lifting it off of the blade shaft.

Lines.Text: place hands on bowl and turn it gently , but firmly , counter-clockwise .

Steps.Text_raw: Place hands on bowl and turn it gently, but firmly, counter-clockwise.

Lines.Text: make sure there is no food or grime along the outside sides of the bowl or the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure there is no food or grime along the outside sides of the bowl or the base.

Lines.Text: bring the device to its upright position .

Steps.Text_raw: Bring the device to its upright position.

Lines.Text: using a metal spudger , pry the switch from the front of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a metal spudger, pry the switch from the front of the device.

Lines.Text: using the metal spudger , remove the four adhesive plastic covers that hide the screws .
these covers are adhered to the screws .

Lines.Text: remove any access glue that is adhered to the screws with the precision tweezers .

Lines.Text: using a jis 1 driver , remove the four 10 mm screws .

Lines.Text: lift the drive shaft .

Lines.Text: reach in and remove the set of 3 gears .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach in and remove the set of 3 gears.

Lines.Text: remove the four 8 mm jis 1 screws that are revealed after removing the set of gears .
there will be lubricant on the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 8 mm JIS #1 screws that are revealed after removing the set of gears. There will be lubricant on the screws.

Lines.Text: flip your device over so the bottom is visible .

Lines.Text: using a jis 1 screwdriver , remove each of the four suction cups that are attached to the bottom of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a JIS #1 screwdriver, remove each of the four suction cups that are attached to the bottom of the device.

Lines.Text: using a jis 1 screwdriver , remove the four 12 mm screws on the bottom .
the screws are recessed about 3 mm inside of the device and may not be very visible .

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 4 mm screws underneath the on/off switch with a jis 1 screwdriver .

Lines.Text: remove the bottom of the food processor by gently but firmly pulling it away from the silver section .

Lines.Text: using a jis 1 screwdriver , remove the three screws on the white plastic piece inside the device , on the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a JIS # 1 screwdriver, remove the three screws on the white plastic piece inside the device, on the side.

Lines.Text: remove the white piece , carefully sliding wires on the sides through the small gaps .
be careful not to dislodge the spring on the cylindrical white piece next to it .

Lines.Text: begin by inverting the coffee maker and resting it on a flat surface to make working on the bottom easier .
now use a y0 bit to remove all of the . 46 inch long screws from the bottom .
lift the plate to remove it from the rest of the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin by inverting the coffee maker and resting it on a flat surface to make working on the bottom easier. Now use a Y0 bit to remove all of the .46 inch long screws from the bottom. Lift the plate to remove it from the rest of the machine.

Lines.Text: once the bottom plate is removed , use a ph1 bit to remove the . 525 inch long screws holding the motherboard bracket in the main housing .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the bottom plate is removed, use a PH1 bit to remove the .525 inch long screws holding the motherboard bracket in the main housing.

Lines.Text: using a ph1 bit , remove the two . 425 inch long screws holding down the white power cord bracket . this will give you the slack in the wire that you need to work on the motherboard .
carefully remove the large white connector that has multiple wires attached to it . this is the wire connected to the button functions on the interface of the coffee maker .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a PH1 bit, remove the two .425 inch long screws holding down the white power cord bracket. This will give you the slack in the wire that you need to work on the motherboard. Carefully remove the large white connector that has multiple wires attached to it. This is the wire connected to the button functions on the interface of the coffee maker.

Lines.Text: after removing the motherboard , follow the powercord down to where it splits . it will be connected to the motherboard in two places with solder . locate these two points .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the motherboard, follow the powercord down to where it splits. It will be connected to the motherboard in two places with solder. Locate these two points.

Lines.Text: using a soldering iron , heat up one soldered point that is holding the power cord in place . while the solder is hot , carefully pull the cord out of the connection .
the wire will be hot . you may want to use pliers to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a soldering iron, heat up one soldered point that is holding the power cord in place. While the solder is hot, carefully pull the cord out of the connection. The wire will be hot. You may want to use pliers to remove it.

Lines.Text: locate the second half of the power cord . on the underside of the motherboard , heat up the soldered connection and remove the wire while the solder is hot .
when replacing any soldered components , you may want to apply new solder .

using a ph1 bit , remove the three . 77 inch long screws with the washers to free the component from the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: After separating the main housing of the Hamilton Beach 49980A, locate the small heating unit which will be standing vertically on two tubes. Using a PH1 bit, remove the three .77 inch long screws with the washers to free the component from the machine.

Lines.Text: locate the top two spring clamps on the tube attached to the small heating unit . pinch these clips while pulling down to release the tube from the heating unit . pliers will make this task easier .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the top two spring clamps on the tube attached to the small heating unit. Pinch these clips while pulling down to release the tube from the heating unit. Pliers will make this task easier.

Lines.Text: after pushing the clips down , pull the tube from the heating unit . this may be difficult , so use a spudger to pry the tube off as you pull the unit up .

Steps.Text_raw: After pushing the clips down, pull the tube from the heating unit. This may be difficult, so use a spudger to pry the tube off as you pull the unit up.

Lines.Text: after removing the heating unit from the tube , the heating unit should come free . it will still be attached to the motherboard by three wires . they will be black , blue , and white .

Steps.Text_raw: After removing the heating unit from the tube, the heating unit should come free. It will still be attached to the motherboard by three wires. They will be black, blue, and white.

Lines.Text: in order to remove the small housing that covers the motherboard , remove the lone screw with a ph1 bit . after this the plastic cover should easily snap off .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to remove the small housing that covers the motherboard, remove the lone screw with a PH1 bit. After this the plastic cover should easily snap off.

Lines.Text: first , remove the blue wire from the motherboard . this wire will have a black connector on the end connecting to the motherboard . it is found here . heat up the solder on the bottom of the circuit board and remove the wire from its connection .
the wire will be hot . you may want to use pliers to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: First, remove the blue wire from the motherboard. This wire will have a black connector on the end connecting to the motherboard. It is found here. Heat up the solder on the bottom of the circuit board and remove the wire from its connection. The wire will be hot. You may want to use pliers to remove it.

Lines.Text: next , on the underside of the motherboard heat up the soldered connection of the white wire . this wire is located in the top corner .
both heating component's white wires are located next to each other . make sure you remove the correct wire for your heater .

Steps.Text_raw: Next, on the underside of the motherboard heat up the soldered connection of the white wire. This wire is located in the top corner. Both heating component's white wires are located next to each other. make sure you remove the correct wire for your heater.

Lines.Text: lastly , on the bottom of the motherboard heat up the soldered connection for the black wire . while the solder is melted , remove the wire from the connection .
when replacing any soldered components , you may want to apply new solder .

Steps.Text_raw: Lastly, on the bottom of the motherboard heat up the soldered connection for the black wire. While the solder is melted, remove the wire from the connection. When replacing any soldered components, you may want to apply new solder.

attention ! the valve has a direction . the sense of the flew is towards the black point . the double raccord must be there !

Title: BCG800XL Grinder Jamming due to Worn Impeller

Toolbox.Name: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: unplug your grinder before completing this repair to avoid electric shock .
remove the hopper and take the upper burrs out . empty out any coffee grounds ( an air gun or vacuum helps ) and then inspect the impeller blades .
if the impeller can fit through the hole ( ie : be removed just by taking out the lower burr ) then it definitely needs replacement .
a good impeller should not be removable without dis-assembly and the tips of the impeller blades should not be visible .

if your impeller is made of '''stainless steel''' rather than plastic you likely have a newer model with significant design changes ( eg : bcg8 '''20 ''' ) . stainless steel should not wear out and so your problem is elsewhere .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your grinder before completing this repair to avoid electric shock. Remove the hopper and take the upper burrs out. Empty out any coffee grounds (An air gun or vacuum helps) and then inspect the impeller blades. If the impeller can fit through the hole (ie: be removed just by taking out the lower burr) then it definitely needs replacement. A good impeller should not be removable without dis-assembly and the tips of the impeller blades should not be visible. If your impeller is made of '''stainless steel''' rather than plastic you likely have a newer model with significant design changes (eg: BCG8'''20'''). Stainless steel should not wear out and so your problem is elsewhere.

Lines.Text: i modeled and 3 d printed this replacement part it several times at the local library . i've made the final design available for printing at www . shapeways . com ( see link below ) . of course , you can also model your own design if you wish to spend the time .
bcg800 xl impeller shop
a video with some background on the shapeways part .

after nearly 2 years of roughly 3-double shots per day ( 54 grams per day ) , i did a full teardown to see how the design was holding up . i am very happy with the results , and you can see the details here .

Steps.Text_raw: I modeled and 3D printed this replacement part it several times at the local library. I've made the final design available for printing at www.shapeways.com (See link below). Of course, you can also model your own design if you wish to spend the time. [https://www.shapeways.com/product/NASLAGCCP/breville-coffee-grinder-impeller-upgrade|Shapeways BCG800XL Impeller Shop] [https://youtu.be/zB5F9ha1-zs|Here's a video] with some background on the Shapeways part. After nearly 2 years of roughly 3-double shots per day (~54 grams per day) , I did a full teardown to see how the design was holding up. I am very happy with the results, and you can see the [https://photos.app.goo.gl/868a5ReyM2XAyjZq8|full details here].
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: you'll need either a 10 mm socket with ratchet or a 10 mm wrench .
a 2 phillips screwdriver with '''8 inches of shaft or longer''' , and preferably with magnetic tip .
you can rub a magnet against the tip to temporarily magnetize it .
the sandpaper and file are only necessary if the 3 d printed impeller isn't a perfect fit .

Steps.Text_raw: You'll need either a 10mm socket with ratchet or a 10mm wrench. A #2 Phillips screwdriver with '''8 inches of shaft or longer''', and preferably with magnetic tip. You can rub a magnet against the tip to temporarily magnetize it. The sandpaper and file are only necessary if the 3D printed impeller isn't a perfect fit.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: remove the hopper and upper burrs .
use a 10 mm socket to remove the nut for the lower burrs .
the nut for the lower burrs is reverse threaded . rotate '''clockwise''' to loosen .
turn the grind-adjustment knob to the finest setting .
remember what order in which the washers were removed for proper reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the hopper and upper burrs. Use a 10mm socket to remove the nut for the lower burrs. The nut for the lower burrs is reverse threaded. Rotate '''clockwise''' to loosen. Turn the grind-adjustment knob to the finest setting. Remember what order in which the washers were removed for proper reassembly.

Lines.Text: unwrap the power cord and remove the 4 screws from the base .
remove the four rubber pads
slide the power cord through the hole in the base while lifting the base away from the grinder .

Steps.Text_raw: Unwrap the power cord and remove the 4 screws from the base. Remove the four rubber pads Slide the power cord through the hole in the base while lifting the base away from the grinder.

Lines.Text: use the long phillips 2 driver to remove the 4 screws holding the top in place .
flip the grinder over and slowly lift away the top .
the top is still attached to a wire so the lid will hang off to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the long Phillips #2 driver to remove the 4 screws holding the top in place. Flip the grinder over and slowly lift away the top. The top is still attached to a wire so the lid will hang off to the side.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: remove the two screws from the top of the display .
lift the display up and out of the frame .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws from the top of the display. Lift the display up and out of the frame.

Lines.Text: be sure the grind knob is turned to the finest setting .

it's critical that the alignment be preserved when removing the gear assembly . the small gear in the picture is an encoder . its purpose is to track the position of the grind adjustment level so it can be displayed on the digital readout . if it gets out of alignment the display will end up reading wrong .
use a permanent marker to make alignment marks on the three parts of the gear assembly . the marks should line up during reassembly .
there are 4 plastic tabs radially holding the big white gear assembly in place . i used both hands , placing my finger tips under each side of the big gear and pulled straight up to remove it .
if pulling straight up isn't working , try curling your fingers under just one side of the white gear , and prying upwards until that side pops free a little . then do the other side .

Steps.Text_raw: Be sure the grind knob is turned to the finest setting. It's critical that the alignment be preserved when removing the gear assembly.  The small gear in the picture is an encoder. Its purpose is to track the position of the grind adjustment level so it can be displayed on the digital readout. If it gets out of alignment the display will end up reading wrong. Use a permanent marker to make alignment marks on the three parts of the gear assembly. The marks should line up during reassembly. There are 4 plastic tabs radially holding the big white gear assembly in place. I used both hands, placing my finger tips under each side of the big gear and pulled straight up to remove it. If pulling straight up isn't working, try curling your fingers under just one side of the white gear, and prying upwards until that side pops free a little. Then do the other side.

Lines.Text: lift out the old impeller making sure the steel washer underneath the impeller doesn't fall out .

discard the fibrous felt washer below the metal washer . this is no longer needed as the new impeller design hugs the bushing pedestal more closely and does a good enough job keeping grounds away from the bushing anyway .
optional modding tip : replace the metal washer with a washer that's about 0.1 to 0.2 mm thicker if you'd like your grinder to grind even finer than it did before .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift out the old impeller making sure the steel washer underneath the impeller doesn't fall out. Discard the fibrous felt washer below the metal washer. This is no longer needed as the new impeller design hugs the bushing pedestal more closely and does a good enough job keeping grounds away from the bushing anyway. Optional Modding Tip: Replace the metal washer with a washer that's about 0.1 to 0.2 mm thicker if you'd like your grinder to grind even finer than it did before.

Lines.Text: while it's accessible , use compressed air or toothpick to clean out the exit chute so it's free of any compacted coffee .
give your new replacement impeller a quick rinse and pat down with a towel to prevent static charge during first grinding .

Steps.Text_raw: While it's accessible, use compressed air or toothpick to clean out the exit chute so it's free of any compacted coffee. Give your new replacement impeller a quick rinse and pat down with a towel to prevent static charge during first grinding.

Lines.Text: it is important for the 3 d printed part to fit properly . tolerances of the design error on the tight side .
check that the burr drive pegs fit the holes of the conical burrs . if its too tight , apply a small amount of sanding to the impeller and youll be in good shape .
do not sand the flat part of the center hole . only sand the curved part slightly if needed . the flat part takes the most stress from the drive shaft .
the gap here should be small with the new part . if it's too tight , you can sand the edges slightly .
a video of the fit-up with the shapeways printed part .

Steps.Text_raw: It is important for the 3D printed part to fit properly. Tolerances of the design error on the tight side. Check that the burr drive pegs fit the holes of the conical burrs.  If it’s too tight, apply a small amount of sanding to the impeller and you’ll be in good shape. Do not sand the flat part of the center hole. Only sand the curved part slightly if needed. The flat part takes the most stress from the drive shaft. The gap here should be small with the new part. If it's too tight, you can sand the edges slightly. [https://youtu.be/Q8l3dkAJJfA|Here's a video] of the fit-up with the Shapeways printed part.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: before reassembly , check that the conical lower burr and impeller fit well onto the driveshaft with the steel washer underneath . the lip on the drive shaft should be within about 0.5 mm of the top surface of the conical burr . when the nut is tightened it will squish to about flush .
the lip on the drive shaft should be within about 0.5 mm of the top surface of the conical burr . when the nut is tightened it will squish to about flush .
if the burr is too high above the lip on the shaft ( higher than in the pic ) , try putting the nut+washer on , tightening hard , and then taking it back off .
if the lower burr is still sitting too high on the shaft , take a quick detour to 20 and then come back .

Steps.Text_raw: Before reassembly, check that the conical lower burr and impeller fit well onto the driveshaft with the steel washer underneath. The lip on the drive shaft should be within about 0.5mm of the top surface of the conical burr. When the nut is tightened it will squish to about flush. The lip on the drive shaft should be within about 0.5mm of the top surface of the conical burr. When the nut is tightened it will squish to about flush. If the burr is too high above the lip on the shaft (higher than in the pic), try putting the nut+washer on, tightening hard, and then taking it back off. If the lower burr is still sitting too high on the shaft, take a quick detour to [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/BCG800XL+Grinder+Jamming+due+to+Worn+Impeller/62905#s134180|Step 20 ] and then come back.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: with the following pieces aligned carefully set the gear assembly into place :
avoid rotating these pieces to maintain alignment .
as you set the assembly into place , make sure the two stop-screws are on the left side of the black plastic stop .
align the large peg with the wide slot .
align and the small peg with the small slot .
press down on the gear assembly to snap it into place .
once in place , rotate the coarseness knob through the full range to make sure it's all working .
watch the reinstallation video for clarification .

Steps.Text_raw: With the following pieces aligned carefully set the gear assembly into place: Avoid rotating these pieces to maintain alignment. As you set the assembly into place, make sure the two stop-screws are on the left side of the black plastic stop. Align the large peg with the wide slot. Align and the small peg with the small slot. Press down on the gear assembly to snap it into place. Once in place, rotate the coarseness knob through the full range to make sure it's all working. Watch the reinstallation video [https://youtu.be/1lL8BInrki8?t=15m41s|here] for clarification.

Lines.Text: advanced modding tip : if you want greater grind-control range , you can back out the two screws in the big gear in the photo . you will then be able to adjust the grind much beyond the normal range . caveats : go too fine and the grounds become like paste and it will certainly jam . also , you must not adjust too fine or the burrs will hit !
note : the encoder driven by the little gear also has a hard stop built into it . you will still run into this stop if you keep turning the adjustment knob .

disclaimer : this step is completely optional . it is up to you and ultimately your responsibility if you choose to do it . understand the risks of jamming and burrs hitting . also be aware of the possibility that others may use your grinder and need to be informed of the modification . you do this unnecessary and optional step at your own risk .

Steps.Text_raw: Advanced Modding Tip: If you want greater grind-control range, you can back out the two screws in the big gear in the photo. You will then be able to adjust the grind much beyond the normal range. Caveats: Go too fine and the grounds become like paste and it will certainly jam. Also, you must not adjust too fine or the burrs will hit! Note: The encoder driven by the little gear also has a hard stop built into it. You will still run into this stop if you keep turning the adjustment knob. DISCLAIMER: This step is completely optional. It is up to you and ultimately your responsibility if you choose to do it. Understand the risks of jamming and burrs hitting. Also be aware of the possibility that others may use your grinder and need to be informed of the modification. You do this unnecessary and optional step at your own risk.

Lines.Text: place the display back into the frame and screw in the two screws that hold it in place .
put the conical burr in place making sure it sets on the pegs of the impeller properly .
place the washers on while maintaining their original order .
tighten the '''reverse threaded''' 10 mm nut .

tighten the nut as hard as you can . the impeller , being plastic , has a small amount of springiness to it and must be squashed hard so that the height of the lower burr does not vary . if you find that the burrs are too close after you're all done , then this is the reason . tighten until the motor begins to move , and then give it an extra wack .
check the grind knob to be sure it has full range of motion .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the display back into the frame and screw in the two screws that hold it in place. Put the conical burr in place making sure it sets on the pegs of the impeller properly. Place the washers on while maintaining their original order. Tighten the '''reverse threaded''' 10mm nut. Tighten the nut as hard as you can. The impeller, being plastic, has a small amount of springiness to it and must be squashed hard so that the height of the lower burr does not vary. If you find that the burrs are too close after you're all done, then this is the reason. Tighten until the motor begins to move, and then give it an extra wack. Check the grind knob to be sure it has full range of motion.

Lines.Text: put the plastic top back on .
flip the grinder over and use the long phillips 2 screwdriver to reinstall the 4 screws that hold the top in place .
if the screwdriver is not already magnetized , it'll be worth rubbing a magnet on it to do so prior to this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the plastic top back on. Flip the grinder over and use the long Phillips #2 screwdriver to reinstall the 4 screws that hold the top in place. If the screwdriver is not already magnetized, it'll be worth rubbing a magnet on it to do so prior to this step.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: put the four rubber feet back in place .
screw back in the four base screws .
re-wrap the cord .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the four rubber feet back in place. Screw back in the four base screws. Re-wrap the cord.

Lines.Text: put the upper burr back on and reinstall the hopper ( without coffee beans yet ) .
run the ( empty ) grinder briefly to make sure it all sounds ok . try both coarse and fine grind settings .
if all sounds well , add some coffee to the hopper . dial in the grind and try it out ! if something seems off , see the troubleshooting steps below or refer to the troubleshooting page
there is a bit of a break-in period the first week where the new impeller gets a protective coffee coating . it is recommended using a medium or light roast during this time .
congrats on using 3 d printing to repair something ! enjoy your coffee ! godspeed ! deus tecum .

if you thought this guide was thorough , you should see our primary work . steadymouse llc helps folks with parkinson's disease use their mouse again . come check us out anytime at and perhaps help us spread awareness . cheers !

Steps.Text_raw: Put the upper burr back on and reinstall the hopper (without coffee beans yet). Run the (empty) grinder briefly to make sure it all sounds OK. Try both coarse and fine grind settings. If all sounds well, add some coffee to the hopper. Dial in the grind and try it out! If something seems off, see the troubleshooting steps below or refer to the troubleshooting page [https://www.ifixit.com/Wiki/Breville_BCG800XL_Smart_Grinder_Troubleshooting?revisionid=HEAD|here.] There is a bit of a break-in period the first week where the new impeller gets a protective coffee coating. It is recommended using a medium or light roast during this time. Congrats on using 3D printing to repair something! Enjoy your coffee! Godspeed! Deus tecum. Come check us out anytime at https://www.steadymouse.com and perhaps help us spread awareness. Cheers!

Lines.Text: if you encounter ground coffee escaping the chute and getting on the counter , it may mean your coffee is too dry , humidity is too low ( static charge ) , or even that the grinder chute is too clean .
to fix this , try placing a tiny dab of cooking oil on your finger and rubbing it high up inside of the coffee chute . this will allow a fine layer of grounds to coat the walls of the chute .
the added friction of the grounds on the wall of the chute should slow the velocity of the grounds down enough that the overspray stops .
fyi : this whole step happens naturally with oily coffee beans , but takes a little longer than with the vegetable oil trick .
also for static charge issues , see here :

Steps.Text_raw: If you encounter ground coffee escaping the chute and getting on the counter, it may mean your coffee is too dry, humidity is too low (static charge), or even that the grinder chute is too clean. To fix this, try placing a tiny dab of cooking oil on your finger and rubbing it high up inside of the coffee chute. This will allow a fine layer of grounds to coat the walls of the chute. The added friction of the grounds on the wall of the chute should slow the velocity of the grounds down enough that the overspray stops. FYI: This whole step happens naturally with oily coffee beans, but takes a little longer than with the vegetable oil trick. Also for static charge issues, see here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0Dh1W40ILY

Lines.Text: too close ( ie : grinding too fine ) : if the burrs are too close , or even touching ( but centered ) , the nut on the lower burr may not be tight enough . with the ratchet and 10 mm socket , give it a quick counter-clockwise jerk . if that fails , recheck your fit-up against the second photo to make sure the lower conical burr is the proper height .

if it's clear that the lower burr is sitting too high on the impeller , see the 3 rd picture and sand the area highlighted in red . while doing this , periodically install and re-check the lower burr height until it matches photo 2. careful not to sand off too much as it's easy to remove thickness but hard to add it back .

too far : if the burrs are too far apart such that the grind isn't fine enough , it could be that the steel washer underneath the impeller got left out . see step 9. additionally , you can try removing one of the two washers ++above++ the lower burr and not tightening the nut as much . there's also a shim kit offered by breville if you contact them .

lastly , both of the above issues can happen if the alignment in step 12 got shifted . if so , you may need to pop-off and adjust the rotation of the upper-burr holder assembly . this is tricky , but doable . i suggest marking the existing alignment with permanent marker before experimenting .

Steps.Text_raw: TOO CLOSE (ie: grinding too fine): If the burrs are too close, or even touching (but centered), the nut on the lower burr may not be tight enough. With the ratchet and 10mm socket, give it a quick counter-clockwise jerk. If that fails, recheck your fit-up against the second photo to make sure the lower conical burr is the proper height. If it's clear that the lower burr is sitting too high on the impeller, see the 3rd picture and sand the area highlighted in RED. While doing this, periodically install and re-check the lower burr height until it matches photo #2. Careful not to sand off too much as it's easy to remove thickness but hard to add it back. TOO FAR: If the burrs are too far apart such that the grind isn't fine enough, it could be that the steel washer underneath the impeller got left out. See step #9. Additionally, you can try removing *one* of the two washers ++above++ the lower burr and not tightening the nut as much. There's also a shim kit offered by Breville if you contact them. Lastly, both of the above issues can happen if the alignment in "Step 12" got shifted. If so, you may need to pop-off and adjust the rotation of the upper-burr holder assembly. This is tricky, but doable. I suggest marking the existing alignment with permanent marker before experimenting.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: if it sounds horrible when running ( even without coffee beans ) like this : then it's probably either a damaged torque limiter or a stripped drive gear . fyi : the situation in the video was the aftermath of a rock getting jammed in the burrs .

i don't cover tear down all the way to the gear box . step 9 is as close as i go . in the photo though there are 4 washer screws and 2 screws on the encoder . if you remove those you'll be well on your way to investigating the gear box .

the options to fix either of these are not as well explored , so if there is damage here and you fix it successfully , post a comment below . fyi : breville has a repair service for about 90 and that may still be the best option in this situation .
the torque limiter may be fixable by stretching each of the radially-distributed springs about 2 mm each . this should increase the torque at which it slips .

the drive gear on the right has a potential source found by a user below ( thanks dave gordon ! ) : this is not yet verified to work , but the price is reasonable , so if you try it out and it works , post below so we can know !

Steps.Text_raw: If it sounds horrible when running (even without coffee beans) like this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PcQcbHIPqx8 then it's probably either a damaged torque limiter or a stripped drive gear. FYI: The situation in the video was the aftermath of a rock getting jammed in the burrs. I don't cover tear down all the way to the gear box. Step #9 is as close as I go. In the photo though there are 4 washer screws and 2 screws on the encoder. If you remove those you'll be well on your way to investigating the gear box. The options to fix either of these are not as well explored, so if there is damage here and you fix it successfully, post a comment below. FYI: Breville has a repair service for about $90 and that may still be the best option in this situation. The torque limiter may be "fixable" by stretching each of the radially-distributed springs about 2mm each. This should increase the torque at which it slips. The drive gear on the right has a potential source found by a user below (Thanks Dave Gordon!): http://www.forumappliances.com/breville-main-gear-for-bcg800-820-smart-grinder/ This is not yet verified to work, but the price is reasonable, so if you try it out and it works, post below so we can know!
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 8 inches or more

Lines.Text: occasionally a user reports statically charged coffee grounds coming out that seems to defy the laws of gravity . they float up into the air and cling to things , making a mess !

often it will stop on its own after the impeller gets a few days of use . it's a bit of a mystery however , i believe the issue arises mainly in dry climates , with certain beans in combination with the plastic impeller .
to fix the issue , simply give your impeller a scrub and rinse in the sink and then pat it down with a towel until dry .

this slight bit of moisture seems to take care of static issues permanently . i suspect it gets us by until the impeller builds up a natural coat of coffee , which also serves to prevent static charge .
see also :

Steps.Text_raw: Occasionally a user reports statically charged coffee grounds coming out that seems to defy the laws of gravity. They float up into the air and cling to things, making a mess! Often it will stop on its own after the impeller gets a few days of use. It's a bit of a mystery however, I believe the issue arises mainly in dry climates, with certain beans in combination with the plastic impeller. To fix the issue, simply give your impeller a scrub and rinse in the sink and then pat it down with a towel until dry. This slight bit of moisture seems to take care of static issues permanently. I suspect it gets us by until the impeller builds up a natural coat of coffee, which also serves to prevent static charge. See also: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0Dh1W40ILY

Lines.Text: some beans , especially the roasted so dark it's nearly charcoal variety can be way too oily . the characteristic is that rather than grind to a powder it turns to paste in the lower chamber . this is obviously bad , because it then comes out in clumps or not at all .
clumpy grounds , for some reason tend to overshoot the portafilter and make a mess . i suspect this is because the large clump size has more mass , and comes out of the chute with too much momentum .
if you pull the upper burr , and see what looks like a nice smooth black surface where the impeller would normally be , then that's your sign .
the fix : clean the lower chamber , or at least break up the cake of grounds , and switch to a less oily roast .

Steps.Text_raw: Some beans, especially the "roasted so dark it's nearly charcoal" variety can be way too oily. The characteristic is that rather than grind to a powder it turns to "paste" in the lower chamber. This is obviously bad, because it then comes out in clumps or not at all. Clumpy grounds, for some reason tend to overshoot the portafilter and make a mess. I suspect this is because the large clump size has more mass, and comes out of the chute with too much momentum. If you pull the upper burr, and see what looks like a nice smooth black surface where the impeller would normally be, then that's your sign. The Fix: Clean the lower chamber, or at least break up the cake of grounds, and switch to a less oily roast.

Subject: BCG800XL Impeller

Steps.Text_raw: Slide back black plastic covers and cut the two wires connected to the LED with a pair of scissors. The LED bulb should now be free to remove. '''careful ! ''' those 5 wispy little wires break pretty easily . i ended up having to resolder all of them , which was annoying . i'm almost tempted to recommend just breaking them off at the beginning and then resoldering them at the end just so you're sure they're attached well .

Steps.Text_raw: Just undo the two screws and you're in. '''Careful!''' Those 5 wispy little wires break pretty easily. I ended up having to resolder ALL of them, which was annoying. I'm almost tempted to recommend just breaking them off at the beginning and then resoldering them at the end just so you're sure they're attached well.

Lines.Text: i bought a pack of four 9.5 mm tact switches at radio shack ( which i had no idea still existed or sold electronic parts ) .

'''important ! ''' make sure if you don't buy the right size switch that you cut your switch down to the right size . i didn't , and when i glued the facepiece back on at the end , it held down the power switch and i had to take it off and sand the switch down .
also , make sure you put a ''tiny bit'' of solder on all of the faces ( 8 total faces for four connections ) before you try to solder them together . it'll be a lot easier to bond them . afterward .

Steps.Text_raw: I bought a pack of four 9.5mm tact switches at radio shack (which I had no idea still existed or sold electronic parts). '''Important!''' Make sure if you don't buy the right size switch that you cut your switch down to the right size. I didn't, and when I glued the facepiece back on at the end, it held down the power switch and I had to take it off and sand the switch down. Also,  make sure you put a ''tiny bit'' of solder on all of the faces (8 total faces for four connections) before you try to solder them together. It'll be a lot easier to bond them. Afterward.

Lines.Text: as i said before , these all broke off when i was doing this , so i had to resolder them .
either way , make sure they're still well-connected .

Title: Keurig B60 Water Gasket Replacement

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the Water Reservoir Cap and the Water Reservoir from the brewer by simply pulling up and out

Lines.Text: remove the three 9.5 mm phillips 1 screws that secure the small circular screen to the bottom of the water reservoir .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 9.5 mm Phillips #1 screws that secure the small circular screen to the bottom of the water reservoir.

Lines.Text: this circular screen has a rubber o-ring around the base . use the plastic opening tool to pry off the rubber seal . replace with undamaged seal .

Steps.Text_raw: This circular screen has a rubber "O"-ring around the base.  Use the plastic opening tool to pry off the rubber seal.  Replace with undamaged seal.

Lines.Text: lift the handle

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the handle

Lines.Text: locate and remove the two 9.5 mm torx t15 screws on both sides of the handle .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the two 9.5 mm Torx T15 screws on both sides of the handle.

Lines.Text: remove the broken handle and replace with the new one

Lines.Text: locate and remove the two 9.5 mm phillips 1 screws .
remove the plastic ring around the k-cup pack holder

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the two 9.5 mm Phillips #1 screws. Remove the plastic ring around the K-Cup Pack Holder

Lines.Text: remove the two 9.5 mm phillips 1 screws on the underside of the lid .

puncture needle should now be exposed

Title: KitchenAid Professional 600 Bevel Gear Replacement

Lines.Text: take out the screw which holds on the silver band using a phillips 2 screwdriver .
remove the silver band .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the screw which holds on the silver band using a Phillips #2 screwdriver. Remove the silver band.

Lines.Text: remove the four phillips 2 screws located around the mixer where the band was removed .
this picture only shows two of the screw that you need to remove . the other two are on the exact opposite side of the mixer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Phillips #2 screws located around the mixer where the band was removed. This picture only shows two of the screw that you need to remove. The other two are on the exact opposite side of the mixer.

Lines.Text: remove the top of the mixer to reveal the inner parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the top of the mixer to reveal the inner parts.

Lines.Text: remove the 4 phillips 2 screws connecting the black housing cover to the device .
only one of the screws is seen in the picture . the other three are also located around the black housing cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 4 Phillips #2 screws connecting the black housing cover to the device. Only one of the screws is seen in the picture. The other three are also located around the black housing cover.

Lines.Text: take off the black housing cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Take off the black housing cover.

Lines.Text: to remove the bevel gear , remove the snap ring wrapped around the base of the gear using snap ring pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the Bevel Gear, remove the snap ring wrapped around the base of the gear using Snap Ring pliers.

Lines.Text: slide the bevel gear off .
remember to apply food safe grease onto your new replacement part before assembling the device back together .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the Bevel Gear off. Remember to apply food safe grease onto your new replacement part  before assembling the device back together.

Title: Bosch 81466 disassembly

Lines.Text: '''disconnect the vacuum cleaner from the mains ! the repair works on open contacts - risk of electric shock ! '''
pull out cable until stop
remove hoses , bags , filters on the bag , filter on the rear
clean filter , if necessary wash out and lay to dry
dust bag flap can be disengaged : caution that the noses do not break off ! the left notch ( seen from hose to the rear ) is bevelled so that it slips better when re-engaged .

Steps.Text_raw: '''Disconnect the vacuum cleaner from the mains! The repair works on open contacts - risk of electric shock!''' Pull out cable until stop Remove hoses, bags, filters on the bag, filter on the rear Clean filter, if necessary wash out and lay to dry Dust bag flap can be disengaged: Caution that the noses do not break off! The left notch (seen from hose to the rear) is bevelled so that it slips better when re-engaged.

Lines.Text: loosen and remove four torx-15 screws ( 2 on the dust bag , 2 on the back under the outlet filter ) ( leave the two torx-15 s in the handle )

now it gets fiddly : the red shell should be removed as vertically as possible . but behind it hangs quite firmly in the impact protection plastic edge . the engine with a black holder and the attached cable guide should stay in there at the bottom !
the black plastic edge holds just behind the bag filter wall the black holder + attached cable management .
therefore , the two torx-15 on the handle out and carefully loosen handle top shell - be careful , soft plastic shock protection edge !
remove the black holder + the attached cable guide vertically - caution : the holder holds the motor and with a claw the electronics !

'''attention : ''' cruise control works on heavily silicone-lubricated worm shaft , white slide can be compared . taken off the board . carefully push the worm shaft out of the trimmer and lift it out from its side so that it does not fall into the dust .

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen and remove four TORX-15 screws (2 on the dust bag, 2 on the back under the outlet filter) (leave the two TORX-15s in the handle) Now it gets fiddly: the red shell should be removed as vertically as possible. But behind it hangs quite firmly in the impact protection plastic edge. The engine with a black holder and the attached cable guide should stay in there at the bottom! The black plastic edge holds just behind the bag filter wall the black holder + attached cable management. Therefore, the two TORX-15 on the handle out and carefully loosen handle top shell - be careful, soft plastic shock protection edge! Remove the black holder + the attached cable guide vertically - Caution: The holder holds the motor and with a claw the electronics! '''Attention:''' Cruise control works on heavily silicone-lubricated worm shaft, white slide can be compared. taken off the board. Carefully push the worm shaft out of the trimmer and lift it out from its side so that it does not fall into the dust.

Lines.Text: now the motor can be taken out vertically together with electronics .
'''caution : ''' the engine has a thick rubber seal on the side of the bag , which is only laid on top .

'''caution : '''the engine has a rubber mold block on the other side , which holds the engine in the middle of the plastic formwork . be sure to remember the radial position of the motor so that the block can be replaced later .

'''attention : ''' electronics is plugged with two shoes on cable drum pins . to reinstall , pay attention to how the red-brown level gauge ( working with spring ) and triac are seated on the air duct .
'''attention : ''' do not damage the glow lamp !
fleece underneath the engine : note the position , remove and wash with liquid soap and plenty of water , then squeeze vigorously and reinsert .

Steps.Text_raw: Now the motor can be taken out vertically together with electronics. '''Caution:''' The engine has a thick rubber seal on the side of the bag, which is only laid on top. '''Caution: '''The engine has a rubber mold block on the other side, which holds the engine in the middle of the plastic formwork. Be sure to remember the radial position of the motor so that the block can be replaced later. '''Attention:''' Electronics is plugged with two shoes on cable drum pins. To reinstall, pay attention to how the red-brown level gauge (working with spring) and triac are seated on the air duct. '''Attention:''' Do not damage the glow lamp! Fleece underneath the engine: note the position, remove and wash with liquid soap and plenty of water, then squeeze vigorously and reinsert.

Lines.Text: black plastic formwork around the engine is engaged with two side tabs . carefully fold up and separate , remembering cable routing and fleece layer !
remove fleece and wash with liquid soap and plenty of water , then squeeze vigorously .
remove dirt from the suction hole and the impeller , ditto in the motor housing .
'''caution : ''' do not damage the cable and the electrical system ! coals check what the bent brass claw does not need to be bent back .
instead , the immersion depth of the coals can be determined with a stable , thin wire , and the coal length can be estimated from this .

Steps.Text_raw: Black plastic formwork around the engine is engaged with two side tabs. Carefully fold up and separate, remembering cable routing and fleece layer! Remove fleece and wash with liquid soap and plenty of water, then squeeze vigorously. Remove dirt from the suction hole and the impeller, ditto in the motor housing. '''Caution:''' Do not damage the cable and the electrical system! Coals check what the bent brass claw does not need to be bent back. Instead, the immersion depth of the coals can be determined with a stable, thin wire, and the coal length can be estimated from this.

Lines.Text: assembly : motor with fleece and motor shell provided , lead cable again through the slot .
engage the rubber block on the engine plates and in the engine shell again for centering .
nsert motor with rubber ring , observe cable routing on the slider , as well as the position of the board ( pressure sensor / triac , glow lamp , vertical guide on motor side ) .
insert worm shaft with long end into trimmer , then snap in other side . grease the threaded edge with silicone . trimmer on left stop . push the white slide from the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Assembly: Motor with fleece and motor shell provided, lead cable again through the slot. Engage the rubber block on the engine plates and in the engine shell again for centering. nsert motor with rubber ring, observe cable routing on the slider, as well as the position of the board (pressure sensor / TRIAC, glow lamp, vertical guide on motor side). Insert worm shaft with long end into trimmer, then snap in other side. Grease the threaded edge with silicone. Trimmer on left stop. Push the white slide from the side.

Lines.Text: fit the handle top and fix the motor , screw tight . insert impact protection edge on lower part .
position cruise control and slide , position red upper cover vertically .
when doing so , position the rear edge inside the sauce protection rim
tighten 4 torx-15 while checking slide for ease of movement . complete remaining work .

Steps.Text_raw: Fit the handle top and fix the motor, screw tight. Insert impact protection edge on lower part. Position cruise control and slide, position red upper cover vertically. When doing so, position the rear edge inside the sauce protection rim Tighten 4 * TORX-15 while checking slide for ease of movement. Complete remaining work.

Title: Samsung NaviBot SR8981 (VCR8981L3B-XEG) Disassembly

Lines.Text: first , remove the dust container from the sr8981.

Steps.Text_raw: First, remove the dust container from the SR8981.

Lines.Text: screw on the battery compartment at the green marked points and open the lid .
the blue arrow marks the connection between the battery and the housing . once this is solved , the battery can be removed from the device .
note : the orange arrow marks a usb interface that is likely to change the operating system or update it .

Steps.Text_raw: Screw on the battery compartment at the green marked points and open the lid. The blue arrow marks the connection between the battery and the housing. Once this is solved, the battery can be removed from the device. Note: The orange arrow marks a USB interface that is likely to change the operating system or update it.

Lines.Text: open and remove the brush cover on the fixing clip ( green arrow ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Open and remove the brush cover on the fixing clip (green arrow).

Lines.Text: the brush can be easily lifted out of the warehouse on the right and then removed to the right .

Steps.Text_raw: The brush can be easily lifted out of the warehouse on the right and then removed to the right.

Lines.Text: the first picture shows the side view .
second picture : the plastic bracket ( green arrow ) of the side part must be carefully levered over the plastic nose ( blue arrow ) . subsequently , the side part can be pulled backwards .
third picture : the side panel has been pulled back , now the plastic bracket ( green arrow ) and the plastic nose ( blue arrow ) are clearly visible .

Steps.Text_raw: The first picture shows the side view. Second picture: The plastic bracket (green arrow) of the side part must be carefully levered over the plastic nose (blue arrow). Subsequently, the side part can be pulled backwards. Third picture: The side panel has been pulled back, now the plastic bracket (green arrow) and the plastic nose (blue arrow) are clearly visible.

Lines.Text: loosen screws on the left ( first picture ) and on the right
second picture : carefully loosen the plastic claw and pry off the cover plate .
third picture : the navibot without cover plate

Steps.Text_raw: Loosen screws on the left (first picture) and on the right Second picture: carefully loosen the plastic claw and pry off the cover plate. Third picture: the NaviBot without cover plate

Lines.Text: remove the marked screws ( green arrows ) and remove the intermediate level .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the marked screws (green arrows) and remove the intermediate level.

Lines.Text: to disassemble the front sensor cover , the six screws on the bottom ( second picture ) must be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: To disassemble the front sensor cover, the six screws on the bottom (second picture) must be removed.

Lines.Text: remove the screws on the green arrows .

note : as you can see from the orange mark , i have numbered the connectors that do not explain themselves by their placement on both the connector and the connector . as a result , they are easier to reassign later .
release the plug connections ( fig . 2 ) . caution : especially the rigid cable connections ( figure 3 ) are a bit difficult to open and can be damaged without the proper caution .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screws on the green arrows. Note: As you can see from the orange mark, I have numbered the connectors that do not explain themselves by their placement on both the connector and the connector. As a result, they are easier to reassign later. Release the plug connections (Fig. 2). Caution: especially the rigid cable connections (Figure 3) are a bit difficult to open and can be damaged without the proper caution.

Lines.Text: once the four front screws are loosened , the front tripartite sensor board can also be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the four front screws are loosened, the front tripartite sensor board can also be removed.

Title: 1922 GE AOU Fan Power cord Replacement

Lines.Text: tip the fan to its side and remove the three size 8 screws using a 9 /32 flat-head screwdriver .
the screws may be brittle from age , so be careful .
take the bottom plate off the fan and set it aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Tip the fan to its side and remove the three size 8 screws using a 9/32 flat-head screwdriver. The screws may be brittle from age, so be careful. Take the bottom plate off the fan and set it aside.

Lines.Text: remove the three number 8 screws that hold the switch in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three number 8 screws that hold the switch in place.

Lines.Text: remove the switch , carefully sliding the speed lever out of its slot .
don't remove the switch too quickly or you can damage the head-wire .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the switch, carefully sliding the speed lever out of its slot. Don't remove the switch too quickly or you can damage the head-wire.

Lines.Text: once the switch is free , unscrew the two knurled nuts holding the wires in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the switch is free, unscrew the two knurled nuts holding the wires in place.

Lines.Text: turn the switch over and unscrew the nut securing the wire with the 5 /16 crescent wrench .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the switch over and unscrew the nut securing the wire with the 5/16 crescent wrench.

Lines.Text: remove the switch and set it aside , then pull the wire through the grommet .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the switch and set it aside, then pull the wire through the grommet.

Subject: Power cord

Title: Dirt Devil UD20005 Suction Path Replacement

Lines.Text: locate the dust cup latch and press down .
pull outwards and up with the handle to remove the cup .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the dust cup latch and press down. Pull outwards and up with the handle to remove the cup.

Lines.Text: at the bottom of the now vacant dust cup holder , locate the filter assembly and shroud . it is located just above the performance indicator
pull up on the latch indicated and remove the shroud .
be aware of any dust that may come off of the hepa filter .

Steps.Text_raw: At the bottom of the now vacant dust cup holder, locate the filter assembly and shroud. It is located just above the "Performance Indicator" Pull up on the latch indicated and remove the shroud. Be aware of any dust that may come off of the HEPA filter.

Lines.Text: putting the shroud aside , use two fingers on the edges of the filter assembly to lift the rest of it out of its housing .
note the slot that must line up with the filter during reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Putting the shroud aside, use two fingers on the edges of the filter assembly to lift the rest of it out of its housing. Note the slot that must line up with the filter during reassembly.

Lines.Text: use a prying tool , such as a spudger , to separate the foam filter from the larger hepa filter .
as mentioned previously , a lot of fine dust can kick up during this step , especially if your vacuum is extremely dirty . consider using a mask if necessary .
the picture shows a pencil being used , which works fine , but take care to not puncture or otherwise damage the foam filter .
set both of these aside with the rest of the filter assembly for cleaning later .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a prying tool, such as a spudger, to separate the foam filter from the larger HEPA filter. As mentioned previously, a lot of fine dust can kick up during this step, especially if your vacuum is extremely dirty. Consider using a mask if necessary. The picture shows a pencil being used, which works fine, but take care to not puncture or otherwise damage the foam filter. Set both of these aside with the rest of the filter assembly for cleaning later.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 2 screwdriver to remove the dust cup shroud .
the shroud is cosmetic , but this will make future steps easier .
remove the shroud by sliding it downwards over the dust cup slowly , working it off , being careful not to let it over-extend .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #2 Screwdriver to remove the dust cup shroud. The shroud is cosmetic, but this will make future steps easier. Remove the shroud by sliding it downwards over the dust cup slowly, working it off, being careful not to let it over-extend.

Lines.Text: on the bottom of the dust cup , locate the hinged door . use the screwdriver to push the two hinge pins in to remove the door .
set the door aside for cleaning .

Steps.Text_raw: On the bottom of the dust cup, locate the hinged door. Use the screwdriver to push the two hinge pins in to remove the door. Set the door aside for cleaning.

Lines.Text: with the hinged door removed , look into the dust cup and locate the two screws holding the cyclonic funnel in place .
use a 2 phillips screwdriver to remove them . the funnel will remove easily , place it aside for cleaning when finished .

Steps.Text_raw: With the hinged door removed, look into the dust cup and locate the two screws holding the cyclonic funnel in place. Use a #2 Phillips Screwdriver to remove them. The funnel will remove easily, place it aside for cleaning when finished.

Lines.Text: grip the dust collector with your hand firmly , looking for the twist-lock that attaches it to the top of the dust cup .
twist it clockwise and remove , setting it aside for cleaning .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the dust collector with your hand firmly, looking for the twist-lock that attaches it to the top of the dust cup. Twist it clockwise and remove, setting it aside for cleaning.

Lines.Text: rinse the filter shroud off in water . particulates should come off fairly easy , as they should be small . if not , scrub lightly .
rinse the foam filter off , working the particulates out with water , being careful not to damage the filter .
run water through the hepa filter in the opposite direction of the airflow . the water should be hitting the side that the foam filter usually is mounted on .
place all three items somewhere to dry .

Steps.Text_raw: Rinse the filter shroud off in water. Particulates should come off fairly easy, as they should be small. If not, scrub lightly. Rinse the foam filter off, working the particulates out with water, being careful not to damage the filter. Run water through the HEPA filter in the opposite direction of the airflow. The water should be hitting the side that the foam filter usually is mounted on. Place all three items somewhere to dry.

Lines.Text: run water through all the dust cup components , especially the dust collector , removing any lodged particulates or hair .
make sure all components are completely dry before reassembly . especially for the filter assembly , this can take up to a day .

Steps.Text_raw: Run water through all the dust cup components, especially the dust collector, removing any lodged particulates or hair. Make sure all components are completely dry before reassembly. Especially for the filter assembly, this can take up to a day.

Subject: Suction Path

Title: Holmes Blizzard Fan Oscillation Button Replacement

Lines.Text: using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the 3 screws located on the back of the fan cage .
next , loosen the screw located on the bottom of the fan .
the bottom screw does not need to be removed , but only loosened about 3 or 4 turns .
the front of the fan's cage is now able to be removed by prying the front away from the back .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #2 Screwdriver, remove the 3 screws located on the back of the fan cage. Next, loosen the screw located on the bottom of the fan. The bottom screw does not need to be removed, but only loosened about 3 or 4 turns. The front of the fan's cage is now able to be removed by prying the front away from the back.

Lines.Text: using a 7 mm socket and wrench , remove the 2 nuts that are behind the fan blades .
there is a washer located behind each nut . be sure not to lose these .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a 7 mm socket and wrench, remove the 2 nuts that are behind the fan blades. There is a washer located behind each nut. Be sure not to lose these.

Lines.Text: on the top of the fan , there is a screw fastening the oscillation button to the gear train within the housing . remove this screw with the phillips 0 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: On the top of the fan, there is a screw fastening the oscillation button to the gear train within the housing. Remove this screw with the Phillips #0 Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: the on/off and fan speed nob can be removed by simply pulling it away from the main housing .

Steps.Text_raw: The on/off and fan speed nob can be removed by simply pulling it away from the main housing.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws holding the clear plastic plate in place with a phillips 2 screwdriver .
the plate is now free and can be taken out by hand .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2 screws holding the clear plastic plate in place with a Phillips #2 Screwdriver. The plate is now free and can be taken out by hand.

Lines.Text: the motor switch is also free and can be removed by hand to reveal a screw holding the housing assembly in place .
be sure not to damage the wires on the switch during removal . while you do not need to be overly gentle during this step , excessive force could cause the wires to be pulled out .

Steps.Text_raw: The motor switch is also free and can be removed by hand to reveal a screw holding the housing assembly in place. Be sure not to damage the wires on the switch during removal. While you do not need to be overly gentle during this step, excessive force could cause the wires to be pulled out.

Lines.Text: remove the screw that holds the housing assembly in place by using a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screw that holds the housing assembly in place by using a Phillips #2 Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: the housing assembly can now be pulled off and pushed to the side to reveal the fan motor and gear train .
the oscillation button the was unscrewed earlier will fall out of the housing assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: The housing assembly can now be pulled off and pushed to the side to reveal the fan motor and gear train. The oscillation button the was unscrewed earlier will fall out of the housing assembly.

Lines.Text: the oscillation button has been removed and can be cleaned or replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: The oscillation button has been removed and can be cleaned or replaced.

Subject: Oscillation Button
