Title: Solis 537 Blender  Repair

Lines.Text: here you see the solis 836 /537 blender .
first take the blender jar off and take a look underneath . here you will find the metal rotating bit which will fit into the female gear on the motor side of the blender .
the text already shows which direction to rotate to get the knife component out of the glass jar ( turn to the right , yep this was unexpected ) . you have to apply some force to get it loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Here you see the Solis 836/537 Blender. First take the blender jar off and take a look underneath. Here you will find the metal rotating bit which will fit into the female gear on the motor side of the blender. The text already shows which direction to rotate to get the knife component out of the glass jar (turn to the right, yep this was unexpected). You have to apply some force to get it loose.

Lines.Text: when you look at this component , you will see four torx t3 screws . leave them for later and get to the other side .

get a 10 wrench and something to hold the other side . i used a pipe wrench for this , but you can use any other plier for it ( see photo for the tools ) . to loosen the bolt you have to turn it to the right ( again unexpected , must be something swiss ; ) .
if all went well you can now take all three knifes off and you will see a metal washer and underneath a rubber bushing .

Steps.Text_raw: When you look at this component, you will see four Torx T3 screws. Leave them for later and get to the other side. Get a 10 wrench and something to hold the other side. I used a pipe wrench for this, but you can use any other plier for it  (see photo for the tools). To loosen the bolt you have to turn it to the right (again unexpected, must be something Swiss ;). If all went well you can now take all three knifes off and you will see a metal washer and underneath a rubber bushing.

Lines.Text: now we come to the tricky part . you have to take the washer out to get to the rubber bushing .
i did some twisting and turning to get the washer of . i also used the ifixit metal spudger together with a small plier to get it loose .

the washer is bended in the process of taking it out . it is very difficult to get this part out , because it is tightly wrapped around the axel . i flattened by placing it in between two wooden boards together with a hammer
after you have taken the washer off , you can take the rubber off .
look at the rubber , it consists of two parts , a plastic bushing and a rubber ring . leave it like this .

Steps.Text_raw: Now we come to the tricky part. You have to take the washer out to get to the rubber bushing. I did some twisting and turning to get the washer of. I also used the iFixit metal spudger together with a small plier to get it loose. The washer is bended in the process of  taking it out. It is very difficult to get this part out, because it is tightly wrapped around the axel. I flattened by placing it in between two wooden boards together with a hammer After you have taken the washer off, you can take the rubber off. Look at the rubber, it consists of two parts, a plastic bushing and a rubber ring. Leave it like this.

Lines.Text: alright , you got this far . now we have to turn the component and unscrew the 4 torx screws .
i used a t3 screwdriver for this
loosen the axel from the underside of the blender cup .
you will see a rubber part which tightly fits into the underside of the blender cup . this rubber is encapsulating the ball bearing ( which probably is jammed ) .
take the rubber of the bearing . it looks like a car-wheel tire !

mine looked like on the foto , completely wrecked because of rubber degradation . fractions of the rubber made the bearing jam , which made the tightly fitted rubber tire rotate in its fitting , producing the burning rubber smell .

Steps.Text_raw: Alright, you got this far. Now we have to turn the component and unscrew the 4 Torx screws. I used a T3 screwdriver for this Loosen the axel from the underside of the blender cup. You will see a rubber part which tightly fits into the underside of the blender cup. This rubber is encapsulating the ball bearing (which probably is jammed). Take the rubber of the bearing. It looks like a car-wheel tire! Mine looked like on the foto, completely wrecked because of rubber degradation. Fractions of the rubber made the bearing jam, which made the tightly fitted rubber "tire" rotate in its fitting, producing the burning rubber smell.

Lines.Text: i took of the bonded rubber bits from the bearing using the metal spudger .
it took a while and gave some mess on my working table . it also smells funny and tastes terrible .
when all rubber bits are taken off , you will see a small washer on top of the ball bearings , likely to keep out the rubber of the bearing balls .
take the washer out , and you will see the balls in the ball bearing . the outside ring should rotate nicely around the axes . the bearing jammed , so this was not the case .

i took some wd40 to clean the ball bearings and wiggled the outside to get it loose . after a while this will work . use some napkins to clean the wd40 together with the rest of the rubbery bits from the bearings .
use loads of napkins , to keep yourself and your working environment clean . i also used some bandage to clean gaps in between the parts .
your hands will get black dirty !

Steps.Text_raw: I took of the bonded rubber bits from the bearing using the metal spudger. It took a while and gave some mess on my working table. It also smells funny and tastes terrible. When all rubber bits are taken off, you will see a small washer on top of the ball bearings, likely to keep out the rubber of the bearing balls. Take the washer out, and you will see the balls in the ball bearing. The outside ring should rotate nicely around the axes. The bearing jammed, so this was not the case. I took some WD40 to clean the ball bearings and wiggled the outside to get it loose. After a while this will work. Use  some napkins to clean the WD40 together with the rest of the rubbery bits from the bearings. Use loads of napkins, to keep yourself and your working environment clean. I also used some bandage to clean gaps in between the parts. Your hands will get black dirty!

Lines.Text: ok , the bearing is clean . i took some oil to lubricate the bearing .
now take the small washer or replace it with a new one to cover te balls from the rubber tire encapsulating the bearing .
take your rubber tire and encapsulate the bearing with it . i turned the rubber bit and cut of the fraying bits from it , preventing it to get stuck in between the balls .

now put everything back together in the right order . take note that you '''don't tighten the bolt to much''' , but good enough to tighten the knifes . test if the bowl is waterproof with some water . if the bolt is tighten to much , the gear will be pressed against the fitting , and the rubber will be burned when rotating at high speed !

Steps.Text_raw: OK, the bearing is clean. I took some oil to lubricate the bearing. Now take the small washer or replace it with a new one to cover te balls from the rubber "tire" encapsulating the bearing. Take your rubber "tire" and encapsulate the bearing with it. I turned the rubber bit and cut of the fraying bits from it, preventing it to get stuck in between the balls. Now put everything back together in the right order. Take note that you '''don't tighten the bolt to much''', but good enough to tighten the knifes.  Test if the bowl is waterproof with some water.  If the bolt is tighten to much, the gear will be pressed against the fitting, and the rubber will be burned when rotating at high speed!

Subject: Knife bearing

Title: Tune-up A Rancilio Silvia Espresso Machine

Lines.Text: this section assists in identifying the version of machine you are repairing . the version matters because there are slight variations in the way the repairs are performed .
this is the version 3. it is identified by the ergonomic handle , the larger steam handle with a silver cap on it , and a steam wand that is mounted on a ball joint .
version m has the same group head configuration as version 3. in appearance , version m has two lights on the front of the machine and no light on the power switch . version m is the newest version .
this is the version 2. it is identified by the smooth handle , the steam knob with ridges , and the plastic rancilio logo .
this is version 1. the handle has ridges on it . the logo is silk screened on the machine .

Steps.Text_raw: This section assists in identifying the version of machine you are repairing. The version matters because there are slight variations in the way the repairs are performed. This is the version 3. It is identified by the ergonomic handle, the larger steam handle with a silver cap on it, and a steam wand that is mounted on a ball joint. Version M has the same group head configuration as Version 3.  In appearance, Version M has two lights on the front of the machine and no light on the power switch.  Version M is the newest version. This is the version 2. It is identified by the smooth handle, the steam knob with ridges, and the plastic Rancilio logo. This is version 1. The handle has ridges on it. The logo is silk screened on the machine.

Lines.Text: lift the water tank cover and put it aside .
lift hoses from the tank and pull to the side .
pull tank straight out of machine .
make sure to tuck both hoses inside machine .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the water tank cover and put it aside. Lift hoses from the tank and pull to the side. Pull tank straight out of machine. Make sure to tuck both hoses inside machine.

Lines.Text: remove drip tray
flip machine upside down .
make sure hoses stay tucked in machine . they could get cut by the case laying on them .
remove screw with flathead screwdriver .
the new parts kit comes with a 8 mm hex head screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove Drip Tray Flip machine upside down. Make sure hoses stay tucked in machine. They could get cut by the case laying on them. Remove screw with flathead screwdriver. The new parts kit comes with a 8mm hex head screw.

Lines.Text: our favorite screwdriver for extracting difficult to remove screws . it has a big handle for a good grip . the screwdriver cannot be too long or it will hit the drip tray and won't fit . this is a craftsman 5 /16 x 1 3 /4 slotted screwdriver .
remove the screen . it may take some prying . if it is really stuck you can use a channel lock pliers .
it is okay to damage the old screen . just be careful not to damage the brass housing .
remove the small stainless steel diffuser .

Steps.Text_raw: Our favorite screwdriver for extracting difficult to remove screws. It has a big handle for a good grip. The screwdriver cannot be too long or it will hit the drip tray and won't fit. This is a Craftsman 5/16" x 1 3/4" slotted screwdriver. Remove the screen. It may take some prying. If it is really stuck you can use a channel lock pliers. It is okay to damage the old screen. Just be careful not to damage the brass housing. Remove the small stainless steel diffuser.

Lines.Text: soak this dirty little guy in coffee detergent with hot water . then clean it again with a wire brush if needed .
make sure to clean out all the water channels on the back side of the diffuser .

on version 3 you will need to remove the brass disc . just lift it out . if it is stuck you can use a channel lock pliers to get it loose . be gentle ! careful not to damage the brass . you cannot remove the brass disk on version 1 2
this is the brass disc after it is been removed . soak it in coffee cleaner with hot water for about 10 minutes . then , scrub both sides with a steel brush . get leftover coffee residue off disc .

Steps.Text_raw: Soak this dirty little guy in coffee detergent with hot water. Then clean it again with a wire brush if needed. Make sure to clean out all the water channels on the back side of the diffuser. On Version 3 you will need to remove the brass disc. Just lift it out. If it is stuck you can use a channel lock pliers to get it loose. Be gentle! Careful not to damage the brass. You cannot remove the brass disk on Version 1 & 2 This is the brass disc after it is been removed. Soak it in coffee cleaner with hot water for about 10 minutes. Then, scrub both sides with a steel brush. Get leftover coffee residue off disc.

Lines.Text: picture of grouphead with brass disc removed on version 3.
an awl works great for removing grouphead gaskets from espresso machines .
pry the gasket up with the sharp tip of the awl .
patience ! you don't want to stab or poke yourself .

Steps.Text_raw: Picture of grouphead with brass disc removed on Version 3. An awl works great for removing grouphead gaskets from espresso machines. Pry the gasket up with the sharp tip of the awl. Patience! You don't want to stab or poke yourself.

Lines.Text: if you are lucky the gasket will still be intact after you remove it . however the gasket may be hard as a rock and difficult to remove .
you may need to use the awl and a hammer to split the gasket into pieces before removal .
careful not to damage the brass grouphead when splitting the gasket .
it's time to clean the bottom of the grouphead .
we like to pour about a 1 /2 tsp of coffee cleaner on the bottom of the grouphead .

Steps.Text_raw: If you are lucky the gasket will still be intact after you remove it. However the gasket may be hard as a rock and difficult to remove. You may need to use the awl and a hammer to split the gasket into pieces before removal. Careful not to damage the brass grouphead when splitting the gasket. It's time to clean the bottom of the grouphead. We like to pour about a 1/2 tsp of coffee cleaner on the bottom of the grouphead.

Lines.Text: pour boiling hot water on the grouphead and let it soak for about 10 minutes .
take a wire brush like the one in the picture . scrub the top of the grouphead clean .
take some paper towel and soak up the liquid in the grouphead . the grouphead doesn't need to be perfectly dry at this point .

Steps.Text_raw: Pour boiling hot water on the grouphead and let it soak for about 10 minutes. Take a wire brush like the one in the picture. Scrub the top of the grouphead clean. Take some paper towel and soak up the liquid in the grouphead. The grouphead doesn't need to be perfectly dry at this point.

Lines.Text: get a pick like the one in the image . clean the inside edges of the grouphead .
clean all surfaces . first , focus specifically on the top rim that comes in contact with the portafilter . this helps the portafilter to seat correctly .
focus on the bottom surface . cleaning this surface helps the gasket to seat correctly .
use compressed air to remove all excess debris from the grouphead .
if you have version 3 do not install the brass disk until you are finished installing the new gasket .

Steps.Text_raw: Get a pick like the one in the image. Clean the inside edges of the grouphead. Clean all surfaces. First, focus specifically on the top rim that comes in contact with the portafilter. This helps the portafilter to seat correctly. Focus on the bottom surface. Cleaning this surface helps the gasket to seat correctly. Use compressed air to remove all excess debris from the grouphead. If you have Version 3 do not install the brass disk until you are finished installing the new gasket.

Lines.Text: get the new grouphead gasket .
make sure it is a rancilio brand gasket . if it is an imitation it may not be exactly the right size . this could cause many problems .
next with the lettering down insert the gasket into the grouphead . we use a 3 /16 punch to gently push the gasket into place . make sure the gasket is level on the entire surface .
if you have difficulty getting the gasket in or getting it level you may need to do a deeper cleaning of the grouphead .
if you have version 3 insert the brass disk you scrubbed earlier .

Steps.Text_raw: Get the New grouphead gasket. Make sure it is a Rancilio Brand gasket. if it is an imitation it may not be exactly the right size. This could cause many problems. Next with the lettering down insert the gasket into the grouphead. We use a 3/16" punch to gently push the gasket into place. Make sure the gasket is level on the entire surface. If you have difficulty getting the gasket in or getting it level you may need to do a deeper cleaning of the grouphead. if you have version 3 insert the brass disk you scrubbed earlier.

Lines.Text: then insert the stainless steel diffuser that you cleaned earlier .
the slotted side with the water channels should be facing down . therefore , you will not be able to see the water channels when the diffuser is installed correctly .
install the new screen .
we highly recommend against using the old screen . it can be almost impossible to get perfectly clean because it has two layers .
now put the screw in nice and tight . use a 8 mm socket wrench to do so . the screen should flex downward toward the grouphead when tightening the screw .
congratulations ! you have finished the repair .
we will be happy to hear about your experience ! please share it with us on our facebook thank you !

Steps.Text_raw: Then insert the stainless steel diffuser that you cleaned earlier. The slotted side with the water channels should be facing down. Therefore, you will not be able to see the water channels when the diffuser is installed correctly. Install the new screen. We highly recommend against using the old screen. It can be almost impossible to get perfectly clean because it has two layers. Now put the screw in nice and tight. Use a 8mm socket wrench to do so. The screen should flex downward toward the grouphead when tightening the screw. Congratulations! You have finished the repair. We will be happy to hear about your experience! Please share it with us on our Facebook pagehttps://www.facebook.com/pages/Kanen-Cof... Thank you!

Title: Jura Mahlsteine - Grindstone Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug !
remove water tank and coffee .
on the second picture you can see a new pair of grindstones on the left side and an old pair on the right . the stones consist in a ring and a cone .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug! Remove water tank and coffee. On the second picture you can see a new pair of grindstones on the left side and an old pair on the right. The stones consist in a ring and a cone.

Lines.Text: lift the two sidecovers . there are two screws , mostly torx 15.

on the rear side is an obstacle : four oval head screws looking like rivets . using an oval head bit you can turn them out . if you havent got one you can carefully use pliers . its a good idea to change the screws for normal ones . now you can raise the top cover .
if you only will work on the grinder you must not necessarily remove the side covers as described below .
the rear cover can be removed easyly . the side covers must be pushed about 1 cm backwards , sometimes this is a little bit difficult .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the two sidecovers. There are two screws, mostly Torx 15. On the rear side is an obstacle: four "oval head screws" looking like rivets. Using an oval head bit you can turn them out. If you haven´t got one you can carefully use pliers. Its a good idea to change the screws for normal ones. Now you can raise the top cover. If you only will work on the grinder you must not necessarily remove the side covers as described below. The rear cover can be removed easyly. The side covers must be pushed about 1 cm backwards, sometimes this is a little bit difficult.

Lines.Text: make a photo of the adjuster in order to restore the situation later , then pull it out .
there are two holes in which two screws hold the container for the coffee . clean them , then unscrew them . the protection cap must not be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Make a photo of the adjuster in order to restore the situation later, then pull it out. There are two holes in which two screws hold the container for the coffee. Clean them, then unscrew them. The protection cap must not be removed.

Lines.Text: now the grinder is free . again take a picture , then pull out the axis of the adjuster .
there is a silicon sealing , remove it .
watch the fabrication signs , here green . this alignment must be restored later . now turn the great black gear about 90 degrees counterclockwise . the grinder ring is free and can be lifted off .

Steps.Text_raw: Now the grinder is free. Again take a picture, then pull out the axis of the adjuster. There is a silicon sealing, remove it. Watch the fabrication signs , here green. This alignment must be restored later. Now turn the great black gear about 90 degrees counterclockwise. The grinder ring is free and can be lifted off.

Lines.Text: in the next step be very careful not to loose these three springs , balls and cartridges .
now the coffee bean feeding helix can be removed . very very carefully lift off the grinder cone

Steps.Text_raw: In the next step be very careful not to loose these three springs, balls and cartridges. Now the coffee bean feeding helix can be removed. Very very carefully lift off the grinder cone

Lines.Text: clean everything well .

the felt ring around the drive axis can be pulled out using a needle . clean it . for the inner grinder use a wet cloth , the other parts with brush and warm water . each part must be well dried before assembling it .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean everything well. The felt ring around the drive axis can be pulled out using a needle. Clean it. For the inner grinder use a wet cloth, the other parts with brush and warm water. Each part must be well dried before assembling it.

Lines.Text: push both latches alternately . the ring cover comes out .
two clamps hold the grinder ring , push them and it is free
again clean everything . press in the new ring and cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Push both latches alternately. The ring cover comes out. Two clamps hold the grinder ring, push them and it is free Again clean everything. Press in the new ring and cover.

Lines.Text: now insert the plastic entrainment , then those three cartridges , springs and balls . on top you put the cone well matching .
at last introduce the coffee bean feeding helix . screw in the central screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Now insert the plastic entrainment, then those three cartridges, springs and balls. On top you put the cone well matching. At last introduce the coffee bean feeding helix. Screw in the central screw.

Lines.Text: insert the grinder ring . turn the black gear clockwise until the three marks match again . then put in the axis of the adjuster .
its a good idea to prove if the grinder turns freely .
now reassable the remaining parts .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the grinder ring. Turn the black gear clockwise until the three marks match again. Then put in the axis of the adjuster. It´s a good idea to prove if the grinder turns freely. Now reassable the remaining parts.

Lines.Text: these two pictures are no fake : before repairing the grinder the coffee is thin and transparent . with new stones the coffee is strong and has a fine crema . the repair was a real success !

Steps.Text_raw: These two pictures are no fake: Before repairing the grinder the coffee is thin and transparent. With new stones the coffee is strong and has a fine crema. The repair was a real success!

Title: Jura Wassertankdichtung - Water Tank Sealing Replacement

Lines.Text: the instructions are suitable for nearly every model of jura and similar ones e . g . aeg and krups
unplug !
remove water tank .

Steps.Text_raw: The instructions are suitable for nearly every model of Jura and similar ones e.g. AEG and Krups Unplug! Remove water tank.

Lines.Text: lift the two sidecovers . there are two screws , mostly torx 15.

on the rear side is an obstacle : four oval head screws looking like rivets . using an oval head bit you can turn them out . if you havent got one you can carefully use tongs . its a good idea to change the screws for normal ones . now you can raise the top cover .
the rear cover can be removed easyly . the side covers must be pushed about 1 cm backwards , sometimes its a little bit difficult to move .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the two sidecovers. There are two screws, mostly Torx 15. On the rear side is an obstacle: four "oval head screws" looking like rivets. Using an oval head bit you can turn them out. If you haven´t got one you can carefully use tongs. Its a good idea to change the screws for normal ones. Now you can raise the top cover. The rear cover can be removed easyly. The side covers must be pushed about 1 cm backwards, sometimes it´s a little bit difficult to move.

Lines.Text: the support of the sealing is secured by a screw , mostly tx 15.
on the left and right side are notches , open them and raise the support .
turn it upside down .

Steps.Text_raw: The support of the sealing is secured by a screw, mostly Tx 15. On the left and right side are notches, open them and raise the support. Turn it upside down.

Lines.Text: press both plastic rivets with tiers , then push them out . the cover of the sealing is free .
change sealings . the old one was black , the new one red .
attach cover

Steps.Text_raw: Press both plastic rivets with tiers, then push them out. The cover of the sealing is free. Change sealings. The old one was black, the new one red. Attach cover

Title: Oster 3905 Outer Shell Replacement

Lines.Text: firmly grip your hand around the slot lever .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip your hand around the slot lever.

Lines.Text: stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top .

Steps.Text_raw: Stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top.

Lines.Text: forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table .

Steps.Text_raw: Forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table.

Lines.Text: both slot levers can be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Both slot levers can be removed.

Lines.Text: place the toaster upside down so the bottom is facing the ceiling .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the toaster upside down so the bottom is facing the ceiling.

Lines.Text: take off both rubber feet using a small metal spudger .
wedge a spudger under the feet and pull up to pop off .

Steps.Text_raw: Take off both rubber feet using a small metal spudger. Wedge a spudger under the feet and pull up to pop off.

Lines.Text: use a ph2 screw bit to remove eight 12 mm screws that are located around the perimeter .
there are two screws under the rubber feet .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a PH#2 screw bit to remove eight 12mm screws that are located around the perimeter. There are two screws under the rubber feet.

Lines.Text: place the toaster right side up .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the toaster right side up.

Lines.Text: grab the outer shell firmly and pull up towards the face of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the outer shell firmly and pull up towards the face of the toaster.

Lines.Text: for this part , you might need to wiggle the toaster to get the outer shell off .
the shell will not completely come off until the motherboard is removed in the next step .

Steps.Text_raw: For this part, you might need to wiggle the toaster to get the outer shell off. The shell will not completely come off until the motherboard is removed in the next step.

Lines.Text: use a j1 screw bit to unscrew eight 8 mm screws from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a J1 screw bit to unscrew eight 8mm screws from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: take out the grey cancel and bagel buttons from the shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the grey “cancel” and “bagel” buttons from the shell.

Subject: Outer Shell

Title: Oster 3905 Retractable Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: firmly grip your hand around the slot lever .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip your hand around the slot lever.

Lines.Text: stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top .

Steps.Text_raw: Stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top.

Lines.Text: forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table .

Steps.Text_raw: Forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table.

Lines.Text: both slot levers can be removed .

Steps.Text_raw: Both slot levers can be removed.

Lines.Text: place the toaster upside down so the bottom is facing the ceiling .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the toaster upside down so the bottom is facing the ceiling.

Lines.Text: take off both rubber feet using a small metal spudger .
wedge a spudger under the feet and pull up to pop off .

Steps.Text_raw: Take off both rubber feet using a small metal spudger. Wedge a spudger under the feet and pull up to pop off.

Lines.Text: use a ph2 screw bit to remove eight 12 mm screws that are located around the perimeter .
there are two screws under the rubber feet .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a PH#2 screw bit to remove eight 12mm screws that are located around the perimeter. There are two screws under the rubber feet.

Lines.Text: place the toaster right side up .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the toaster right side up.

Lines.Text: grab the outer shell firmly and pull up towards the face of the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the outer shell firmly and pull up towards the face of the toaster.

Lines.Text: for this part , you might need to wiggle the toaster to get the outer shell off .
the shell will not completely come off until the motherboard is removed in the next step .

Steps.Text_raw: For this part, you might need to wiggle the toaster to get the outer shell off. The shell will not completely come off until the motherboard is removed in the next step.

Lines.Text: use a j1 screw bit to unscrew eight 8 mm screws from the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a J1 screw bit to unscrew eight 8mm screws from the motherboard.

Lines.Text: take out the grey cancel and bagel buttons from the shell .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the grey “cancel” and “bagel” buttons from the shell.

Lines.Text: rotate the toaster so that the back is facing towards you .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the toaster so that the back is facing towards you.

Lines.Text: use the ph1 bit to remove one 8 mm screw located above the wire on the casing .
then use the same screw bit to remove two 10 mm screws found at the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the PH#1 bit to remove one 8mm screw located above the wire on the casing. Then use the same screw bit to remove two 10mm screws found at the bottom.

Lines.Text: using the metal spudger , pry next to the black clip found at the base of the toaster and the casing .
push down to separate the casing from the toaster .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the metal spudger, pry next to the black clip found at the base of the toaster and the casing. Push down to separate the casing from the toaster.

Lines.Text: gently tilt the casing towards the toaster as you pull up from the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently tilt the casing towards the toaster  as you pull up from the base.

Lines.Text: use the ph1 bit to remove the three 8 mm screws located on the back side of the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the PH#1 bit to remove the three 8mm screws located on the back side of the casing.

Lines.Text: when opening the casing a metal spring may suddenly pop out .
use the metal spudger to pry open the two halves of the casing .
if you are having some trouble only using the metal spudger do not be afraid of using your fingers to pry the casing apart .

Steps.Text_raw: When opening the casing a metal spring may suddenly pop out. Use the metal spudger to pry open the two halves of the casing. If you are having some trouble only using the metal spudger do not be afraid of using your fingers to pry the casing apart.

Lines.Text: carefully remove the spool keeping your fingers on either side of the casing .
tape down the metal spring to keep it from unraveling out of place .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully remove the spool keeping your fingers on either side of the casing. Tape down the metal spring to keep it from unraveling out of place.

Lines.Text: carefully unwind the power cord from the spool .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully unwind the power cord from the spool.

Subject: Retractable Cord

Title: Cuisinart DFP-14BCN Capacitor Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly .
remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly. Remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up.

Lines.Text: remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up .
there may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up. There may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step.

Lines.Text: remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting.

Lines.Text: take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up .
avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up. Avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp.

Lines.Text: position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left .
grab the handle and push clockwise . lift up the bowl to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left. Grab the handle and push clockwise. Lift up the bowl to remove it.

Lines.Text: turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over .
position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you .
place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over. Position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you. Place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it.

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that hold down the casing with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that hold down the casing with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers .
remove the 13.0 mm screw under each rubber foot with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers. Remove the 13.0mm screw under each rubber foot with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift off the back casing by raising it upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift off the back casing by raising it upward.

Lines.Text: orient the base of the processor so that the power cord is facing you .
locate the capacitor that you need to replace . the capacitor looks like a black cylindrical battery .
there are two capacitors in the device , but these steps refer to replacing the leftmost capacitor .
slide the plastic covering off of the white wire connection on the top of the capacitor by pulling gently .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the base of the processor so that the power cord is facing you. Locate the capacitor that you need to replace. The capacitor looks like a black cylindrical battery. There are two capacitors in the device, but these steps refer to replacing the leftmost capacitor. Slide the plastic covering off of the white wire connection on the top of the capacitor by pulling gently.

Lines.Text: lift the capacitor out of the plastic casing by pulling up .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the capacitor out of the plastic casing by pulling up.

Lines.Text: remove the capacitor by desoldering the white and black wire from the capacitor with a soldering iron .
check out this guide if you need help .
for reassembly , the new capacitor's connections will have to be soldered together .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the capacitor by desoldering the white and black wire from the capacitor with a soldering iron. Check out this [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|soldering guide] if you need help. For reassembly, the new capacitor's connections will have to be soldered together.

Subject: Capacitor

Title: iRobot Roomba 770 Battery Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the roomba over so that the wheels are facing up and the dust tray is closest to you .
using the j1 phillips screwdriver , locate and unscrew the two 11 mm phillips screws above the brushes on the battery panel .
remove the plastic plate from the battery box .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Roomba over so that the wheels are facing up and the dust tray is closest to you. Using the J1 Phillips screwdriver, locate and unscrew the two 11mm phillips screws above the brushes on the battery panel. Remove the plastic plate from the battery box.

Lines.Text: locate the 2 green tabs on the left and right of the big yellow battery .
grab the tabs with your hands and lift straight upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the 2 green tabs on the left and right of the big yellow battery. Grab the tabs with your hands and lift straight upward.

Subject: Battery

avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp .

Lines.Text: turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over .

place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over. Position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you. Place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it.

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that hold down the casing with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that hold down the casing with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers. Remove the 13.0mm screw under each rubber foot with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift off the back casing by raising it upward .

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that are holding down the button assembly using the phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that are holding down the button assembly using the Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift out the button assembly by pulling up .

Lines.Text: remove the two 5.5 mm nuts with a 5.5 mm nut driver .

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that hold the switch to the button assembly with a phillips 2 screwdriver .
the screws have glue in their threads , so this step might require a little extra force .
slide off the switch and yellow plastic to remove the button assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that hold the switch to the button assembly with a Phillips #2 screwdriver. The screws have glue in their threads, so this step might require a little extra force. Slide off the switch and yellow plastic to remove the button assembly.

Title: Magic Bullet NutriBullet Pro Disassembly

Lines.Text: to start the disassembly of the magic bullet nutribullet pro you will begin from the bottom .
flip the device over to the bottom .
unscrew the four 1 cm screws using 2 phillips head screwdriver .
remove the loose bottom portion of the device by pulling up from the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: To start the disassembly of the Magic Bullet NutriBullet Pro you will begin from the bottom. Flip the device over to the bottom. Unscrew the four 1 cm screws using #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver. Remove the loose bottom portion of the device by pulling up from the bottom.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two 1 cm screws holding down the power cord using the 2 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two 1 cm screws holding down the power cord using the #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: unscrew the three 1 cm screws on the device circled on the screws pictures using the 1 phillips head screwdriver .
lift off the grey plastic piece off .
slide off the silver metal piece .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the three 1 cm screws on the device circled on the screws pictures using the #1 Philips Head Screwdriver. Lift off the grey plastic piece off. Slide off the silver metal piece.

Lines.Text: flip the device over .
remove the three rubber seals covering the screws by pulling the components upward with the tweezer .
unscrew the three 16 mm screws using the 2 phillips head screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device over. Remove the three rubber seals covering the screws by pulling the components upward with the tweezer. Unscrew the three 16 mm screws using the #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver.

Lines.Text: pull off the casing from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull off the casing from the device.

Title: Cuisinart DFP-14BCN Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly .
remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly. Remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up.

Lines.Text: remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up .
there may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up. There may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step.

Lines.Text: remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting.

Lines.Text: take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up .
avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up. Avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp.

Lines.Text: position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left .
grab the handle and push clockwise . lift up the bowl to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left. Grab the handle and push clockwise. Lift up the bowl to remove it.

Lines.Text: turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over .
position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you .
place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over. Position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you. Place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it.

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that hold down the casing with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that hold down the casing with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers .
remove the 13.0 mm screw under each rubber foot with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers. Remove the 13.0mm screw under each rubber foot with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift off the back casing by raising it upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift off the back casing by raising it upward.

Lines.Text: unlatch the power cord from its casing at the bottom left corner of the base by lifting the cord upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Unlatch the power cord from its casing at the bottom left corner of the base by lifting the cord upward.

Lines.Text: use flat pliers to clamp down on the wide part of the plastic covering located at the power cord's white wire connection .
pull the plastic cover off of the wire by keeping the pliers clamped down and pulling away from the wires .
this may require some force .
repeat for the power cord's brown wire connection .

Steps.Text_raw: Use flat pliers to clamp down on the wide part of the plastic covering located at the power cord's white wire connection. Pull the plastic cover off of the wire by keeping the pliers clamped down and pulling away from the wires. This may require some force. Repeat for the power cord's brown wire connection.

Lines.Text: use wire cutters to cut the exposed wire on the power cord's white wire . to cut the wire , position the blades of the wire cutter over the exposed wire and clamp down .
repeat for the power cord's brown wire connection . this cuts off the connection between the power cord and motor .
pull the power cord out . it is no longer attached to the device .
for reassembly , the wires will need to be soldered together . check out this guide for instructions .

Steps.Text_raw: Use wire cutters to cut the exposed wire on the power cord's white wire. To cut the wire, position the blades of the wire cutter over the exposed wire and clamp down. Repeat for the power cord's brown wire connection. This cuts off the connection between the power cord and motor. Pull the power cord out. It is no longer attached to the device. For reassembly, the wires will need to be soldered together. Check out this [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|soldering guide] for instructions.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: Cuisinart DFP-14BCN Safety Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly .
remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your food processor before starting any disassembly. Remove the small pusher by rotating it clockwise and lifting up.

Lines.Text: remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up .
there may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the large pusher by grabbing its sides and pulling up. There may be a clicking sound from the safety feature being disengaged in this step.

Lines.Text: remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the lid from the bowl by turning it clockwise and lifting.

Lines.Text: take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up .
avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp .

Steps.Text_raw: Take out the blades by grabbing the plastic center piece and lifting up. Avoid contact with blades as they are extremely sharp.

Lines.Text: position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left .
grab the handle and push clockwise . lift up the bowl to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Position the handle of the bowl so that it is on your left. Grab the handle and push clockwise. Lift up the bowl to remove it.

Lines.Text: turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over .
position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you .
place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the food processor's base upside down by lifting it up and turning it over. Position the base so that the on and pulse buttons are facing you. Place the base on top of the food processor's bowl to keep the base from wobbling while you work on it.

Lines.Text: remove the two 13.0 mm screws that hold down the casing with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 13.0mm screws that hold down the casing with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers .
remove the 13.0 mm screw under each rubber foot with a phillips 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up the front left and the back right rubber feet by pulling back the rubber with your fingers. Remove the 13.0mm screw under each rubber foot with a Phillips #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift off the back casing by raising it upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift off the back casing by raising it upward.

Lines.Text: orient the device so that the power cord is facing you .
remove the two 10.0 mm screws that hold down the safety switch with a phillips 2 screwdriver .
pull up on the safety switch with your hands to lift it out of the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Orient the device so that the power cord is facing you. Remove the two 10.0mm screws that hold down the safety switch with a Phillips #2 screwdriver. Pull up on the safety switch with your hands to lift it out of the casing.

Lines.Text: slide the plastic covering off of the brown wire connection to the safety switch by pulling gently .
use a soldering iron to remove the solder from the safety switch for the white , brown and orange wires .
follow this guide for help with desoldering .
remove the safety switch once all of the wires are desoldered .
for reassembly , you will need to solder the white , brown , and orange wire to the new connections .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the plastic covering off of the brown wire connection  to the safety switch by pulling gently. Use a soldering iron to remove the solder from the safety switch for the white, brown and orange wires. Follow this [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|soldering guide] for help with desoldering. Remove the safety switch once all of the wires are desoldered. For reassembly, you will need to solder the white, brown, and orange wire to the new connections.

Subject: Safety Switch

Title: Shark Rocket HV301 Rotary Belt Replacement

Lines.Text: flip vacuum so the bottom base is visible .
gently pry bottom two wheels off with a plastic opening tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip vacuum so the bottom base is visible. Gently pry bottom two wheels off with a plastic opening tool.

Lines.Text: remove five visible screws with a phillips 2 screwdriver .
locate and twist the three plastic screws to the unlock position with a quarter or flathead screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove five visible screws with a  Phillips #2 screwdriver. Locate and twist the three plastic screws to the unlock position with a quarter or flathead screwdriver.

Lines.Text: remove plate covering the roller brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove plate covering the roller brush.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 2 screwdriver to extract the three screws revealed from removing the plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #2 screwdriver to extract the three  screws revealed from removing the plate.

Lines.Text: turn the vacuum over so the rotary brush is on the ground .
grab the vacuum on both sides of the hose and pull up to remove the top of the vacuum halfway .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the vacuum over so the rotary brush is on the ground. Grab the vacuum on both sides of the hose and pull up to remove the top of the vacuum halfway.

Lines.Text: gently pinch head of cable and pull upwards until casing disconnects from vacuum .
proceed with removing upper casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pinch head of cable and pull upwards until casing disconnects from vacuum. Proceed with removing upper casing.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 2 screwdriver to remove the four visible screws securing the rotary brush to the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #2 screwdriver to remove the four visible screws securing the rotary brush to the vacuum.

Lines.Text: locate rotary belt on right side of vacuum and remove from bearing .
gently lift casing to remove belt and brush from vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate rotary belt on right side of vacuum and remove from bearing. Gently lift casing to remove belt and brush from vacuum.

Lines.Text: gently pry off plastic casings on both sides of rotary brush .
lift clear plastic shell from rotary brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pry off plastic casings on both sides of rotary brush. Lift clear plastic shell from rotary brush.

Lines.Text: remove rotary belt attached to brush and replace if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove rotary belt attached to brush and replace if needed.

Lines.Text: replace belt if torn or damaged .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace belt if torn or damaged.

Title: Keurig K70 Limit Switch Replacement

Lines.Text: open the k-cup holder by lifting the handle .

Steps.Text_raw: Open the K-Cup Holder by lifting the handle.

Lines.Text: while looking upwards from underneath the keurig , remove the two 8 mm phillips 2 screws from underneath the black plastic shroud .

Steps.Text_raw: While looking upwards from underneath the Keurig, remove the two 8mm Phillips #2 screws from underneath the black plastic "shroud".

Lines.Text: remove the black plastic shroud by pushing inwards and then pulling upwards to disengage the plastic hooks that are not visible .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the black plastic "shroud" by pushing inwards and then pulling upwards to disengage the plastic hooks that are not visible.

Lines.Text: remove the two 10 mm phillips 1 screws from the switch .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 10mm Phillips #1 screws from the switch.

Lines.Text: remove the switch by cuting the two connecting wires . reconnect a replacement switch this guide to join wires with solder , or this guide to solder connections , or by using any other technique to connect wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the switch by cuting the two connecting wires. Reconnect a replacement switch  [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+join+two+wires+with+solder/37671|using this guide to join wires with solder], or [https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+To+Solder+and+Desolder+Connections/750|using this guide to solder connections], or by using any other technique to connect wires.

Subject: Limit Switch

Title: Breville JE98XL Juice Fountain Plus Filter Basket Replacement

Lines.Text: place the juicer on a flat surface . make sure the juicer is unplugged and in the off position . for the following steps , the pulp basket is on the left .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the juicer on a flat surface. Make sure the juicer is unplugged and in the "off" position. For the following steps, the pulp basket is on the left.

Lines.Text: tilt the juicer slightly to the right so the pulp basket is off of your surface .

Steps.Text_raw: Tilt the juicer slightly to the right so the pulp basket is off of your surface.

Lines.Text: pull the pulp basket down and out from under the juicer cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the pulp basket down and out from under the juicer cover.

Lines.Text: place one hand on either side of the safety locking arm .
disengage the locking mechanism by pulling down on the lever with even pressure . the lever should be free to move up or down once it has been properly disengaged .

Steps.Text_raw: Place one hand on either side of the safety locking arm. Disengage the locking mechanism by pulling down on the lever with even pressure. The lever should be free to move up or down once it has been properly disengaged.

Lines.Text: firmly grip both sides of the juicer . twist clock-wise and lift to remove the lid .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip both sides of the juicer. Twist clock-wise and lift to remove the lid.

Lines.Text: twist the filter bowl that surrounds the basket in a counterclockwise fashion . lift the bowl straight up to remove it from the juicer .

Steps.Text_raw: Twist the filter bowl that surrounds the basket in a counterclockwise fashion. Lift the bowl straight up to remove it from the juicer.

Lines.Text: to remove the filter basket from the surrounding bowl , use a plastic opening tool to create separation between the basket and the bowl .
once there is enough room , place your fingers under the grooves of the filter basket and lift up .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the filter basket from the surrounding bowl, use a plastic opening tool to create separation between the basket and the bowl. Once there is enough room, place your fingers under the grooves of the filter basket and lift up.

Lines.Text: in order to access the cutting disc , the basket must be removed from the base . to do this , simply lift the basket up and off of the base .

Steps.Text_raw: In order to access the cutting disc, the basket must be removed from the base. To do this, simply lift the basket up and off of the base.

Lines.Text: to remove the cutting disc , unscrew the three phillips 1 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the cutting disc, unscrew the three Phillips #1 screws.

Lines.Text: with all three screws removed , use a plastic opening tool to lift the cutting disc out of the filter basket .
the cutting disc has many small and sharp blades . make sure to hold the disc in between blades when handling .

Steps.Text_raw: With all three screws removed, use a plastic opening tool to lift the cutting disc out of the filter basket. The cutting disc has many small and sharp blades. Make sure to hold the disc in between blades when handling.

Subject: Filter Basket

Title: Rival CM4015 Heating Element Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the three 16 mm tri-point screws from the base plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three 16mm Tri-Point screws from the base plate.

Lines.Text: remove the base plate by pressing the plastic body away from the metal plate with your thumbs .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the base plate by pressing the plastic body away from the metal plate with your thumbs.

Lines.Text: remove the 8 mm phillips screw that attaches the power button to the inside of the coffee maker .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 8mm Phillips screw that attaches the power button to the inside of the coffee maker.

Lines.Text: use a flat head screwdriver to pry the power button from its slot in the body of the device .
make sure the tool is pressed securely under the plastic clip , in order to not break it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a flat head screwdriver to pry the power button from its slot in the body of the device. Make sure the tool is pressed securely under the plastic clip, in order to not break it.

Lines.Text: clean both the button and its slot before replacing the power button .

Steps.Text_raw: Clean both the button and its slot before replacing the power button.

Lines.Text: remove the two 8 mm phillips screws from the plastic body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8mm Phillips screws from the plastic body.

Lines.Text: remove the two 8 mm phillips screws from the chassis of coffee maker .
pull back the metal backing from the plastic body .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8 mm Phillips screws from the chassis of coffee maker. Pull back the metal backing from the plastic body.

Lines.Text: remove the four 8 mm phillips screws from the inner plastic body .
you will need a long , thin phillips screwdriver to get this deep into the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 8 mm Phillips screws from the inner plastic body. You will need a long, thin Phillips screw driver to get this deep into the device.

Lines.Text: flip the device upside down and remove the outer plastic body from the device by pulling straight up .
take your time to make sure the thin cables within the device don't tear .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the device upside down and remove the outer plastic body from the device by pulling straight up. Take your time to make sure the thin cables within the device don't tear.

Lines.Text: remove the two 8 mm phillips screws from the metal backing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8 mm Phillips screws from the metal backing.

Lines.Text: remove the 4 springs holding the water tubes by squeezing the 2 prongs together .
you may also use pliers for this step if the springs are too strong .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the  4 springs holding the water tubes by squeezing the 2 prongs together. You may also use pliers for this step if the springs are too strong.

Lines.Text: bend the heating element back and forth to wiggle the water tubes loose from the plastic .

Steps.Text_raw: Bend the heating element back and forth to wiggle the water tubes loose from the plastic.

Subject: Heating Element

Title: Keurig K70 Top  Needle Replacement

Lines.Text: locate the handle on top of the unit
locate the two torx head screws on the underside of the handle . remove them with a t15 screwdriver

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the handle on top of the unit Locate the two Torx head screws on the underside of the handle. Remove them with a T15  screwdriver

Lines.Text: bend the handle outward to remove

Steps.Text_raw: Bend the handle outward to remove

Lines.Text: while looking upwards from underneath the keurig , remove the two 8 mm phillips 2 screws from underneath the black plastic shroud .
remove the black plastic shroud by pushing inwards and then pulling upwards to disengage the plastic hooks that are not visible .

Steps.Text_raw: While looking upwards from underneath the Keurig, remove the two 8mm Phillips #2 screws from underneath the black plastic "shroud". Remove the black plastic "shroud" by pushing inwards and then pulling upwards to disengage the plastic hooks that are not visible.

Lines.Text: remove the two 8 mm screws with a ph 1 screwdrver
pull on the plastic tube to remove it
this will require a generous amount of force

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8 mm screws with a PH #1 screwdrver Pull on the plastic tube to remove it This will require a generous amount of force

Lines.Text: remove the two 8 mm screws with a ph 2 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8mm screws with a     PH #2 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: pull out on the top component perpendicular to the top face as shown . it will pop out without too much effort .

the needle is now exposed on the bottom of the part being handled in this photo . be careful where you grab this component , we recommend doing as we have done here . grab the front lip of the component ( see photo ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out on the top component perpendicular to the top face as shown.  It will pop out without too much effort. The needle is now exposed on the bottom of the part being handled in this photo.  Be careful where you grab this component, we recommend doing as we have done here.  Grab the front "lip" of the component (see photo).

Lines.Text: this is the component that should detach after pulling down .
be careful of the needle !

Steps.Text_raw: This is the component that should detach after pulling down. Be careful of the needle!

Lines.Text: on the bottom of the component is the exposed needle , which is now accessible .
if you remove the needle be careful as it may be sharp .

Title: iRobot Roomba 770 Main Wheels Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the roomba over so that the wheels are facing up and the dust tray is closest to you .
using the j1 phillips screwdriver , locate and unscrew the two 11 mm phillips screws above the brushes on the battery panel .
remove the plastic plate from the battery box .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Roomba over so that the wheels are facing up and the dust tray is closest to you. Using the J1 Phillips screwdriver, locate and unscrew the two 11mm phillips screws above the brushes on the battery panel. Remove the plastic plate from the battery box.

Lines.Text: locate the 2 green tabs on the left and right of the big yellow battery .
grab the tabs with your hands and lift straight upward .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the 2 green tabs on the left and right of the big yellow battery. Grab the tabs with your hands and lift straight upward.

Lines.Text: using the j1 phillips screwdriver , remove the 15.5 mm screw located in the center of the side brush .
remove the brush by pulling upwards .
do not lean directly over the brush when attempting to remove . removing the brush requires a firm pull and may release suddenly .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the J1 Philips Screwdriver, remove the 15.5 mm screw located in the center of the side brush. Remove the brush by pulling upwards. Do not lean directly over the brush when attempting to remove. Removing the brush requires a firm pull and may release suddenly.

Lines.Text: using the j1 phillips screwdriver , remove the two 15.5 mm screws located on the bottom of the plate covering the bottom of the roomba .
lift upwards to remove the bottom plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the J1 Philips Screwdriver, remove the two 15.5 mm screws located on the bottom of the plate covering the bottom of the roomba. Lift upwards to remove the bottom plate.

Lines.Text: using the j1 phillips screwdriver , remove the two gold 15.5 mm screws located on the blue plastic module the side brush had previously been attached too .
lift the blue module upwards . the module contains the motor for the side brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the J1 Philips Screwdriver, remove the two gold 15.5 mm screws located on the blue plastic module the side brush had previously been attached too. Lift the blue module upwards. The module contains the motor for the side brush.

Lines.Text: locate the three 15.5 mm screws surrounding each wheel . use a j1 phillips screwdriver to remove these .
the screw towards the center for each wheel may be hard to locate and may seem inaccessible . the head of your screw is long enough to reach it .
use your j1 phillips screwdriver to remove these screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the three 15.5 mm screws surrounding each wheel. Use a J1 Philips screw driver to remove these. The screw towards the center for each wheel may be hard to locate and may seem inaccessible. The head of your screw is long enough to reach it. Use your J1 Philips screwdriver to remove these screws.

Lines.Text: pull up on the wheels to remove them from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull up on the wheels to remove them from the device.

Subject: Main Wheels

Lines.Text: to start the disassembly of the magic bullet nutribullet pro you will begin from the bottom .
flip the device over to the bottom .
unscrew the four 1 cm screws using 2 phillips head screwdriver .
remove the loose bottom portion of the device by pulling up from the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: To start the disassembly of the Magic Bullet NutriBullet Pro you will begin from the bottom. Flip the device over to the bottom. Unscrew the four 1 cm screws using #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver. Remove the loose bottom portion of the device by pulling up from the bottom.

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two 1 cm screws holding down the power cord using the #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver.

lift off the grey plastic piece off .
slide off the silver metal piece .

remove the three rubber seals covering the screws by pulling the components upward with the tweezer .
unscrew the three 16 mm screws using the 2 phillips head screwdriver .

there are three separate activators with two screws each .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 8 mm screws using the #2 Phillips Head Screwdriver while holding the activator in place. There are three separate activators with two screws each.

gently pry bottom two wheels off with a plastic opening tool .

Lines.Text: locate rotary belt on right side of vacuum and remove from bearing .
gently lift casing to remove belt and brush from vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate rotary belt on right side of vacuum and remove from bearing. Gently lift casing to remove belt and brush from vacuum.

Lines.Text: gently pry off plastic casings on both sides of rotary brush .
lift clear plastic shell from rotary brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently pry off plastic casings on both sides of rotary brush. Lift clear plastic shell from rotary brush.

Lines.Text: remove rotary belt attached to brush and replace if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove rotary belt attached to brush and replace if needed.

Subject: Rotary Brush

Title: Sunbeam SM8900 Stick blender Motor Brush Replacement

Lines.Text: disconnect the stick blender from the power mains and remove any accessories from the main unit .
warning : - the motor runs at about 270 volts dc so be very careful and do not repair it while it is connected to mains power . make sure it is unplugged from the wall .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the stick blender from the power mains and remove any accessories from the main unit. WARNING:- THE MOTOR RUNS AT ABOUT 270VOLTS DC SO BE VERY CAREFUL AND DO NOT REPAIR IT WHILE IT IS CONNECTED TO MAINS POWER. MAKE SURE IT IS UNPLUGGED FROM THE WALL.

Lines.Text: 1. the variable speed dial on the top popped off by putting a narrow blade knife under it and gently twisting levering it . first position the dial to the minimum speed setting . put a tea towel over the dial , otherwise it will come off with some speed and fly off .

under the dial are two screws which attach the power cord fitting onto the unit . unscrew these . this fitting is popped out with the same thin bladed knife . take care to remember the position of the white variable speed gear ( minimum speed setting ) . the power cord socket can then be gently eased off the variable speed circuit board inside the unit .

Steps.Text_raw: 1. The variable speed dial on the top popped off by putting a narrow blade knife under it and gently twisting & levering it. First position the dial to the minimum speed setting. Put a tea towel over the dial, otherwise it will come off with some speed and fly off. Under the dial are two screws which attach the power cord fitting onto the unit. Unscrew these. This fitting is popped out with the same thin bladed knife. Take care to remember the position of the white variable speed gear (minimum speed setting). The power cord socket can then be gently eased off the variable speed circuit board inside the unit.

Lines.Text: the lower part of the unit that holds the motor and circuit board , slides into the upper shell and is held in position by 4 lugs ( 90 degrees apart ) about 15 mm away from the external joint line .

as can be seen from the photos , i cut 4 slots in the housing ( with a dremmel diamond blade ) so as to loosen the housing and used screwdrivers to force the housing off the retaining lugs . with hindsight , maybe a heat gun softening the plastic housing to just below the deformation temperature would have saved cutting the housing .
once the lugs are free , the whole motor unit , including the circuit board can be pulled out of the housing . press down the control buttons or they will jam in their rubber fittings .

Steps.Text_raw: The lower part of the unit that holds the motor and circuit board, slides into the upper shell and is held in position by 4 lugs (90 degrees apart) about 15mm away from the external joint line. As can be seen from the photos, I cut 4 slots in the housing (with a dremmel diamond blade) so as to loosen the housing and used screw drivers to force the housing off the retaining lugs. With hindsight, maybe a heat gun softening the plastic housing to just below the deformation temperature would have saved cutting the housing. Once the lugs are free, the whole motor unit, including the circuit board can be pulled out of the housing. Press down the control buttons or they will jam in their rubber fittings.

Lines.Text: use a multi-meter to check for continuity across the motor terminals . mine registered open circuit across the motor terminals so the fault was either a bad brush contact or a burnt-out armature . luckily , it was one carbon brush that had worn right down to the metal holder .

before unsoldering the circuit board from the motor , mark and photograph the position of the circuit board with the motor and also , the plastic brush holder fitting and the motor housing ( otherwise it will be hard to re-assemble and the motor may spin in reverse )

Steps.Text_raw: Use a multi-meter to check for continuity across the motor terminals. Mine registered open circuit across the motor terminals so the fault was either a bad brush contact or a burnt-out armature. Luckily, it was one carbon brush that had worn right down to the metal holder. Before unsoldering the circuit board from the motor, mark and photograph the position of the circuit board with the motor and also, the plastic brush holder fitting and the motor housing (otherwise it will be hard to re-assemble and the motor may spin in reverse)

Lines.Text: after de-soldering the circuit board from the motor , use a sharp pair of strong wire cutters to bend back the 8 lugs that are bent over the rear metal bearing housing . ( these hold everything firmly in place )

once the lugs are bent back a couple of large screwdrivers will lever out the plastic brush holder ( you can also use the knife to pry off the bearing housing prior to this to reduce force on the black plastic ) .

Steps.Text_raw: After de-soldering the circuit board from the motor, use a sharp pair of strong wire cutters to bend back the 8 lugs that are bent over the rear metal bearing housing. (These hold everything firmly in place) Once the lugs are bent back a couple of large screw drivers will lever out the plastic brush holder (you can also use the knife to pry off the bearing housing prior to this to reduce force on the black plastic).

Lines.Text: inspect the carbon brushes . one was very worn down on my model , so i removed it gently with some pliers .
i used small files and sandpaper to make a new carbon brush from an old salvaged larger brush . luckily the remaining brush had negligible wear and i was able to copy its dimensions ( see image )

Steps.Text_raw: Inspect the carbon brushes. One was very worn down on my model, so I removed it gently with some pliers. I used small files and sandpaper to make a new carbon brush from an old salvaged larger brush. Luckily the remaining brush had negligible wear and I was able to copy its dimensions (see image)

Lines.Text: after some light filing the new brush popped into its holding slot and held firmly

use two 2 mm diameter screwdrivers pushed through the holes in the plastic brush holder to hold the brushes away from each other as you push the holder back onto the motor and the brushes over the commutator

Steps.Text_raw: After some light filing the new brush popped into its holding slot and held firmly Use two 2mm diameter screw drivers pushed through the holes in the plastic brush holder to hold the brushes away from each other as you push the holder back onto the motor and the brushes over the commutator

Lines.Text: when re-assembling , i had to clamp together the bearing housing and motor in a vice while i tapped the 8 housing lugs back over the bearing housing .

make sure that the circuit board is soldered back onto the motor terminals in exactly the same position as it was before , otherwise the control buttonswill not fit in their sockets , the motor may go backwards or the housing may not fit over the motor .
the motor and circuit board should now slide into the outer shell and the 4 retaining lugs should pop into their recesses .

press in the power cord socket . screw down the cord clamp and insert the variable speed gear ( make sure it is at the minimum speed setting ) press on the speed dial , keeping it at the minimum speed setting . if you removed the housing without cutting it then there will be no need to seal it .

Steps.Text_raw: When re-assembling, I had to clamp together the bearing housing and motor in a vice while I tapped the 8 housing lugs back over the bearing housing. Make sure that the circuit board is soldered back onto the motor terminals in exactly the same position as it was before, otherwise the control buttonswill not fit in their sockets, the motor may go backwards or the housing may not fit over the motor. The motor and circuit board should now slide into the outer shell and the 4 retaining lugs should pop into their recesses. Press in the power cord socket. Screw down the cord clamp and insert the variable speed gear (make sure it is at the minimum speed setting) Press on the speed dial, keeping it at the minimum speed setting. If you removed the housing without cutting it then there will be no need to seal it.

Lines.Text: note : - the unit uses soft-carbon commutator brushes which have a limited life . the next time i repair it , i will make the new brushes from the copper based brushes that are used in vehicle starter motors . these should last about 4 to 10 times longer than the originals .

Steps.Text_raw: NOTE:- The unit uses soft-carbon commutator brushes which have a limited life. The next time I repair it, I will make the new brushes from the copper based brushes that are used in vehicle starter motors. These should last about 4 to 10 times longer than the originals.

Subject: Motor Commutator Carbon Brush

Title: Oster 3905 Heat Coil Replacement

Lines.Text: firmly grip your hand around the slot lever .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grip your hand around the slot lever.

Lines.Text: stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top .

Steps.Text_raw: Stabilize the toaster by placing your hand on top.

Lines.Text: forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table .

Steps.Text_raw: Forcefully pull the slot lever away from the toaster by keeping parallel to the table.
