Title: Saeco Vienna Sup 018 Disassembly

Lines.Text: never forget : pull the plug out !
remove all attachments such as drawers , water tank , brewing unit .
carefully pull the steam button out . if it is too tight , first loosen the cover ( steps 2 to 4 ) , lift slightly and then push the ratchet nose with a small screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Never forget: Pull the plug out! Remove all attachments such as drawers, water tank, brewing unit. Carefully pull the steam button out. If it is too tight, first loosen the cover (steps 2 to 4), lift slightly and then push the ratchet nose with a small screwdriver.

Lines.Text: it is fixed with two screws . unscrew those . the dispensers of the mill and the coffee can remain .

Steps.Text_raw: It is fixed with two screws. Unscrew those. The dispensers of the mill and the coffee can remain.

Lines.Text: the lid is equipped with four screws , two at the bottom front , two at the back up . one is a torx 10 , the other cross-slot .

Steps.Text_raw: The lid is equipped with four screws, two at the bottom front, two at the back up. One is a Torx 10, the other cross-slot.

Lines.Text: now the cover can be lifted off . pull backwards , then diagonally forward . remove the silicone hose from the water tank .

Steps.Text_raw: Now the cover can be lifted off. Pull backwards, then diagonally forward. Remove the silicone hose from the water tank.

Lines.Text: on the work table , a cloth is laid , the machine is then placed on the back . the turntable may have to be pulled out on the ground eventually .

on the right side of the floor are several rectangular openings . at the third is a catch with which the complete unit is attached . this is pushed backwards , then you can pull the entire unit upwards . this sometimes gets stuck when the machine is very dirty .
you have to pay attention to two things : the power cord must be able to slide freely , and the catch of the bottom drawer must not jam .

Steps.Text_raw: On the work table, a cloth is laid, the machine is then placed on the back. The turntable may have to be pulled out on the ground eventually. On the right side of the floor are several rectangular openings. At the third is a catch with which the complete unit is attached. This is pushed backwards, then you can pull the entire unit upwards. This sometimes gets stuck when the machine is very dirty. You have to pay attention to two things: The power cord must be able to slide freely, and the catch of the bottom drawer must not jam.

Lines.Text: a view of the unit from behind . above left the mill , in front of that the flowmeter . on the far left is the ulka pump , in the middle of the boilers for the fast steam , among the gearbox with the engine . right below the heater . right up the control electronics
from the front you can see the grinder , the base plate with the recess for the support valve and the drive shaft . on the left is the fully calcified heate

Steps.Text_raw: A view of the unit from behind. Above left the mill, in front of that the flowmeter. On the far left is the Ulka pump, in the middle of the boilers for the fast steam, among the gearbox with the engine. Right below the heater. Right up the control electronics From the front you can see the grinder, the base plate with the recess for the support valve and the drive shaft. On the left is the fully calcified heate

Title: iRobot Roomba 860 Side Wheel Assembly Replacement

Lines.Text: to remove the debris extractor , first begin by removing and emptying the trash bin .
push down and pull out on the silver button located on the top of the roomba in the back .
the trash bin should then slide out .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the debris extractor, first begin by removing and emptying the trash bin. Push down and pull out on the silver button located on the top of the Roomba in the back. The trash bin should then slide out.

Lines.Text: with the roomba upside down , locate the two yellow buttons by the extractor .
to open the flap holding the extractos in place , pinch the two yellow buttons together towards the center and pull up on the flap at the same time

Steps.Text_raw: With the Roomba upside down, locate the two yellow buttons by the extractor. To open the flap holding the extractos in place, pinch the two yellow buttons together towards the center and pull up on the flap at the same time

Lines.Text: once the flap is open , grab the yellow end of the dark gray extractor and pull up slightly .
after lifting it up about an inch , pull it out towards one of the side wheels .
the extractor should slide out with ease . repeat the same procedure for the light gray debris extractor .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the flap is open, grab the yellow end of the dark gray extractor and pull up slightly. After lifting it up about an inch, pull it out towards one of the side wheels. The extractor should slide out with ease. Repeat the same procedure for the light gray debris extractor.

Lines.Text: to remove the side wheel assembly , start by locating 2 15 mm phillips 2 point screws above the wheels .
remove the screws and pull up on the plate surrounding the side wheels .

Steps.Text_raw: To remove the Side Wheel Assembly, start by locating 2 15mm Phillips #2 Point screws above the wheels. Remove the screws and pull up on the plate surrounding the side wheels.

Lines.Text: locate and remove 3x phillips 0 point screws located behind the yellow side brush , bottom let corner of heel assembly , and on the outside of the wheel assembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove 3x Phillips #0 Point Screws located behind the yellow side brush, bottom let corner of heel assembly, and on the outside of the wheel assembly.

Lines.Text: with all the screws removed , lift up on the side wheel assembly to remove it from the roomba housing .
the other wheel can be removed and replaced the same way

Steps.Text_raw: With all the screws removed, lift up on the side wheel assembly to remove it from the Roomba housing. The other wheel can be removed and replaced the same way

Subject: Side Wheel Assembly

Title: iRobot Roomba 870 Side Brush Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the roomba over so that the back side is facing up .
using the phillips 00 screwdriver , remove the 4.0 mm screw in the center of the yellow side brush and lift the part out .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the Roomba over so that the back side is facing up. Using the Phillips #00 screwdriver, remove the 4.0mm screw in the center of the yellow side brush and lift the part out.

Lines.Text: use the phillips 00 screwdriver to remove the four 3.5 mm screws that hold down the battery panel and rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the Phillips #00 screwdriver to remove the four 3.5mm screws that hold down the battery panel and rear panel.

Lines.Text: first remove the battery panel , which is the small rectangular .
after removing the battery panel , remove the rear panel .

Steps.Text_raw: First remove the battery panel, which is the small rectangular. After removing the battery panel, remove the rear panel.

Lines.Text: remove the three small 3.5 mm screws fastened to the motor housing .
after removing the screws , remove the motor housing from the rest of the roomba .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the three small 3.5mm screws fastened to the motor housing. After removing the screws, remove the motor housing from the rest of the Roomba.

Lines.Text: remove the 2.5 mm screw in the center of the motor housing using a tri-wing y1 screwdriver .
after removing the screw , remove the top shell casing of the motor housing . underneath , you will see a white gear with two screws next to it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2.5mm screw  in the center of the motor housing using a Tri-Wing Y1 screwdriver. After removing the screw, remove the top shell casing of the motor housing. Underneath, you will see a white gear with two screws next to it.

Lines.Text: remove the two 2.5 mm screws in the inner motor housing using a phillips 00 screwdriver .
after removing the two screws , the motor will slide right out the back , and it can be replaced .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.5mm screws in the inner motor housing using a Phillips #00 screwdriver. After removing the two screws, the motor will slide right out the back, and it can be replaced.

Subject: Side Brush Motor

Title: iRobot Roomba 870  Bumper Sensor Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the iroomba over so that the underside is facing up .
using the phillips 0 screwdriver , remove the 4.0 mm screw in the center of the yellow side brush .
remove the yellow side brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the iRoomba over so that the underside is facing up. Using the Phillips #0 screwdriver, remove the 4.0mm screw in the center of the yellow side brush. Remove the yellow side brush.

Lines.Text: remove the two 3.5 mm phillips screws that hold the battery cover onto the roomba with a phillips 0 screwdriver .
remove the battery cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 3.5mm Phillips screws that hold the battery cover onto the Roomba with a Phillips #0 screwdriver. Remove the battery cover.

Lines.Text: remove the two remaining 3.5 mm phillips 0 screws that attach the base-plate to the bottom of the roomba .
remove the entire base-plate from the bottom of the roomba .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two remaining 3.5mm Phillips #0 screws that attach the base-plate to the bottom of the Roomba. Remove the entire base-plate from the bottom of the Roomba.

Lines.Text: remove the ten 3 mm screws that attach the bumper guard to the bumper with a phillips 1 screwdriver .
remove the bumper guard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the ten 3mm screws that attach the bumper guard to the bumper with a Phillips #1 screwdriver. Remove the bumper guard.

Lines.Text: be careful when removing the bumper from the roomba to prevent damage to the sensor wires . remove slowly !
lift up the roomba so that its bumper is not resting on anything , and slowly separate the bumper from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Be careful when removing the bumper from the Roomba to prevent damage to the sensor wires. Remove slowly! Lift up the Roomba so that its bumper is not resting on anything, and slowly separate the bumper from the device.

Lines.Text: remove the two 3 mm screws that attach the sensor connector to the bumper/sensor with a 1 phillips screwdriver .
carefully detach the sensor connector from the bumper and the sensor .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 3mm screws that attach the sensor connector to the bumper/sensor with a #1 Phillips Screwdriver. Carefully detach the sensor connector from the bumper and the sensor.

Lines.Text: the sensor is now loose on the bumper . be careful not to rapidly move the bumper for fear of dislodging the sensor and breaking it .
flip the bumper over , ensuring the sensor remains inside the sensor compartment .
gently remove the bumper from the black infrared sensor .

Steps.Text_raw: The sensor is now loose on the bumper. Be careful not to rapidly move the bumper for fear of dislodging the sensor and breaking it. Flip the bumper over, ensuring the sensor remains inside the sensor compartment. Gently remove the bumper from the black infrared sensor.

Subject: Bumper Sensor

Title: Waring 51BL29 Drive Coupling Replacement

Lines.Text: turn the blender on its side so the bottom panel is facing you .
unscrew the 22 mm phillips 1 screw on the indent of the panel .
unscrew the 3 screws in the rubber holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the blender on its side so the bottom panel is facing you. Unscrew the 22mm Phillips #1 screw on the indent of the panel. Unscrew  the 3 screws in the rubber holes.

Lines.Text: remove the bottom panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bottom panel.

Lines.Text: place the screwdriver in the head of the middle flat-head screw .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the screwdriver in the head of the middle flat-head screw.

Lines.Text: unscrew this screw while holding the coupling with your other hand and not allowing it to rotate .
keep in mind that this screw is reverse threaded so you will have to unscrew it righty loosey .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew this screw while holding the coupling with your other hand and not allowing it to rotate. Keep in mind that this screw is reverse threaded so you will have to unscrew it "righty loosey".

Lines.Text: once the coupling mechanism has been loosened all the way , gently pull it off the top of the blender .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the coupling mechanism has been loosened all the way, gently pull it off the top of the blender.

Subject: Drive Coupling

Title: Samsung POWERbot VR9000 Top Chassis Replacement

Lines.Text: turn off the emergency switch located at the bottom right of the powerbot .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn off the emergency switch located at the bottom right of the POWERbot.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool under the black cover , near the samsung logo on the back of the device , and partially pry open .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool under the black cover, near the Samsung logo on the back of the device, and partially pry open.

Lines.Text: slide the plastic opening tool to the left , remaining under the black cover , until two left side pins have been detached . then slide the plastic opening tool to the right until two right side pins have been detached .
grab the two clips near the front of the black cover , on in front of each wheel . pull the clips away from the wheels .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the plastic opening tool to the left, remaining under the black cover, until two left side pins have been detached. Then slide the plastic opening tool to the right until two right side pins have been detached. Grab the two clips near the front of the black cover, on in front of each wheel. Pull the clips away from the wheels.

Lines.Text: remove the black cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the black cover.

Lines.Text: insert the plastic opening tool under copper-colored cover , under the words cycloneforce , and pry open until the two pins are released .
grab the underside of the cover and lift upwards while pushing forward until the cover pops off .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert the plastic opening tool under copper-colored cover, under the words "CycloneForce," and pry open until the two pins are released. Grab the underside of the cover and lift upwards while pushing forward until the cover pops off.

Lines.Text: locate the knob at the top of the fan .

Lines.Text: remove the knob by gripping it and pulling straight up . use a spudger if it is difficult to grip .
when reassembling , be sure to align the bottom of the new knob and the turning mechanism in the fan before pushing down .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the knob by gripping it and pulling straight up. Use a spudger if it is difficult to grip. When reassembling, be sure to align the bottom of the new knob and the turning mechanism in the fan before pushing down.

Lines.Text: using the plastic opening tool , turn the device over and remove the black plastic covers over the four screw holes .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the plastic opening tool, turn the device over and remove the black plastic covers over the four screw holes.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws underneath the plastic covers .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws underneath the plastic covers.

Lines.Text: remove 5 smaller screws visible through small holes between the base and the casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove 5 smaller screws visible through small holes between the base and the casing.

Lines.Text: remove four screws on the back , two near the top and two near the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove four screws on the back, two near the top and two near the bottom.

Lines.Text: pull off the back casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull off the back casing.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws that attach the front part of the casing to the motor .

Lines.Text: remove the two middle screws attaching the black plastic cover to the front .

Title: iRobot Roomba 880 Bumper Sensors Replacement

Lines.Text: flip your roomba over so the wheels are facing up .
using a phillips 2 screwdriver , remove the side brush and place off to the side . there will be a 10 mm screw that remains in the brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip your Roomba over so the wheels are facing up. Using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, remove the side brush and place off to the side. There will be a 10mm screw that remains in the brush.

Lines.Text: remove the battery panel and 10 mm screws with a phillips 2 driver and then take the battery out of the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the battery panel and 10mm screws with a Phillips #2 driver and then take the battery out of the device.

Lines.Text: remove the two 10 mm screws holding the back plate in place using a phillips 2 screwdriver , and then remove the plate from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 10mm screws holding the back plate in place using a Phillips #2 screwdriver, and then remove the plate from the device.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the ten 10 mm screws that hold the bumper in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the ten 10mm screws that hold the bumper in place.

Lines.Text: flip your roomba over so you are looking at the face of your device .
using a plastic opening tool , pry the face plate off of the roomba .
while prying the the face plate off of the roomba , do so gently . do not force the plate off as this could result in broken pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip your Roomba over so you are looking at the face of your device. Using a plastic opening tool, pry the face plate off of the Roomba. While prying the the face plate off of the Roomba, do so gently. Do not force the plate off as this could result in broken pieces.

Lines.Text: remove the white cover that protects the motherboard .
remove the black circular face plate from your device . it is snapped in place , but you can gently pop it off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the white cover that protects the motherboard. Remove the black circular face plate from your device. It is snapped in place, but you can gently pop it off.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 0 screwdriver , remove the six 10 mm screws holding the black panel in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #0 screwdriver, remove the six 10mm screws holding the black panel in place.

Lines.Text: remove the two plastic coverings that further protect the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two plastic coverings that further protect the motherboard.

Lines.Text: this next step will require some force as the cables are securely connected to the motherboard at this time .
remove the two cables that connect the bumper and sensors from the motherboard .
as you can see in the photo , the cable and the location of where it goes on the motherboard are marked with their respective shapes .
fully disengage the bumper , along with the skinny ir sensor track from the main part of the device .
the sensor track is hidden underneath the bumper , but it connected with several wires .

Steps.Text_raw: This next step will require some force as the cables are securely connected to the motherboard at this time. Remove the two cables that connect the bumper and sensors from the motherboard. As you can see in the photo, the cable and the location of where it goes on the motherboard are marked with their respective shapes. Fully disengage the bumper, along with the skinny  IR sensor track from the main part of the device. The sensor track is hidden underneath the bumper, but it connected with several wires.

Lines.Text: rotate the device 180 degrees so you are looking at the other side .
remove the cables that are holding this part of the motherboard in place .
this might require a bit of tugging . we recommend gently wiggling the cable at the base , to help loosen the hold .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the device 180 degrees so you are looking at the other side. Remove the cables that are holding this part of the motherboard in place. This might require a bit of tugging. We recommend gently wiggling the cable at the base, to help loosen the hold.

Lines.Text: remove the 6 bumper sensors from the side of your device .
this will require some tugging as the sensors are securely situated in the device currently . we recommend using a spudger if they are particularly difficult .

you might need to cut the tape that is currently holding several sets of bumper sensor wires together . it might be helpful to tape the new sensor wires back together when putting your device back together .
as you can see in the third photo the cable from the bumper sensor was originally connected to the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 6 bumper sensors from the side of your device. This will require some tugging as the sensors are securely situated in the device currently. We recommend using a spudger if they are particularly difficult. You might need to cut the tape that is currently holding several sets of bumper sensor wires together. It might be helpful to tape the new sensor wires back together when putting your device back together. As you can see in the third photo the cable from the bumper sensor was originally connected to the motherboard.

Lines.Text: now you can easily snap the 6 replacement bumper sensors into the device , and begin the reassembly .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you can easily snap the 6 replacement bumper sensors into the device, and begin the reassembly.

Subject: Bumper Sensors

Title: iRobot Roomba 880 Cleaning Head Replacement

Lines.Text: flip the roomba over , wheel-side up .
using a phillips 1 screwdriver , loosen the four 15 mm screws illustrated . two are located on the battery door , while two are on the bottom panel .
remove the battery door , pulling straight up from the two indents above the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the Roomba over, wheel-side up. Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, loosen the four 15 mm screws illustrated. Two are located on the battery door, while two are on the bottom panel. Remove the battery door, pulling straight up from the two indents above the screws.

Lines.Text: using a flat head screwdriver , loosen the screw on the top of the side brush .
remove side brush .
the bottom panel cannot be removed without first removing the side brush , so make sure to do this first .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a flat head screwdriver, loosen the screw on the top of the side brush. Remove side brush. The bottom panel cannot be removed without first removing the side brush, so make sure to do this first.

Lines.Text: pull up on the bottom panel to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull up on the bottom panel to remove.

Lines.Text: reach underneath the dust bin , press the bin removal button , and pull out .
the bin removal button is located on the top edge of the bin .

Steps.Text_raw: Reach underneath the dust bin, press the bin removal button, and pull out. The bin removal button is located on the top edge of the bin.

Lines.Text: using a phillips 1 screwdriver , remove the four 10 mm screws shown .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a Phillips #1 screwdriver, remove the four 10 mm screws shown.

Lines.Text: remove the cleaning head by grabbing the two protruding tabs as shown , and pulling straight up .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the cleaning head by grabbing the two protruding tabs as shown, and pulling straight up.

Subject: Cleaning Head

Title: Wexford CT-166TF Air Filter Casing Replacement

Lines.Text: using a plastic opening tool , remove the four small foam pieces on the bottom of the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a plastic opening tool, remove the four small foam pieces on the bottom of the fan.

Lines.Text: remove the four screws that were uncovered in the previous step .
remove the bottom cover using a spudger if needed .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four screws that were uncovered in the previous step. Remove the bottom cover using a spudger if needed.

Lines.Text: remove the five screws that can be seen by aligning the base and the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the five screws that can be seen by aligning the base and the fan.

Lines.Text: stand the fan upright . locate and remove the two screws near the top .

Steps.Text_raw: Stand the fan upright. Locate and remove the two screws near the top.

Lines.Text: locate and remove the two bottom screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the two bottom screws.

Lines.Text: remove the back casing by pulling it away from the front casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the back casing by pulling it away from the front casing.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws attaching the motor to the front casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws attaching the motor to the front casing.

Lines.Text: remove the two middle screws connecting the air filter casing to the front casing .
remove the front casing .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two middle screws connecting the air filter casing to the front casing. Remove the front casing.

Lines.Text: remove the four remain screws holding the air filter casing together

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four remain screws holding the air filter casing together

Lines.Text: put the new air filter casing in place after cleaning the filter .
repeat steps 1-9 in reverse order to properly put back together the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the new air filter casing in place after cleaning the filter. Repeat steps 1-9 in reverse order to properly put back together the fan.

Subject: Air Filter Casing

Title: Dyson DC39 Origin  Replacement

Lines.Text: push down on the gray button located next to the power button to release the bin from the ball housing .
pull the bin away , then up from the ball housing to remove it .
if the bin won't fit back into place during re-assembly , you may need to push the grey button again .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the gray button located next to the power button to release the bin from the ball housing. Pull the bin away, then up from the ball housing to remove it. If the bin won't fit back into place during re-assembly, you may need to push the grey button again.

Lines.Text: place the ball housing on its side and orient it so that the underside of the steering assembly is facing you .
remove the four 18.0 mm torx 15 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the ball housing on its side and orient it so that the underside of the steering assembly is facing you. Remove the four 18.0 mm Torx 15 screws.

Lines.Text: using two hands , hold the ball housing with the handle in one hand and the steering assembly base in the other .
hold the steering assembly base near one of the wheels .
pull the steering assembly base directly away from the ball housing . you should notice a pin release .
push up on the steering assembly to remove it completely from the ball housing .
during reassembly , slide the steering assembly in first , then push the pin back into its locking position .

Steps.Text_raw: Using two hands, hold the ball housing with the handle in one hand and the steering assembly base in the other. Hold the steering assembly base near one of the wheels. Pull the steering assembly base directly away from the ball housing.  You should notice a pin release. Push up on the steering assembly to remove it completely from the ball housing. During reassembly, slide the steering assembly in first, then push the pin back into its locking position.

Lines.Text: remove the two 17.8 mm phillips 2 screws located in the top of the inlet hose bracket .
remove the two 13.7 mm torx 8 screws located at the opposite end of the inlet hose .
the torx 8 screws are located at an odd angle . be sure the screwdriver is secure to prevent stripping the screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two 17.8 mm Phillips #2 screws located in the top of the inlet hose bracket. Remove the two 13.7 mm Torx 8 screws located at the opposite end of the inlet hose. The Torx 8 screws are located at an odd angle.  Be sure the screwdriver is secure to prevent stripping the screws.

Lines.Text: pull the inlet hose straight up from the steering assembly .
the inlet hose 'snaps' out of its position , so you may have to apply a little extra force while pulling .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the inlet hose straight up from the steering assembly. The inlet hose  'snaps' out of its position, so you may have to apply a little extra force while pulling.

Subject: Inlet Hose

Title: Dyson DC39 Origin Cyclone Filter Replacement

Lines.Text: push down on the gray button located next to the power button to release the bin from the ball housing .
pull the bin away , then up from the ball housing to remove it .
if the bin won't fit back into place during re-assembly , you may need to push the grey button again .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the gray button located next to the power button to release the bin from the ball housing. Pull the bin away, then up from the ball housing to remove it. If the bin won't fit back into place during re-assembly, you may need to push the grey button again.

Lines.Text: remove the purple pre-filter by pulling it up and out of the bin .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the purple pre-filter by pulling it up and out of the bin.

Lines.Text: push down on the red button , located on top of the bin , to release the bottom section of the bin .

Steps.Text_raw: Push down on the red button, located on top of the bin, to release the bottom section of the bin.

Lines.Text: push the grey button located in between the parts of the red lever to release the clear , bottom section of the bin .
the grey button can only be pressed after the bottom section is open .

Steps.Text_raw: Push the grey button located in between the parts of the red lever to release the clear, bottom section of the bin. The grey button can only be pressed after the bottom section is open.

Lines.Text: you should notice several notches around the rim of the filter . slide the plastic opening tool around the rim to release the notches .
after releasing all of the notches , pull the filter away from the orange cyclone assembly to remove it from the bin .

Steps.Text_raw: You should notice several notches around the rim of the filter. Slide the plastic opening tool around the rim to release the notches. After releasing all of the notches, pull the filter away from the orange cyclone assembly to remove it from the bin.

Subject: Cyclone Filter

Title: Caribou Coffee CC-EKV8SS7 Safety Shutoff Mechanism Replacement

Lines.Text: ++ unplug the unit before disassembling to avoid electrocution . ++
remove the five ( 10 mm ) y screws from the bottom of the base . three are in a triangle around the center and two are on the corners of the flat edge .

Steps.Text_raw: ++  Unplug the unit before disassembling to avoid electrocution. ++ Remove the five (10mm) Y screws from the bottom of the base. Three are in a triangle around the center and two are on the corners of the flat edge.

Lines.Text: now you will need to 'unlock' the top and bottom of the base from each other . on the flat edge , there is a rectangle inset with one side cut out . insert a metal spudger about 1 /2 '' in to the opening to toggle open an interior tab .
with the metal tool still inserted , use an opening tool between the black and silver sides to pry the base open .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you will need to 'unlock' the top and bottom of the base from each other. On the flat edge, there is a rectangle inset with one side cut out. Insert a metal spudger about 1/2'' in to the opening to toggle open an interior tab. With the metal tool still inserted, use an opening tool between the black and silver sides to pry the base open.

Lines.Text: once you have the halves opened at least 1 /4 '' , remove the metal key and rotate the base a quarter turn in any direction .
continue using the spudger to pry open the base at each quarter turn until the sides separate easily .
the black bottom will catch on the power cord plug , to prevent total dismantlement .

once those pieces are detached , you can insert them into the replacement part , as they were .

Title: Shark Pet Perfect II Battery Replacement

Lines.Text: locate and remove the 7.5 mm phillips screw holding the battery cover in place on bottom of the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate and remove the 7.5mm Philips screw holding the battery cover in place on bottom of the vacuum.

Lines.Text: once the cover is removed , slide the plastic retaining bracket down and pull out to remove .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the cover is removed, slide the plastic retaining bracket down and pull out to remove.

Lines.Text: pull the battery out of the compartment .
carefully disconnect the quick disconnect couplers .
the couplers may be tightly secured so it may be necessary to use a small flat device to carefully loosen the coupler .
be sure to use an esd safe tool like the nylon spudger when working with wires and batteriesthis will prevent injury and/or device damage .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the battery out of the compartment. Carefully disconnect the quick disconnect couplers. The Couplers may be tightly secured so it may be necessary to use a small flat device to carefully loosen the coupler. Be sure to use an ESD safe tool like the nylon spudger when working with wires and batteries—this will prevent injury and/or device damage.

Lines.Text: completely remove the old battery from the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Completely remove the old battery from the vacuum .

Subject: Battery

Title: Shark Pet Perfect II Front Belt Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the motorized brush from the dust cup by pulling it apart .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the motorized brush from the dust cup by pulling it apart.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the five 14 mm screws from the face of the motorized brush .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the five 14mm screws from the face of the  motorized brush.

Lines.Text: separate the motorized brush face plate by using a flat prying tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the motorized brush face plate by using a flat prying tool.

Lines.Text: remove the brush roller by lifting vertically away from the brush head . it should come out easily along with the belt .
be careful in handling the belt . if stretched or damaged , the belt can cause the motorized brush to operate incorrectly .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the brush roller by lifting vertically away from the brush head. It should come out easily along with the belt. Be careful in handling the belt. If stretched or damaged, the belt can cause the motorized brush to operate incorrectly.

Subject: Front Belt

Lines.Text: separate the motorized brush face plate by using a flat prying tool .

Steps.Text_raw: Separate the motorized brush face plate by using a flat prying tool.

Lines.Text: lift the motor from the motor mount .
use a soldering tool to carefully soften the solder on the connectors .
if after re-soldering the wires to the motor doesn't cause it to begin functioning properly , you may attempt to replace it with another 18 volt dc electric hobby motor .
manufacturer does not advertise exact specifications of motor . attempt replacing motor as a last resort and do so at your own risk .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the motor from the motor mount. Use a soldering tool to carefully soften the solder on the connectors. If after re-soldering the wires to the motor doesn't cause it to begin functioning properly, you may attempt to replace it with another 18 volt DC electric hobby motor. Manufacturer does not advertise exact specifications of motor.  Attempt replacing motor as a last resort and do so at your own risk.

Subject: Front Brush Motor

Title: Vornado 133 Compact Air Circulator Fuse Replacement

Lines.Text: ensure the unit is powered off and remove the plug from the outlet .

Steps.Text_raw: Ensure the unit is powered off and remove the plug from the outlet.

Lines.Text: slide open the fuse access cover on the top of the plug by moving it towards the end of the plug .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide open the fuse access cover on the top of the plug by moving it towards the end of the plug.

Lines.Text: use a pair of tweezers or a small plastic spudger to remove the fuse from from the fuse casing . remove the end nearer to the fan body first , then the end nearer to the plug end .
the replacement fuse must be 2.5 amp , 125 volt .
do not push against the glass center of the fuse , only the metal end pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a pair of tweezers or a small plastic spudger to remove the fuse from from the fuse casing. Remove the end nearer to the fan body first, then the end nearer to the plug end. The replacement fuse must be 2.5 amp, 125 volt. Do not push against the glass center of the fuse, only the metal end pieces.

Subject: Fuse

Title: Caribou Coffee CC-EKV8SS7 Power Cord Replacement

Lines.Text: ++ unplug the unit before disassembling to avoid electrocution . ++
remove the five ( 10 mm ) y screws from the bottom of the base . three are in a triangle around the center and two are on the corners of the flat edge .

Steps.Text_raw: ++  Unplug the unit before disassembling to avoid electrocution. ++ Remove the five (10mm) Y screws from the bottom of the base. Three are in a triangle around the center and two are on the corners of the flat edge.

Lines.Text: now you will need to 'unlock' the top and bottom of the base from each other . on the flat edge , there is a rectangle inset with one side cut out . insert a metal spudger about 1 /2 '' in to the opening to toggle open an interior tab .
with the metal tool still inserted , use an opening tool between the black and silver sides to pry the base open .

Steps.Text_raw: Now you will need to 'unlock' the top and bottom of the base from each other. On the flat edge, there is a rectangle inset with one side cut out. Insert a metal spudger about 1/2'' in to the opening to toggle open an interior tab. With the metal tool still inserted, use an opening tool between the black and silver sides to pry the base open.

Lines.Text: once you have the halves opened at least 1 /4 '' , remove the metal key and rotate the base a quarter turn in any direction .
continue using the spudger to pry open the base at each quarter turn until the sides separate easily .
the black bottom will catch on the power cord plug , to prevent total dismantlement .

Steps.Text_raw: Once you have the halves opened at least 1/4'', remove the metal key and rotate the base a quarter turn in any direction. Continue using the spudger to pry open the base at each quarter turn until the sides separate easily. The black bottom will catch on the power cord plug, to prevent total dismantlement.

Lines.Text: begin detaching the circuit board by removing four rounded top ( 12 mm ) phillips head screws ( one from each corner ) .
when removing thin metal components , hand protection is recommended to avoid small but painful slices to your fingers .
find the blue and black wires that connect to the circuit board from the power cord . using moderate force , pull them away from their silver tabs on the circuit board .

Steps.Text_raw: Begin detaching the circuit board by removing four rounded top (12mm) Philips head screws (one from each corner). When removing thin metal components, hand protection is recommended to avoid small but painful slices to your fingers. Find the blue and black wires that connect to the circuit board from the power cord. Using moderate force, pull them away from their silver tabs on the circuit board.

Lines.Text: detach the power cord's grounding wire ( yellow with green stripes ) from the edge . first unbend the silver strip , then pull upwards with a small jiggle .

Steps.Text_raw: Detach the power cord's grounding wire (yellow with green stripes) from the edge. First unbend the silver strip, then pull upwards with a small jiggle.

Lines.Text: remove the two rounded top ( 12 mm ) phillips head screws from the 1 '' bar holding down the power cord .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two rounded top (12mm) Phillips Head screws from the 1'' bar holding down the power cord.

Lines.Text: disconnect five metal connectors attached to the center circle - three wires from the circuit board , and two wires from the power cord .
from the circuit board , there are two white wires and one red wire to be disconnected .
from the power cord , there is a green wire , as well as two wires ( one blue , one white ) connected with black electrical tape near the metal .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect five metal connectors attached to the center circle - three wires from the circuit board, and two  wires from the power cord. From the circuit board, there are two white wires and one red wire to be disconnected. From the power cord, there is a green wire, as well as two wires (one blue, one white) connected with black electrical tape near the metal.

Lines.Text: at this point , as long as all the color-coded wires at the end are straightened , the power cord can be pulled through the black base bottom .
discard the old power cord and insert the new power cord by following these instructions in reverse .

Steps.Text_raw: At this point, as long as all the color-coded wires at the end are straightened, the power cord can be pulled through the black base bottom. Discard the old power cord and insert the new power cord by following these instructions in reverse.

Subject: Power Cord

Title: BCG600SIL Dose Control Pro Coffee Grinder - Jamming due to Worn Impeller

Toolbox.Name: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 7 inches or more

Lines.Text: first let's verify you have the problem this tutorial is designed to fix . these images show what a bad / worn out bcg600 sil impeller looks like and then what a good impeller looks like . if your grinder has similar wear to the bad picture ( and is jamming ) then this tutorial will be able to help you .
unplug your grinder . remove the hopper and take the upper burrs out . empty out any coffee grounds ( an air gun or vacuum helps ) and then inspect the impeller blades .

if the impeller can fit through the hole ( ie : be removed just by taking out the lower burr ) then it definitely needs replacement . a good impeller should not be removable without dis-assembly and the tips of the impeller blades should not even be visible . if yours is between bad and good , make a judgement call using the pictures as a reference .

fyi : if your impeller is made of '''stainless steel''' rather than plastic ( like the picture ) , your model is not the bcg600 sil . in that case , you likely have a different model with significant design changes . stainless steel should not wear out and so your problem is elsewhere .

Steps.Text_raw: First let's verify you have the problem this tutorial is designed to fix. These images show what a bad / worn out BCG600SIL impeller looks like and then what a good impeller looks like. If your grinder has similar wear to the bad picture (and is jamming) then this tutorial will be able to help you. Unplug your grinder. Remove the hopper and take the upper burrs out. Empty out any coffee grounds (An air gun or vacuum helps) and then inspect the impeller blades. If the impeller can fit through the hole (ie: be removed just by taking out the lower burr) then it definitely needs replacement. A good impeller should not be removable without dis-assembly and the tips of the impeller blades should not even be visible. If yours is between bad and good, make a judgement call using the pictures as a reference. FYI: If your impeller is made of '''stainless steel''' rather than plastic (like the picture), your model is NOT the BCG600SIL. In that case, you likely have a different model with significant design changes. Stainless steel should not wear out and so your problem is elsewhere.

Lines.Text: once sure your impeller is worn out , you'll need a replacement part . i ended up modeling it and 3 d printing it several times at the local library . i've made the final design available for printing at www . shapeways . com ( see link below ) . of course , you can also model your own design if you wish to spend the time .
bcg600 sil impeller shop
optional video of the shapeways part with a little background from when this was '''originally designed for the bcg800 xl''' ( the impeller is the same for both the bcg600 and bcg800 models ) :
for a look at how well the new design holds up in a similar grinder ( the bcg800 ) see my 2-year teardown here :

Steps.Text_raw: Once sure your impeller is worn out, you'll need a replacement part. I ended up modeling it and 3D printing it several times at the local library. I've made the final design available for printing at www.shapeways.com (See link below). Of course, you can also model your own design if you wish to spend the time. [https://www.shapeways.com/product/NASLAGCCP/breville-coffee-grinder-impeller-upgrade|Shapeways BCG600SIL Impeller Shop] Optional video of the ShapeWays part with a little background from when this was '''originally designed for the BCG800XL''' (The impeller is the same for both the BCG600 and BCG800 models): https://youtu.be/zB5F9ha1-zs For a look at how well the new design holds up in  a similar grinder (the BCG800) see my 2-year teardown here: https://photos.app.goo.gl/868a5ReyM2XAyjZq8

Lines.Text: you'll need a 10 mm socket with ratchet ( or a 10 mm wrench ) .
a 2 phillips screwdriver with '''7 inches of shaft or longer''' , and preferably with magnetic tip ( fyi : you can rub a magnet against it to magnetize it if it's not already ) .
1 phillips screwdriver
a knife or something with a sharp edge .
sandpaper and a file are likely optional but are occasionally necessary if the 3 d printed impeller isn't a perfect fit .

for safety the grinder must be unplugged during disassembly and reassembly ! there are high voltage contacts inside that are dangerous and easy to accidentally touch when the unit is plugged in ! please unplug your coffee grinder before continuing !

Steps.Text_raw: You'll need a 10mm socket with ratchet (or a 10mm wrench). A #2 Phillips screwdriver with '''7 inches of shaft or longer''', and preferably with magnetic tip (FYI: You can rub a magnet against it to magnetize it if it's not already). #1 Phillips screwdriver A knife or something with a sharp edge. Sandpaper and a file are likely optional but are occasionally necessary if the 3D printed impeller isn't a perfect fit. FOR SAFETY THE GRINDER MUST BE UNPLUGGED DURING DISASSEMBLY AND REASSEMBLY! THERE ARE HIGH VOLTAGE CONTACTS INSIDE THAT ARE DANGEROUS AND EASY TO ACCIDENTALLY TOUCH WHEN THE UNIT IS PLUGGED IN! Please unplug your coffee grinder before continuing!

Lines.Text: remove the hopper and the upper burr and set them aside .

use a 10 mm socket to remove the nut for the lower burr . note the threads are backwards ! rotate clockwise to loosen . you may have to jerk your wrist to break the nut free without the motor turning .
if the motor starts turning , try snapping your wrist quickly to break the nut free .
set the acorn nut , lock washer , flat washer , and lower burr aside preserving the order .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the hopper and the upper burr and set them aside. Use a 10mm socket to remove the nut for the lower burr. Note the threads are backwards! Rotate CLOCKWISE to loosen. You may have to jerk your wrist to break the nut free without the motor turning. If the motor starts turning, try snapping your wrist quickly to break the nut free. Set the acorn nut, lock washer, flat washer, and lower burr aside preserving the order.

Lines.Text: turn the grind-adjustment all the way '''as fine as it goes''' . this just makes things easier later .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the grind-adjustment all the way '''as fine as it goes'''. This just makes things easier later.

Lines.Text: there are three plastic blocks that must be pried out and set aside using a knife edge . be careful and take your time prying them up and out .
underneath you will find 3 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: There are three plastic blocks that must be pried out and set aside using a knife edge. Be careful and take your time prying them up and out. Underneath you will find 3 screws.

Lines.Text: using a 1 phillips screwdriver remove each of the three top screws and set them aside .

Steps.Text_raw: Using a #1 Phillips Screwdriver remove each of the three top screws and set them aside.

Lines.Text: flip the unit over
using a 2 or 3 phillips screwdriver , remove all four of the bottom screws and set them aside .
carefully lift the bottom cover off , taking care not to place stress on the wires .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the unit over Using a #2 or #3 Phillips Screwdriver, remove all four of the bottom screws and set them aside. Carefully lift the bottom cover off, taking care not to place stress on the wires.

Lines.Text: carefully lift the cover while pulling up on the control card .
flip everything gently to the side so we can get at the internals of the grinder .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the cover while pulling up on the control card. Flip everything gently to the side so we can get at the internals of the grinder.

Lines.Text: using the long 2 phillips screwdriver ( 7 inches or more ) remove the 4 inside top screws and set aside .
next very carefully turn the grinder over to be right-side-up again . you want to avoid stress on the wires .
perhaps place the unit on a towel so there is minimal stress on the wires while we work on the top . as we continue remain aware of the wires so they do not get stressed .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the long #2 Phillips Screwdriver (7 inches or more) remove the 4 inside top screws and set aside. Next VERY CAREFULLY turn the grinder over to be right-side-up again. You want to avoid stress on the wires. Perhaps place the unit on a towel so there is minimal stress on the wires while we work on the top. As we continue remain aware of the wires so they do not get stressed.

Lines.Text: carefully lift off the top and flip it to the side . it will hang from the few wires going to the control knob .
take note that the chrome grind adjuster is set to '''fine''' and the stop-screw in the third pic is up against the plastic stop pointed to by the bottom yellow arrow .

finally , take a photo of the gap between the lip of the upper burr holder and the internal grind adjustment cylinder illustrated in the third picture by the green arrows . at reassembly later it will be very important we get back to this gap . having a photo will help you know you have succeeded .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift off the top and flip it to the side. It will hang from the few wires going to the control knob. Take note that the chrome grind adjuster is set to '''fine''' and the stop-screw in the third pic is up against the plastic stop pointed to by the bottom yellow arrow. Finally, take a photo of the gap between the lip of the "upper burr holder" and the internal "grind adjustment cylinder" illustrated in the third picture by the green arrows. At reassembly later it will be very important we get back to this gap. Having a photo will help you know you have succeeded.

Lines.Text: back the adjustment limiter stop-screw out half way . leaving it partly in insures we don't lose track of what hole it belongs in !
the stop-screw should be out just enough that you can rotate the grind adjuster freely past the stops .
rotate the grind adjuster clockwise ( second pic ) until the upper burr holder cylinder backs all the way out .
remove the upper burr holder , noting the slot orientation for later .

Steps.Text_raw: Back the adjustment limiter "stop-screw" out HALF WAY. Leaving it partly in insures we don't lose track of what hole it belongs in! The stop-screw should be out just enough that you can rotate the grind adjuster freely past the stops. Rotate the grind adjuster clockwise (second pic) until the upper burr holder cylinder backs all the way out. Remove the upper burr holder, noting the slot orientation for later.

Lines.Text: lift out the old impeller
remove and discard the felt ring . it is usually pretty ratty and the new impeller hugs the pedestal more closely and doesn't need it .
clean the grounds expeller chute in case it's clogged .
make sure you still have both washers on the drive shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift out the old impeller Remove and discard the felt ring. It is usually pretty ratty and the new impeller hugs the pedestal more closely and doesn't need it. Clean the grounds expeller chute in case it's clogged. Make sure you still have BOTH washers on the drive shaft.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 7 inches or more

Lines.Text: before installation , i recommend giving your new replacement impeller a quick rinse in the sink followed by a pat down with a towel until dry . this helps to prevent static charge later during first grinding .
press the impeller onto the shaft and check that it's a good fit . if it's too tight to go on , you can file it very slightly to make it fit .
install the lower burr on top of the impeller .

use the 3 rd pic as a reference for optimal height of the burr . if the burr is too high above the lip on the shaft ( higher than in the pic ) , try putting the nut+washer on , tightening hard , and then taking it back off . the top of the burr should be within 0.5 mm of the lip on the drive shaft as illustrated by the pic .

Steps.Text_raw: Before installation, I recommend giving your new replacement impeller a quick rinse in the sink followed by a pat down with a towel until dry. This helps to prevent static charge later during first grinding. Press the impeller onto the shaft and check that it's a good fit. If it's too tight to go on, you can file it very slightly to make it fit. Install the lower burr on top of the impeller. Use the 3rd pic as a reference for optimal height of the burr. If the burr is too high above the lip on the shaft (higher than in the pic), try putting the nut+washer on, tightening hard, and then taking it back off. The top of the burr should be within 0.5mm of the lip on the drive shaft as illustrated by the pic.
Tools_extracted: long shaft phillips 2 screwdriver 7 inches or more

Lines.Text: put the conical lower burr in place making sure it sets on the pegs of the impeller properly . then place the washers on and tighten the 10 mm nut . remember the threads are reversed .

important : tighten the nut pretty hard . the impeller , being plastic , has a small amount of springiness to it and must be squashed hard so that the height of the lower burr does not vary . if you find that the burrs are too close after you're all done , then this is the reason . tighten until the motor begins to move , and then give it an extra wack .

Steps.Text_raw: Put the conical lower burr in place making sure it sets on the pegs of the impeller properly. Then place the washers on and tighten the 10mm nut. Remember the threads are reversed. IMPORTANT: Tighten the nut pretty hard. The impeller, being plastic, has a small amount of springiness to it and must be squashed hard so that the height of the lower burr does not vary. If you find that the burrs are too close after you're all done, then this is the reason. Tighten until the motor begins to move, and then give it an extra wack.

Lines.Text: rotate the grind adjuster until the stop-screw in the first pic is near the switch pointed to by the yellow arrow . this helps the upper-burr-holder threads pickup at the correct spot .
set the upper-burr-holder in place with the slots matching the illustration in the first photo .
critical : study the second photo . while pressing down with one hand , begin to rotate the grind adjuster in the direction shown by the arrow .
continue rotating the adjuster until the upper-burr-holder is all the way down . the '''stop-screw should be about where it is in the 3 rd pic''' at this point .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the grind adjuster until the stop-screw in the first pic is near the switch pointed to by the yellow arrow. This helps the upper-burr-holder threads pickup at the correct spot. Set the upper-burr-holder in place with the slots matching the illustration in the first photo. CRITICAL: Study the second photo. While pressing down with one hand, begin to rotate the grind adjuster in the direction shown by the arrow. Continue rotating the adjuster until the upper-burr-holder is all the way down. The '''stop-screw should be about where it is in the 3rd pic''' at this point.

Lines.Text: with the upper-burr-holder all the way down , reverse direction on the grind-adjuster and rotate through 50 to 75 of a rotation .
stop when the stop-screw is right above the plastic stop shown in the first picture .
the lip should be about the height shown in the first and second pic . that's critical for your grind to match up with the labeling on the chrome-adjustment wheel after this is all done .
compare the lip height with the photo you took in step 11. make sure the gap looks the same .
screw the stop-screw back in .

'''++optional modification++''' : if you desire a finer grind capability than normal , mark the original stop-screw hole , and then move the stop-screw a few holes ''clockwise'' . then rotate the upper-burr-holder counter-clockwise till the screw hits the stop again . ++make extra sure the burrs do not touch if you do this ! ++

Steps.Text_raw: With the upper-burr-holder all the way down, reverse direction on the grind-adjuster and rotate through 50% to 75% of a rotation. Stop when the stop-screw is right above the plastic stop shown in the first picture. The lip should be about the height shown in the first and second pic. That's critical for your grind to match up with the labeling on the chrome-adjustment wheel after this is all done. Compare the lip height with the photo you took in Step 11. Make sure the gap looks the same. Screw the stop-screw back in. '''++Optional Modification++''': If you desire a finer grind capability than normal, mark the original stop-screw hole, and then move the stop-screw a few holes ''clockwise''. Then rotate the upper-burr-holder counter-clockwise till the screw hits the stop again. ++Make extra sure the burrs do not touch if you do this!++

Lines.Text: set the top back on , while making sure the chrome adjuster ring is still on the 'fine' setting .
put the 3 hidden screws back in .
try rotating the chrome adjuster ring through the entire range before proceeding . it is very important that all is correct there before moving on .
gently turn the unit upside down , taking care not to stress the wires near the base .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the top back on, while making sure the chrome adjuster ring is still on the 'fine' setting. Put the 3 hidden screws back in. Try rotating the chrome adjuster ring through the entire range before proceeding. It is very important that all is correct there before moving on. Gently turn the unit upside down, taking care not to stress the wires near the base.

Lines.Text: carefully press the bottom cover back on and then screw it into place with the 4 screws .
flip the unit over and check that grind adjustment still works well be rotating through the entire range .
when satisfied , reinstall the 3 plastic blocks that hide the top screws . take note that they have an orientation as shown in the 3 rd pic !

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully press the bottom cover back on and then screw it into place with the 4 screws. Flip the unit over and check that grind adjustment still works well be rotating through the entire range. When satisfied, reinstall the 3 plastic blocks that hide the top screws. Take note that they have an orientation as shown in the 3rd pic!

Lines.Text: look things over one last time and then reinstall the upper burr .
install the hopper without coffee .
plug it in and run the ( empty ) grinder briefly to make sure it all sounds ok . try both coarse and fine grind settings . if it sounds wrong , investigate or comment below .
if all is well , add some coffee to the hopper . dial in the grind and try it out !
tip : there is a bit of a break-in period the first week where the new impeller builds up a protective coffee coating . i recommended using a medium to light roast during this period .

Steps.Text_raw: Look things over one last time and then reinstall the upper burr. Install the hopper WITHOUT COFFEE. Plug it in and run the (empty) grinder briefly to make sure it all sounds OK. Try both coarse and fine grind settings. If it sounds wrong, investigate or comment below. If all is well, add some coffee to the hopper. Dial in the grind and try it out! Tip: There is a bit of a break-in period the first week where the new impeller builds up a protective coffee coating. I recommended using a medium to light roast during this period.

Lines.Text: if you encounter ground coffee escaping the chute and getting on the counter , it may mean your coffee is too dry , humidity is too low ( static charge ) , or even that the grinder chute is too clean .
to fix this , try placing a tiny dab of vegetable oil on your finger and rubbing it high up inside of the coffee chute . this will allow a fine layer of grounds to coat the walls of the chute .
the added friction of the grounds on the wall of the chute should slow the velocity of the grounds down enough that the overspray stops .
fyi : this whole step happens naturally with oily coffee beans , but takes a little longer than with the vegetable oil trick .
also for static charge issues in general , this is a good tip :

Steps.Text_raw: If you encounter ground coffee escaping the chute and getting on the counter, it may mean your coffee is too dry, humidity is too low (static charge), or even that the grinder chute is too clean. To fix this, try placing a tiny dab of vegetable oil on your finger and rubbing it high up inside of the coffee chute. This will allow a fine layer of grounds to coat the walls of the chute. The added friction of the grounds on the wall of the chute should slow the velocity of the grounds down enough that the overspray stops. FYI: This whole step happens naturally with oily coffee beans, but takes a little longer than with the vegetable oil trick. Also for static charge issues in general, this is a good tip: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0Dh1W40ILY

careful while lifting up the panel ! there are wires that are connected to it as shown below which are fragile .

Lines.Text: using the t10 screwdriver , unscrew the screw as shown . this should free the panel from the wires . place the panel to the side .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the T10 screwdriver, unscrew the screw as shown. This should free the panel from the wires. Place the panel to the side.

Lines.Text: using the t10 screwdriver , unscrew the three screws as shown in the picture . it is important that you take your time to unscrew all three at the same pace . we found that increments of half a turn worked best .
the decision to unclip the wires from the motherboard or remove the blue device doesn't matter on order . complete both steps before proceeding .
as easy as unclipping the wires may sound , you must be careful to avoid breaking them .

Steps.Text_raw: Using the T10 screwdriver, unscrew the three screws as shown in the picture. It is important that you take your time to unscrew all three at the same pace. We found that increments of half a turn worked best. The decision to unclip the wires from the motherboard or remove the blue device doesn't matter on order. Complete both steps before proceeding. As easy as unclipping the wires may sound, you must be careful to avoid breaking them.

Lines.Text: set the freed motherboard off to the side , but take note of the wires connected to the motherboard . on the bottom of the vacuum head , while you should have removed these four screws while dissembling the wheels double check then remove the panel . doing this will expose the engine . using your fingers and the flat head , push the blue piece forward .

the only way we could push the blue piece forward without difficulty was to put the flathead in the center of the part mentioned above and push with your thumb . it comes right out if done correctly .

Steps.Text_raw: Set the freed motherboard off to the side, but take note of the wires connected to the motherboard. On the bottom of the vacuum head, while you should have removed these four screws while dissembling the wheels double check then remove the panel. Doing this will expose the engine. Using your fingers and the flat head, push the blue piece forward. The only way we could push the blue piece forward without difficulty was to put the Flathead in the center of the part mentioned above and push with your thumb. It comes right out if done correctly.

Lines.Text: slowly pull the thin wire from the front of the vacuum cleaner out of the way . it will still be connected to the vacuum cleaner but now out of your way .

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly pull the thin wire from the front of the vacuum cleaner out of the way. It will still be connected to the vacuum cleaner but now out of your way.

Lines.Text: pinch the hose , move it upwards , and out of your way as shown . the wires will not offer any problems , however , despite how the picture .

Steps.Text_raw: Pinch the hose, move it upwards, and out of your way as shown. The wires will not offer any problems, however, despite how the picture.

Lines.Text: firmly grasping the engine , pull it upwards until you hear either a soft click or loud crack . we experience both yet the vacuum was able to function just fine afterward . keep moving it upwards until you can take the engine , motherboard , and hose out .

Steps.Text_raw: Firmly grasping the engine, pull it upwards until you hear either a soft click or loud crack. We experience both yet the vacuum was able to function just fine afterward. Keep moving it upwards until you can take the engine, motherboard, and hose out.

Lines.Text: turn the blender upside down .

Title: Nutri Ninja Ninja Blender Duo BL641 Body Disassembly
Category: Nutri Ninja Ninja Blender Duo BL641

Lines.Text: turn blender upside down

Steps.Text_raw: Turn blender upside down

Lines.Text: remove these six screws ( 0.5 inch 5 gauge phillip's head )
note : 2 of the screws will be star shaped circled in blue
lift the bottom panel off

Steps.Text_raw: Remove these six screws (0.5 inch 5 gauge phillip's head) Note: 2 of the screws will be star shaped circled in blue Lift the bottom panel off

Lines.Text: unscrew and remove these six phillip's screws . ( 0.5 inch 5 gauge phillips )
note : the screws circled in blue are 1 /8 longer and have a slightly different top than the rest . these are the only two screws that are different than the rest .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew and remove these six phillip's screws. (0.5 inch 5 gauge phillips) Note: The screws circled in blue are 1/8" longer and have a slightly different top than the rest. These are the only two screws that are different than the rest.

Lines.Text: insert pry tool in between the two plastic pieces to separate them
move pry tool back and forth from right to left until the two pieces begin to separate as shown .
pry the two pieces apart with your hands as shown in the picture to finish separating the pieces .

Steps.Text_raw: Insert pry tool in between the two plastic pieces to separate them Move pry tool back and forth from right to left until the two pieces begin to separate as shown. Pry the two pieces apart with your hands as shown in the picture to finish separating the pieces.

Lines.Text: this completes the disassembly of the main body of the blender so you can continue to perform replacements on the internal parts .

Title: Nutri Ninja Ninja Blender Duo BL641 Power Cord Replacement
Category: Nutri Ninja Ninja Blender Duo BL641

Lines.Text: unscrew the screws from the base of the blender ( these should be 5 gauge phillips head screws ) .
2 of the screws will be star shaped rather than phillips head .
remove the base plate .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the screws from the base of the blender (These should be 5 gauge phillips head screws). 2 of the screws will be star shaped rather than phillips head. Remove the base plate.

Lines.Text: identify the red and black wires topped with white-clear caps .
use pliers to squeeze the flattened part of both caps .
the black and red wires attached to the power cord should be loose and ready to pull out .

Steps.Text_raw: Identify the red and black wires topped with white-clear caps. Use pliers to squeeze the flattened part of both caps. The black and red wires attached to the power cord should be loose and ready to pull out.

Lines.Text: replace the cord by slipping the new cord's black and red wires into the caps .
pinch the middle of the cap back to the flattened position using the pliers .

Steps.Text_raw: Replace the cord by slipping the new cord's black and red wires into the caps. Pinch the middle of the cap back to the flattened position using the pliers.

Title: Eureka SuctionSeal 2.0 Pet Motor Replacement

Lines.Text: place the device upright with the brush roller closest to you .
pull up on the latch at the top of the dust cup .
tilt the top of the dust cup forward and pull towards yourself , removing the container from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the device upright with the brush roller closest to you. Pull up on the latch at the top of the dust cup. Tilt the top of the dust cup forward and pull towards yourself, removing the container from the device.

Lines.Text: locate the gray exhaust filter cover at the top of the vacuum's base .
grip the two tabs in the middle of the filter cover and rotate counter-clockwise .
lift the cover away from the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the gray exhaust filter cover at the top of the vacuum's base. Grip the two tabs in the middle of the filter cover and rotate counter-clockwise. Lift the cover away from the vacuum.

Lines.Text: pull up and unhook the two front tower latches using two fingers . these are located at the base of the tower .
pull up and unhook the latch on the back of the tower .
firmly lift the vacuum tower up and out of its stand .
the exhaust filter cover can be replaced once the tower is removed . it will not affect the steps .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull up and unhook the two front tower latches using two fingers. These are located at the base of the tower. Pull up and unhook the latch on the back of the tower. Firmly lift the vacuum tower up and out of its stand. The exhaust filter cover can be replaced once the tower is removed. It will not affect the steps.

Lines.Text: remove the four 20 mm screws on the top of the vacuum head's cover using a jis 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four 20mm screws on the top of the vacuum head's cover using a JIS 1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: turn the vacuum head so that the back is facing you .
press the handle release pedal .
rotate the top of the motor cover down while pressing on the pedal release .
the motor cover should rotate from an upright position back towards the ground , as it would if the handle were still attached .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn the vacuum head so that the back is facing you. Press the handle release pedal. Rotate the top of the motor cover down while pressing on the pedal release. The motor cover should rotate from an upright position back towards the ground, as it would if the handle were still attached.

Lines.Text: locate the two tabs on the back of the cover .
pull up on the tabs and lift the cover away from the device .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the two tabs on the back of the cover. Pull up on the tabs and lift the cover away from the device.

Lines.Text: locate the belt latch assembly . it will be on your right when the brush roll is facing you .
remove the two 20 mm screws using a jis 1 screwdriver .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the belt latch assembly. It will be on your right when the brush roll is facing you. Remove the two 20mm screws using a JIS 1 screwdriver.

Lines.Text: lift up on the belt latch assembly and remove it from the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift up on the belt latch assembly and remove it from the vacuum.

Lines.Text: grab the brush roll on both ends .
lift up on the right side of the brush roll .
lift up on the left side of the brush roll , completely removing it from its frame .
separate the brush roll from the belt and remove the brush roll from the vacuum .

Steps.Text_raw: Grab the brush roll on both ends. Lift up on the right side of the brush roll. Lift up on the left side of the brush roll, completely removing it from its frame. Separate the brush roll from the belt and remove the brush roll from the vacuum.

Lines.Text: rotate the belt until the front is above the motor shaft .
twist the belt away from you , allowing the narrow side of the belt to slip between the motor shaft and the vertical rod .
separate the belt from the motor shaft .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the belt until the front is above the motor shaft. Twist the belt away from you, allowing the narrow side of the belt to slip between the motor shaft and the vertical rod. Separate the belt from the motor shaft.

Lines.Text: rotate the motor cover upright until you hear the foot pedal click and the cover won't rotate in either direction .
remove the bottom exhaust filter .
use a 3.0 hex bit screwdriver to remove the two 20 mm screws on the top of the dust cup stand .
remove the dust cup stand .

Steps.Text_raw: Rotate the motor cover upright until you hear the foot pedal click and the cover won't rotate in either direction. Remove the bottom exhaust filter. Use a 3.0 hex bit screwdriver to remove the two 20mm screws on the top of the dust cup stand. Remove the dust cup stand.

Lines.Text: press the handle release pedal and rotate the motor cover downward until it is fully reclined .

Steps.Text_raw: Press the handle release pedal and rotate the motor cover downward until it is fully reclined.

Lines.Text: use a 3.0 hex bit screwdriver to remove the three 20 mm screws on the front of the motor cover .
the screw holes will only be visible if the motor cover is rotated completely downward .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a 3.0 hex bit screwdriver to remove the three 20mm screws on the front of the motor cover. The screw holes will only be visible if the motor cover is rotated completely downward.

Lines.Text: flip the vacuum over so that the underside of the device is facing upward .
use a 3.0 hex bit screwdriver to remove the two 20 mm screws on the bottom of the motor cover .
the two screw holes will only be accessible if the handle release pedal is still released and the motor cover is rotated downward .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the vacuum over so that the underside of the device is facing upward. Use a 3.0 Hex bit screwdriver to remove the two 20mm screws on the bottom of the motor cover. The two screw holes will only be accessible if the handle release pedal is still released and the motor cover is rotated downward.

Lines.Text: flip the vacuum so that it is right side up again with the front of the motor cover facing you .
insert either a metal spudger or a plastic opening tool into the right or left side of the cover seam .
pry upward as you move the tool across the cover , separating the top half of the motor cover from the lower half .
there will be some audible popping noises from separating the cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Flip the vacuum so that it is right side up again  with the front of the motor cover facing you. Insert either a metal spudger or a plastic opening tool into the right or left side of the cover seam. Pry upward as you move the tool across the cover, separating the top half of the motor cover from the lower half. There will be some audible popping noises from separating the cover.

Lines.Text: grip the exhaust valve at the top of the motor cover .
lift up on the left side of the exhaust valve and then pull the right side upward to pry apart the motor cover .
there will be some audible popping noises from separating the cover .
separating the cover takes a firm pull . you may need someone to assist you in pulling the cover apart .

when you remove the cover , make sure to keep the cover close to the motor . there is a short wire that connects the top of the cover to the motor . the wire can be damaged if the cover is separated too far .

Steps.Text_raw: Grip the exhaust valve at the top of the motor cover. Lift up on the left side of the exhaust valve and then pull the right side upward to pry apart the motor cover. There will be some audible popping noises from separating the cover. Separating the cover takes a firm pull. You may need someone to assist you in pulling the cover apart. When you remove the cover, make sure to keep the cover close to the motor. There is a short wire that connects the top of the cover to the motor. The wire can be damaged if the cover is separated too far.

Lines.Text: make sure the vacuum is unplugged before touching any internal components .
grip the white cable that connects the power switch to the motor . get as close as possible to the motor connection .
pull firmly to separate the cable from the motor .

Steps.Text_raw: Make sure the vacuum is unplugged before touching any internal components. Grip the white cable that connects the power switch to the motor. Get as close as possible to the motor connection. Pull firmly to separate the cable from the motor.

Lines.Text: there is a black wire that connects the cover to the motor . be careful to keep this wire connected and undamaged while removing the motor .
lift up on the left side of the motor .
move the motor to the left , sliding the motor shaft out of its circular casing .
separate the motor completely from the vacuum's base .

Steps.Text_raw: There is a black wire that connects the cover to the motor. Be careful to keep this wire connected and undamaged while removing the motor. Lift up on the left side of the motor. Move the motor to the left, sliding the motor shaft out of its circular casing. Separate the motor completely from the vacuum's base.

Subject: Motor
